items.question: A 5-year-old child presents with a solid painless nontesticular mass. No history of trauma or infection. Which of the following is the commonest testicular tumor in children?
items.explanation: MC testicular tumor in peripheral adults: Teratoma. MC testicular tumor of infants and children: Yolk sac tumor. Urology Postgraduate MCQs: The yolk sac tumor is the commonest testicular tumor in infants and children. In adults, it occurs most frequently in combination with other histological types, usually teratoma. In its pure form, the tumor has a homogeneous, yellow, mucinous appearance. 2014

items.question: Which of the following is the indicated treatment for a non-communicating hydrocele in a 2-month-old infant?
items.explanation: Answer: A. Rush5 p507 Q10.

items.question: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after passing three episodes of maroon colored stools. A similar episode occurred the night before. She is afebrile and has no abdominal pain. Her heart rate is 116 bpm and a blood pressure measured at 76/42 mm Hg. Appropriate fluid resuscitation with infusion of 20 mL/kg of normal saline ensues. Vital signs normalize and insertion of a nasogastric tube is performed. There is no blood in the NGT and golden bile is aspirated. What is the differential diagnosis in this GI bleed?
items.explanation: Answer: B, Lange, P299. Most common cause of lower GI bleed in this 2-year-old is a juvenile polyp. Anal fissures are also very common. Meckel's diverticulum is a common cause in this age group involving a large volume of painless blood. Intussusception has to be excluded but in the absence of abdominal pain highly unlikely.

items.question: Neonatal presacral mass is most likely to be:
items.explanation: Answer: D. Sesap13 category 14 Q37. Sacrococcygeal teratoma is the most common neonatal tumor occurring in the presacral region. There are benign, mature teratomas composed of elements of all three embryonic germ layers. Complete surgical excision is essential to reduce local recurrence. Neuroblastoma is the most common pediatric abdominal malignancy. Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest and these tumors occur in the adrenal medulla and paravertebral sympathetic chain in the chest and abdomen. Children present with regional or distant metastases at time of diagnosis. In children under 12 months of age, neuroblastoma may undergo spontaneous regression. The most common site for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma are the head and neck, genitourinary tract, and the extremities. Favorable prognosis is associated with age under 10 years, and tumors of the orbit or nonparameningeal head and neck, genitourinary, and biliary tract. Smaller tumor size and absence of metastatic disease are also associated with a more favorable prognosis. Ewing's sarcoma is generally associated with a worse prognosis. Wilms' tumor or nephroblastoma is a malignant renal tumor that occurs most frequently in 1- to 5-year-old children. It often presents with a palpable abdominal mass and may involve imaging studies such as computed tomography (CT) and and duplex ultrasonography are useful in identifying tumor thrombus in the renal vein and/or inferior vena cava.

items.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Hirschprung's disease?
options: It is due to absent ganglion cells in Auerbach's plexus and associated nerve trunks.
Minority of cases have involvement of the recto-sigmoid nodes and Skin
On rectal biopsy there is an increased acetylcholinesterase containing cells in the muscularis
Absent ganglion cells in both the Auerbach and Meissner plexuses
items.explanation: Answer: B, Rush5 p509. The primary clinical manifestation of Hirschprung disease is intestinal obstruction with failure to pass meconium in the first 24 hours of life or chronic constipation in older infants and children. Hirschprung disease is more common in males than in females. Affected infants are prone to the development of enterocolitis, which carries a high mortality rate if not recognized and treated promptly.

items.question: An 8-year-old boy presented with a pathological fracture of the left femur. He was noted to have abdominal distension, loss of weight and a persistent cough over a three-month period. Additional lytic lesions were seen in the vertebral bodies and in the pelvis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
items.explanation: Answer: D. Surgery Essences, P103. Neuroblastoma: Lung metastasis are rare in neuroblastoma. Metastasis is present in 60-70% of patients at the time of diagnosis. Common sites of metastasis: Long bones (MC), Liver, Lymph nodes and Skin. Encasement of abdominal aorta and IVC by tumor is common. Some neuroblastomas are sharply demarcated with a fibrous pseudo-capsule but others are far more infiltrative and invade surrounding structures including the kidney, renal vein, IVC and envelop the aorta.

items.question: A 7-year-old boy presents with recurrent attacks of pneumonia. Sputum culture showed Pseudomonas aeruginosa. His mother confirms that he had meconium ileus in the neonatal period. Which of the following is the most likely finding in this boy?
items.explanation: Answer: B, Cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. In the neonatal period, CF may present as meconium ileus.

items.question: A mother brings her two-day-old neonate because of progressive abdominal distention failure to pass meconium and bilious vomitus. Plain abdominal x-ray reveals loops of distended bowel with ground glass appearance. What is the recommended management?
options: Emergency laparotomy, bowel resection, & Bishop-Koop enterostomy
Intravenous hydration, and a gastrografin enema
Emergency laparotomy, bowel resection, and anastomosis
Sweat chloride test and pancreatic enzyme therapy
items.explanation: Answer: C, Medcosmos Pediatric Surgery MCQ. Meconium ileus is a form of intestinal obstruction that occurs in 10% to 15% of neonates with cystic fibrosis. The obstruction is related to intraluminal concretions of abnormal meconium. The treatment of choice is adequate hydration and evacuation with a hypertonic gastrografin enema.

items.question: Which of the following is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children?
items.explanation: Answer: C. Schwartz ABSITE 9, p.490. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents. It can occur at any site that has striated muscle.

items.question: Regarding paracolostomy hernia, all are true EXCEPT:
options: It is the most common late complication of colostomy
It should always be repaired because the high risk of strangulation
Placing the stoma lateral to the rectus sheath is a risk factor
Placing the stoma in a previous scar is a risk factor
Colostomy has a higher parastomal hernia than ileostomy
items.explanation: Answer: B. Schwartz 10e p1193. Parastomal hernias are very common late complications of a colostomy. Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic hernias are usually followed expectantly. Repair is indicated if the hernia is symptomatic, large, or interferes with stoma care.

items.question: Which of the following statements about irradiation with advanced rectal cancer treated with chemoradiotherapy is TRUE?
options: A complete clinical response occurs in 50% of cases
Most complete clinical responses will have a pathologic response
With complete pathologic response recurrence rates are low
Prognosis correlates better with pretreatment staging
Final pathologic staging is more predictive of outcome
items.explanation: Answer: E. Sesap14 category 12 part II Q12. Preoperative chemoradiation therapy is standard treatment for locally advanced rectal cancer (T3-4 or N1-2 by ultrasound or MRI). Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy for rectal cancer can result in significant down-staging of these tumors. A complete pathologic response, i.e., no residual tumor in resection specimen, is seen in 10% of cases. One in five patients will have a complete clinical response, i.e., no residual cancer detected either by digital rectal examination, proctoscopy, or ultrasound.

items.question: Biopsy of a villous lesion of the rectum starting from anal verge and extending proximally for 5 cm reveals cellular atypia. Which of the following steps is most appropriate for management?
items.explanation: Answer: C. Rush4 p419. A villous adenoma of the dimensions given has a 30-50% chance of harboring cancer. The sigmoidoscopic biopsy represents a limited sample size and is not adequate proof of the lesion's precise histologic characteristics. In this instance, the finding of atypia suggests a high probability of cancer elsewhere in the adenoma. Complete full-thickness transanal excision of the lesion should be performed.

items.question: The most common indication for surgery secondary to acute diverticulitis is:
items.explanation: Answer: A. Medicosmos Large Intestine Q19. Complications of diverticular disease include obstruction, fistulization, hemorrhage, and infection. By far, the most common indication for surgery is intra-abdominal abscess formation, accounting for 40% to 50% of all complications of diverticulitis.

items.question: A 56-year-old woman has rectal cancer found on colonoscopy performed for evaluation of rectal bleeding. The optimal method for assessing whether preoperative combined modality therapy is indicated in this patient would be:
items.explanation: Answer: A. Sesap13 categ.3 Q51. Multiple randomized controlled studies have demonstrated the value of adjuvant chemoradiation therapy in improving both local control and long-term survival for patients with stage II and stage III adenocarcinomas of the rectum. Patients with stage I rectal cancer do not require adjuvant therapy. Preoperative combined chemoradiation is preferred to postoperative, making preoperative staging critical. EUS is 90% accurate in determining the T stage and 75% in nodal status.

items.question: Transanal local excision alone may provide adequate cancer treatment for patients with:
options: T2, 1 cm distal rectal cancer which is poorly differentiated
T1, 2 cm distal rectal cancer and well differentiated
T1, 2 cm cancer 10 cm above the puborectalis
items.explanation: Answer: D. Sabiston 20e p1379. Transanal endoscopic microsurgery is an approach for the local excision of favorable rectal tumors (T1 cancers and sessile polyps).

items.question: Which of the following is an abandoned treatment for anal fissure:
items.explanation: Answer: E. B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 2e p697. Anal dilatation is no longer recommended because it often results in fecal incontinence.

items.question: In the surgical management of colonic cancer, which statement is CORRECT?
options: The majority are irresectable at the time of presentation
Resection should be deferred if the tumor is not obstructing
Hepatic metastasis detected intraoperatively should be resected
Adequate distal bowel resection is more important than proximal resection
There is no place for primary anastomosis after resection
items.explanation: Answer: D? (Note: The provided answer key in the image suggests D, but notes adequate distal bowel resection). In general, for colon cancer, proximal and distal margins of at least 5 cm are recommended.

items.question: A 40-year-old woman with a 10-year history of Crohn's pancolitis undergoes colonoscopy. Biopsy samples of the colonic mucosa at the sigmoid reveal severe dysplasia. Management would consist of:
options: Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch and reconstruction
Repeat colonoscopy with biopsy in 3 months
items.explanation: Answer: B. ABSITE Virgil, 9e p72. Both Crohn disease and UC predispose to colon cancer, particularly in the presence of pancolitis. Thus, surveillance colonoscopy with random biopsies is recommended for both. The finding of severe dysplasia would warrant surgery. Since the entire colon is at risk, total proctocolectomy is the procedure of choice.

items.question: Which of the following statements about medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is TRUE?
options: The most aggressive form is MEN2B
Normal calcitonin level exclude the diagnosis
MEN2B is associated with mucosal neuromas, pheochromagemas, and characteristic phenotype that includes marfanoid habitus and skeletal abnormalities. MEN2B is much more aggressive than MEN2A.
items.explanation: Answer: B. Sesap14 category 12 part I Q6. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is an unusual tumor, representing 5% to 10% of all thyroid cancers. Three of the four forms of MTC are hereditary, namely MEN2A, MEN2B, and familial MTC. MEN2B is characterized by MTC, pheochromagemas, and characteristic phenotype that includes marfanoid habitus and skeletal abnormalities. MEN2B is much more aggressive than MEN2A.

items.question: A 43-year-old man presents with small bowel obstruction. At laparotomy he has multiple tumors on the wall of the small bowel, one of which has resulted in a bowel intussusception. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Answer: C. Sesap14 category 12 II Q1. The small intestine accounts for less than 25% of the gastrointestinal neoplasms. Small bowel tumors may present with gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, pain, or obstruction. The most common neoplasms of the small bowel include adenocarcinoma, carcinoid, gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), lymphoma, endocrine tumors, and metastatic tumors. Neoplasms of the small bowel, especially metastatic melanoma, are much more likely to be multifocal than primary tumors.

items.question: With regard to the natural history of breast cancer, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Virtually all patients with untreated breast cancer die within 5 years of their diagnosis
The likelihood of distant metastasis is related to primary size and involvement of axillary lymph nodes
The most common initial site of distant metastasis is the liver
Stage for stage, the survival rate for breast cancer in males is lower than in females
Mastectomy has been shown to improve survival when compared with breast conservation in patients with stage I and II breast carcinoma
items.explanation: Answer: B. Rush 5 p189. Breast cancer is a disease of wide biologic variability. The 5-year survival rate for stage 0 (carcinoma in situ with no regional node involvement or distant metastasis) is nearly 100%, whereas the 5-year survival rate for stage IV disease (distant metastasis) is 20%. Increased size and positive axillary nodes are associated with a greater chance for distant metastasis.

items.question: 90. A 24-year-old man, whose father was just diagnosed with colon cancer, is worried about screening colonoscopy for himself. Which of the following is MOST supportive for a clinical suspicion of Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC)?
options: Same side father and two uncles with colon cancer
Same side father, uncle and grandfather with colon cancer
Same side father and grandfather with colon cancer
Same side father and uncle with colon cancer
A father with colon cancer at 50 year of age
items.explanation: Answer: B? (Note: The Amsterdam criteria are used to clinically diagnose HNPCC. These criteria are: at least 3 relatives with histologically confirmed colon cancer, one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two; at least 2 successive generations; at least one diagnosed before age 50.)

items.question: 91. Concerning prognosis of phyllodes tumor of the breast, which statement is INCORRECT?
options: There is a clear positive correlation between the size and probability of local recurrence after excision
The tumor is more aggressive in adolescent than in other age groups
Histopathological feature of tumor necrosis is a signal of poor prognosis
Lymph nodes involvement is a poor prognostic signal
P53 overexpression is a marker of poor prognosis
items.explanation: Answer: B? (Note: Phyllodes tumors are rare fibroepithelial lesions. Most are benign, but some can be malignant. Wide local excision with 1 cm margins is the treatment of choice.)

items.question: 92. The followings are characteristics of BRCA 1-associated breast cancer EXCEPT:
options: Mostly of the invasive ductal carcinoma type
More aggressive with a worse outcome than sporadic cancer
items.explanation: Answer: C. Schwartz ABSITE 10e p515. BRCA1-associated breast cancers are typically 'triple-negative' (ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2-negative).

items.question: 93. Which one of the following statements regarding BRCA2 associated breast cancer is false?
options: They are more frequently grade III tumours
They are often estrogen receptor (ER) positive
items.explanation: Answer: B. MCQs for FRCS. They are often ER positive.

items.question: 95. A patient has a 5 cm suspicious mass in his anterior thigh. You get an MRI and the bone, vascular structures, and nerves are not involved. You think it's a lipoma, but you are not sure. The patient should:
items.explanation: Answer: D. ABSITE Review 6e Fiser p140: Core needle biopsy (best, 95% accurate); if that fails -> incisional biopsy for masses > 4 cm, excisional biopsy for masses < 4 cm. Longitudinal incisional biopsy for masses > 4 cm to eventually resect biopsy skin site if biopsy shows sarcoma.

items.question: 97. In the above patient (56 y/o woman with 2 cm ductal carcinoma), instead of finding no nodes, you find 3 blue nodes. The next appropriate step is:
options: Take the first blue node close to breast
items.explanation: Answer: D. The ABSITE Review 3rd e Fiser p157. For patients with a positive sentinel lymph node biopsy, a formal axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) has traditionally been the standard of care to ensure regional control and accurate staging.

items.question: 98. Pseudo-achalasia:
options: Is usually caused by an esophageal or gastric tumor
Refers to Achalasia with hiatal hernia
items.explanation: Answer: A. B&L 26e p1014: Pseudoachalasia is an achalasia-like disorder that is usually produced by adenocarcinoma of the cardia, but has also been described in relation to benign tumours at this level. Evaluation with endoscopy and CT is required to rule out malignancy.

items.question: 99. A 40-year-old woman on no medications or past medical problems presents with intermittent abdominal pain. She undergoes a contrast abdominal CT scan which shows a 4 cm hypervascular liver lesion. Sulfur colloid scan shows no uptake. AFP is normal. There is obvious peripheral to central enhancement on the contrasted CT scan. The most appropriate next step is:
options: Resection if the lesion is resectable
items.explanation: Answer: B. Rush 5e p333. Hemangiomas are the most common benign liver tumors and occur in 7% of the population. They are characterized by collections of dilated blood vessels and can be diagnosed by their appearance on noninvasive imaging studies. A 'peripheral-to-central enhancement' pattern on CT is classic for hemangioma. Most are asymptomatic and require no treatment.

items.question: 100. In an average male patient, the most distal extent of a rectal cancer which still allows for a low anterior resection with an appropriate margin is:
items.explanation: Answer: D. ABSITE REVIEW MCQ 2e Fiser p425. The most distal rectal tumor extent which would still allow a 2 cm distal margin is about 2 cm from the proximal anal canal.

items.question: 6. A 69-year-old male patient having coronary artery disease was found to have gallbladder stones while undergoing routine ultrasound of the abdomen. There was no history of biliary colic or jaundice at any time. What is the BEST treatment advice for such a patient for his gallbladder stones?
options: No surgery for the gallbladder stones
items.explanation: Answer: C, Surgery Essence8 p179. There was no clear cost benefit and no life-years were gained from prophylactic cholecystectomy, indicating no clear-cut advantages of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis. Expectant management is recommended.

items.question: 7. In a female in the reproductive age group suspect of having acute appendicitis laparoscopic approach is better because of:
options: Better method of avoiding unnecessary appendicectomy
items.explanation: Answer: B? (Note: The provided key in the text says B, but the reasoning often emphasizes D—avoiding unnecessary surgery—in women of reproductive age where pelvic inflammatory disease or ovarian issues are differentials.)

items.question: 8. Which of the following instruments is mostly responsible of inadvertent bowel injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
items.explanation: Answer: A. Monopolar 'hook' diathermy can cause unrecognized thermal injury due to stray current or direct contact, leading to delayed bowel perforation.

items.question: 28. Which of the following is considered the most common early complication after open inguinal hernia repair?
items.explanation: Answer: B. General Surgery Examination & Board Review p67. The overall risk of complications following open inguinal hernia repair is low. Wound and scrotal hematomas are amongst the most common early postoperative complications, with reported rates of 6.1% and 4.5%, respectively.

items.question: 29. After an open inguinal hernia repair, which symptom is likely to appear as a result of the most commonly injured nerve in this type of approach?
options: Numbness on ipsilateral upper lateral thigh
Hyper response of the cremasteric reflex
items.explanation: Answer: B. General Surgery Examination & Board Review p67. Depending on the approach used, specific nerves in the area will be more prone to injury. For example, in open hernia repairs, the ilioinguinal nerve can be most commonly injured at the external ring where it runs on top of the cord. It results in loss of the cremasteric reflex and numbness to the ipsilateral penis, scrotum, and thigh.

items.question: 30. Regarding repair of groin hernias, which of the following techniques will fix a femoral hernia?
items.explanation: Answer: D. General Surgery Examination & Board Review p71. Preperitoneal repair, a variation known as the Kugel repair, involves placing mesh in the preperitoneal space and suturing this from the pubic tubercle to Cooper's ligament. Bi-layer mesh repair can also be used to obliterate the femoral canal in femoral hernia repair.

items.question: 31. A 75-year-old white man with a history of alcohol abuse, 40-pack-year tobacco use, and long-standing GERD controlled by antacids is evaluated for dysphagia and weight loss. Esophagography shows an apple core lesion at the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is TRUE regarding further work-up?
options: Endoscopic biopsy should be avoided because of the risk of perforation.
Computed tomography (CT) is excellent for tumor staging.
Positron emission tomography (PET) is an excellent tool for staging and can be used as a single diagnostic modality.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a poor imaging modality for liver metastasis.
EUS is more sensitive than CT for evaluating the celiac lymph nodes.
items.explanation: Answer: E. Rush5 p256. EUS is more sensitive than CT in evaluating the depth of tumor invasion (T) and the presence of regional lymph nodes (N).

items.question: 33. A 77-year-old man is admitted after a right lobe lobectomy. On postoperative day 3, a productive cough and fever develop. A chest radiograph shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is CORRECT regarding immune function in older patients?
options: WBC counts increase significantly even with mild infection.
The T-cell response to new antigens is impaired.
Normal neutrophil counts decline with age.
Normal acute phase protein levels are decreased.
Normocytic anemia is uncommon in older patients.
items.explanation: Answer: B. Rush5 p565. The immune system undergoes significant changes with aging, a process called immunosenescence. The ability to mount an immune response becomes lessened, leading to increased susceptibility to infections and increased tumorigenis.

items.question: 36. An elderly patient is brought to hospital with recent onset of colicky abdominal pain, distension and constipation. On examination the abdomen is markedly distended and tympanitic; there is no marked tenderness. Plain abdominal x-ray shows a markedly distended loop located mainly in the right upper quadrant. The likely diagnosis is:
items.explanation: Answer: E. Lange5 p128. This patient has sigmoid volvulus. Plain abdominal x-ray shows a massively distended loop in the right upper quadrant, because the sigmoid colon, as it progressively distends, as a result of the twist of its mesentery, has no space in the LLQ to occupy and flips over to the largest available area—namely the right upper quadrant.

items.question: 38. A 64-year-old healthy woman presented with a rectal mass located approximately 6 cm from the anal verge. A biopsy confirmed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, and staging workup shows a T3N0M0 lesion. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
options: Low anterior resection followed by chemotherapy
Neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by low anterior resection
Low anterior resection followed by radiation therapy
items.explanation: Answer: C. SESAP16 categ.11 Q6. For patients with clinical stage II (T3-4, N0) or stage III (any T, N1-2) disease, neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgery has become the standard of care as it improves local control compared to surgery alone.

items.question: 58. Meconium ileus is characterized by:
options: Plain abdominal radiograph demonstrating diffusely dilated air-filled loops of small and large intestine.
An unused colon on barium enema.
Air fluid levels in the large intestine.
items.explanation: Answer: B, SESAP16 CATEGORY 10 Q9. Meconium ileus is a small bowel obstruction of newborns caused by inspissated meconium that fails to pass after birth. Most cases of meconium ileus occur in infants with cystic fibrosis. On exam, the abdomen is distended and may have palpable doughy loops of bowel. Plain abdominal radiographs characteristically show dilated loops of small bowel with a paucity of air in the colon. Air-fluid levels may be absent because the air does not layer above the thick meconium, but rather mixes with the sticky meconium resulting in a 'soap-bubble' appearance. A barium enema has a typical appearance showing an unused colon (microcolon).

items.question: 61. A baby is brought home after a normal, full-term delivery. The baby did well for the first 2 weeks and had normal bowel movements. On the morning of presentation, he was fussy and had several episodes of bilious emesis. The next diagnostic step after plain films is:
options: A CT scan of the head.
items.explanation: Answer: E, SESAP16 CATEGORY 10 Q14. One of the principles of diagnosis in pediatric surgery is to rule out the 'worst thing it could be' for a given symptom complex. In an infant with bilious emesis, the worst thing it could be is a malrotation complicated by midgut volvulus. The diagnostic test of choice is an upper gastrointestinal series.

items.question: 62. Which of the following statements is true regarding routine contralateral exploration in children who present with a symptomatic unilateral inguinal hernia?
options: It is indicated in girls of all ages.
It is indicated in children who are younger than 1-year-old.
It is indicated in boys who are younger than 1-year-old.
It is indicated in all premature infants.
items.explanation: Answer: E, SESAP16 Category 10 Q15. Conceivably the very best longitudinal study of inguinal hernia and repair in infants and children was published by Dr. Sigm-Ein in 2006, representing 6351 hernia repairs done by the same surgeon over a long career. Dr. Ein's paper gives guidance. Many North American surgeons in their practice patents including inguinal hernia repairs... Dr. Ein's experience results in to the abandonment of this practice. He used a reasoning to speculate that as many as 83% of opposite-side hernia sacs will conceivably remain clinically dormant and there is no reason to routinely explore the opposite side in the absence of a history suspicious for a hernia.

items.question: 65. Three months after an esophagectomy with gastric pullup, a patient presents with gastric outlet obstruction. The next BEST step in management of this patient is:
items.explanation: Answer: B, SESAP16 Category 10 Q23. Symptomatic gastric outlet obstruction is reported to occur in 10-30% of patients after esophagectomy with gastric pullup. Endoscopic pyloric balloon dilatation can be performed and is successful in relieving the obstruction in more than 95% of cases.

items.question: 67. A 23-year-old thin (50 kg) woman with a history of surgical correction of her scoliosis is evaluated for symptoms of postprandial epigastric pain, fullness, nausea, and vomiting. Her physical examination is unremarkable except for her thin physique/stature. Barium upper GI series showed a dilated duodenum and stomach with minimal flow of barium into the jejunum. Which of the following is the operative management of choice for this patient's condition?
items.explanation: Answer: D, Rush6 p302. The patient in this scenario has compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) as it passes over it. This rare condition is known as SMA syndrome or Wilkie syndrome. Conservative management consisting of nutritional supplementation can be tried initially. In patients who fail medical management, the operative treatment of choice is duodenojejunostomy.

items.question: 68. A 65-year-old male patient presents with a 2 cm non-ulcerated rectal mass located posteriorly 3 cm above the dentate line. The mass is mobile and the biopsy reveals a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma T2 stage. The recommended treatment is:
items.explanation: Answer: E, Hopkins ABSITE, 2e p144. Transanal excision of rectal cancers may be considered for T1-T2, N0, M0, well-differentiated tumors that are less than 3-4 cm in size, involve <30% of the circumference, and are within 8 cm of the anal verge.

items.question: 70. Which portion of the colon is most liable to perforation secondary to an obstructing carcinoma of the sigmoid colon?
items.explanation: Answer: A, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e p478. Although diverticular disease increases in frequency with increasing age, mounting evidence suggests that the incidence of diverticulitis among patients under 40 or 50 years old, especially obese males, is growing. (Note: The rationale for caecum being most liable to perforation in a closed-loop obstruction is Laplace's law, where the largest diameter part—the caecum—experiences the highest wall tension).

items.question: 74. Which of the following investigations has the highest diagnostic yield for detecting a colovesical fistula?
items.explanation: Answer: E, Medicosmos large intestine Q17. Of the tests listed above, cystoscopy provides the highest diagnostic yield, between 80% and 95%. The most common finding on cystoscopy is localized inflammation and bullous edema of the bladder mucosa. демонстрация of the fistula is unusual, no matter which test is utilized.

items.question: 75. A 52-year-old woman is involved in an automobile accident and sustains compression fractures of the 10th and 11th thoracic vertebrae and right pulmonary contusion. On the fourth day after injury, her abdomen is noted to be distended, tympanitic and profusely tender. Abdominal radiographs reveal gaseous distention of the ascending and transverse segments of the colon. The cecum is 13 cm in greatest diameter. Which of the following is recommended for management?
items.explanation: Answer: C, Medicosmos large intestine Q40. Acute obstruction of the colon in the absence of any identifiable mechanical obstructing lesion is known as Ogilvie's syndrome. Acute pseudo-obstruction usually involves the proximal colon. The major problem with Ogilvie's syndrome is the risk of cecal perforation. Fiberoptic colonoscopic decompressing procedure should be considered when the cecum reaches 10-12 cm in diameter.

items.question: 76. A 25-year-old man has recurrent, indolent fistula in ano. He also complains of weight loss, recurrent attacks of diarrhea with blood mixed in the stool, and tenesmus. Proctoscopy revealed a healthy, normal-appearing rectum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Colitis associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
items.explanation: Answer: A, Lange p139. Recurrent fistulas in ano are a feature of Crohn's colitis. The absence of disease in the rectum eliminates the possibility of ulcerative colitis.

items.question: 77. A 40-year-old man with a long history of bloody diarrhea presents with increased abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. On examination, he IS found to be dehydrated and shows tachycardia and hypotension. The abdomen is markedly tender with guarding and rigidity. What is the most likely cause?
items.explanation: Answer: A, Lange p138. The long history of bloody diarrhea should suggest a diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease. The acute onset of abdominal pain together with the findings of an acute abdomen and systemic manifestations should raise the suspicion of a devastating complication—toxic megacolon in ulcerative colitis.

items.question: 79. A 19-year-old male is admitted with a 2-cm stab wound of the sigmoid colon on the antimesenteric border. A small amount of solid feces is noted. No other injuries are present. Vital signs are stable throughout the case. What is the recommended procedure?
options: Repair the wound in two layers.
Exteriorize the wound as a colostomy.
Repair the wound in two layers with transverse colostomy.
Resect the segment of sigmoid and perform a primary anastomosis.
Resect the wound and perform a Hartmann procedure.
items.explanation: Answer: A, Lange5 p316. In the absence of significant contamination or devitalized tissue in a stable patient, the wound should be repaired without having to resort to a colostomy or a resection.

items.question: 80. A 19-year-old man is brought into the emergency department with a 'gunshot wound' that occurred 4 hours before admission. At exploratory laparotomy, an injury is noted in the transverse colon with extensive tissue destruction. There is a large amount of fecal contamination. Management of this injury should include which of the following?
options: Debridement and closure of the wound.
Resection with proximal colostomy and distal mucous fistula.
Resection of the injured colon with primary anastomosis and proximal colostomy.
Resection of the colon wound with primary anastomosis and proximal cecostomy.
items.explanation: Answer: B, Lange p272 Q61. The necrotic bowel is resected, the proximal end is constructed as an end colostomy, and the distal end is constructed as a mucous fistula. This is the best procedure because it will avoid an anastomosis in a contaminated abdomen.

items.question: 91. Three days after undergoing an operation for an abdominal aortic aneurysm, a patient has moderate fever, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding What is the most helpful investigation?
items.explanation: Answer: D, Lange5 p138. In a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm resection, the most worrisome complication is inadequate blood supply to the sigmoid colon through the marginal artery. Sigmoid ischemia should be ruled out by sigmoidoscopy. In the clinical picture described, sigmoidoscopy should be the most important test.

items.question: 92. Twelve hours after colonoscopy and removal of a 2.5-cm sessile polyp from her cecum, a 55-year-old woman has abdominal pain, fever, leukocytosis, and mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. No free air is seen on an abdominal series. The next step should be:
items.explanation: Answer: C, Sesap14 category3 part1 Q18. Possible complications after colonoscopic polypectomy include perforation, postpolypectomy syndrome, and postpolypectomy hemorrhage. Postpolypectomy syndrome is the second most common, occurring after 0.5% to 1.0% of all polypectomies. Risk factors include sessile polyps > 2 cm and polyps removed from the right colon. The syndrome results from transmural burn without actual perforation. Postpolypectomy syndrome presents like a colonic perforation, with abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. It usually occurs within 12 hours, but can occur days later. In postpolypectomy syndrome, however, there is no free air on abdominal x-rays or CT. CT Imaging A commonly shows focal thickening of the colonic wall and B pericolic and perifarmiat fat stranding. The treatment is C

items.question: 93. Two years after total abdominal colectomy with ileal pouch reconstruction for familial adenomatous polyposis, a 24-year-old man presents with a firm palpable mass at the ileostomy site scar that is non tender. Ultrasound scan reveals a densely homogenous, solid 8-cm mass within the soft tissue of the abdominal wall. The most likely diagnosis is:
items.explanation: Answer: E, Sesap14 category 12 part I Q17. Desmoid tumors may develop in as many as 10% to 15% of patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and are probably the leading cause of death in FAP patients who have undergone colectomy. These tumors are typically abdominal, but can occur on the trunk and body, particularly following abdominal operations. Specific mutations in the APC gene responsible for FAP are also responsible for desmoid tumor development and proliferation. Desmoid tumors have an unpredictable natural history: 10% regress spontaneously, 30% have cyclical growth and regression, 50% remain stable, and 10% grow rapidly. In tumors that can be safely removed, surgical excision is recommended. For large rapidly progressive tumors, the nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent, sulindac, has been used to control disease. Multiple chemotherapy and radiotherapy is reserved for large progressive tumors deemed inoperable due to extent of disease. Based on his history, examination, and ultrasound findings, the mass is not an incisional hernia or lipoma. Infiltrating desmoid tumor would be expected to be painful, symptomatic and tender on examination. Patients with FAP are at risk for both colonic and small bowel adenocarcinoma; however, adenocarcinoma involving the abdominal wall would be a feature of this syndrome. 2014

items.question: 95. After being struck by a moving truck, a 23-year-old woman undergoes splenectomy during diagnostic laparotomy. She leaves the hospital against medical advice on postoperative day 4, after refusing vaccination. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely to result in her developing sepsis?
items.explanation: Answer: A, Hopkins ABSITE 2e p89. The spleen is a secondary organ of the immune system. Encapsulated pathogens are opsonized and then cleared from circulation by the spleen. Therefore, asplenic patients are primarily at risk of overwhelming postsplenectomy infection (OPSI) caused by encapsulated organisms. Asplenic adults are at 40% to 60% greater risk of sepsis compared with nonsplenectomy adults. However, the risk of OPSI in patients undergoing splenectomy for hematologic disease is 1% in comparison to the higher rates seen in patients after splenectomy for trauma. The risk and impact of OPSI is in- versely related to age. In 80% of cases, OPSI occurs within the first 2 years after splenectomy. The risk of OPSI is further increased in asplenic patients with malignancy, hematological disorders such as thalassemia, or the immunosuppressed (e.g., those undergoing chemotherapy). Overall, OPSI has a 50% to 60% mortality rate. The most common organisms that cause OPSI are as follows, in order of decreasing frequency: S. pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, beta-hemolytic Streptococcus sp., S. aureus, E. coli, Pseudo- monas sp. Guidelines for reduction of the risk of OPSI focuses on immunization of patients undergoing elective splenectomy with polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine 10 to 14 days before surgery. Those undergoing splenectomy for trauma should receive the immunization 14 days post-operatively. Booster immunization is recommended every 3 years. In addition, vaccination with the quadrivalent vaccines for H. influenzae type B, meningococcus, and annually for influenza is recommended and man-dated for immunosuppressed patients and those younger than 10 years. In addition, antibiotic prophylaxis such as dental work. Patient education is important following splenectomy. Asplenic patients should be encouraged to carry identification cards to alert health care workers and should be advised to take every sign of early infection very seriously.

items.question: 97. A non-immune surgical resident is stuck by a contaminated needle from an HBsAg-positive source. Which of the following is the CORRECT initial treatment?
options: None because the patient does not have active HBV infection and is immune to HBV
Vaccination against HBV and administration of HBIG
items.explanation: Answer: E, Rush6 p76 Q11. The best method of preventing occupational HBV infection is to vaccinate all HCWs at risk if they do not have natural immunity from previous infection. When exposure occurs, the affected area should be immediately and thoroughly washed with soap and water. The source is tested for HBV, HCV, and HIV. If the source tests positive for HBV, nonimmune individuals are given HBIG for passive prophylaxis and are vaccinated. If a previously vaccinated individual incurs a needle injury, titers should be checked and a dose of vaccine given if titers are not detected. Interferon is not used for prophylaxis following acute exposure but may be useful for some patients with chronic HBV or HCV infection.

items.question: 17. A 60-year-old alcoholic is admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. Upon admission, his white blood cell (WBC) count is 21,000. His lipase is 1,500, blood glucose is 180 mg/dL, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is 400 IU/L, and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is 240 IU/dL Which of the following is TRUE?
options: This patient is expected to have a mortality rate of less than 5%.
The patient's lipase level is an important indication of prognosis.
A venous blood gas would be helpful in assessing the severity of illness in this patient.
A serum calcium level of 6.5 mg/dL on the second hospital day is a bad prognostic sign.
items.explanation: Answer: E, Lange5 p157. The patient has three Ranson's criteria at the time of admission. The expected mortality rate is 15% with 3-4 Ranson's criteria. Amylase and lipase levels are not prognostic factors in acute pancreatitis. Calcium level <8 mg/dL within the first 48 hours is one of Ranson's criteria, as is arterial PO2 <60 mm Hg.

items.question: 19. Which of the following statements regarding unusual hernias is INCORRECT:
options: An obturator hernia may produce nerve compression diagnosed by a positive Howship-Romberg sign.
Grynfeltt's hernia appears through the superior lumbar triangle, whereas Petit's hernia occurs through the inferior lumbar triangle.
Sciatic hernias usually present with a painful groin mass below the inguinal ligament.
Littre's hernia is defined by a Meckel's diverticulum presenting as the sole component of the hernia sac.
Richter's hernia involves the antimesenteric surface of the intestine within the hernia sac and may present with partial intestinal obstruction.
items.explanation: Answer: C, Medicosmos Abdominal wall & acute abdomen Q2. Sciatic hernias usually present with intestinal obstruction or a mass in the gluteal or infragluteal region. 2016, 2019

items.question: 20. The most common site of adenocarcinoma of the small intestine is the:
items.explanation: Answer: A, Medicosmos small intestine Q1

items.question: 21. The most common benign tumor of the small intestine is:
items.explanation: Answer: C, Medicosmos small intestine Q2

items.question: 22. A 20-year-old unrestrained driver was involved in a motor-vehicle crash. A computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen revealed a large hematoma in the second portion of duodenum. The rest of the abdomen is normal. The initial management of this duodenal hematoma should be:
options: Nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, and gradual resumption of oral diet.
items.explanation: Answer: B, Lange5 p261. Intramural duodenal hematoma may occur secondary to blunt trauma of the abdomen. Usually this hematoma is submucosal and the injury is not transmural. It may cause a temporary obstruction of the duodenum and usually responds to nasogastric suction and intravenous fluids. Only if the patient has persistent obstruction (as demonstrated by an upper GI study) beyond 2 weeks, a surgical approach may be required.

items.question: 23. In a patient who had a motor-cycle crash, a CT of the abdomen revealed a peripancreatic hematoma and indistinct pancreatic border. The most definitive test for a pancreatic injury requiring operative intervention is:
items.explanation: Answer: A, Lange5 p261. The most definitive test for a lesion requiring operative correction is demonstration of a disrupted major pancreatic duct. While CT scanning may give a suggestion of a ductal injury, only operative exploration of the area of injury may be inconclusive; ERCP is very reliable in showing a disrupted duct. Amylase testing of lavage effluent is nonspecific.

items.question: 24. A 50-year-old man develops acute pancreatitis due to alcohol abuse. Hyperamylasemia resolves by the third day after admission. By the eighth hospital day, the patient is noted to have recurrent fever (38.5 °C), progressive leukocytosis (18,500 WBC/mm3), and tachypnea. The most appropriate management includes which as the next step?
options: CT guided aspiration of peripancreatic fluid collections.
ERCP with sphincterotomy and placement of biliary stent.
items.explanation: Answer: B, Medicosmos hepatobiliary & pancreas surgery Q59. The common causes of pancreatic abscesses are infected pancreatic pseudocysts and necrotizing pancreatitis. The diagnosis is suggested by persistent fever, leukocytosis, and a palpable abdominal mass. Bacteremia and systemic toxicity are late clinical features. Percutaneous aspiration with positive cultures is the definitive preoperative test, facilitated by CT scanning or ultrasound-guidance to suspicious peripancreatic fluid collections. When diagnosed, the treatment of choice is wide surgical debridement with removal of all infected and necrotized tissue.

items.question: 39. In Pulmonary contusion, one of the following is CORRECT:
options: Results in increased lung compliance at 24 hours.
It is the most common type of lung injury in penetrating chest trauma.
Usually causes ventilation/perfusion mismatch which evolves over 24 hours.
Lung contusion is an entity involving injury to the alveolar capillaries, due to major tear in lung tissue.
items.explanation: Answer: D. Critical Care Handbook for Global Surgery p58: Pulmonary Contusion: An injury to lung parenchyma... Pathophysiology: Following blunt trauma, edema and blood collect in the alveolar space. This causes ventilation/perfusion mismatch which evolves over a period of 24 hours.

items.question: 40. The most common cause of pure aortic stenosis is:
items.explanation: Answer: B? Heart Pathology MCQs. The most common cause of pure aortic stenosis in adults is a congenital bicuspid valve.

items.question: 41. Which of the following is the most common mode of presentation of cardiac myxoma?
items.explanation: Answer: B? Stoelting's Anesthesia and Co-Existing Disease. Obstruction of the mitral valve by the myxoma may mimic mitral valve disease often with nocturnal pulmonary edema.

items.question: 42. The classical indication for surgical treatment of focal nodular hyperplasia (liver) is:
items.explanation: Answer: C? Hopkins ABSITE 2e p132: FNH is a benign liver tumor with a benign course, and it can be managed with observation even if the patient is asymptomatic. If the patient is symptomatic or if the lesion is growing, resection may be considered.

items.question: 43. A 45-year-old patient is one week following an attack of severe acute pancreatitis. He has been unable to eat as this precipitates severe pain. Physical examination reveals a soft abdomen with epigastric tenderness. Bowel sounds are scanty. He is afebrile. His amylase is slightly elevated. Which of the following statements regarding management of his nutrition is CORRECT?
options: Total parenteral nutrition should be commenced
items.explanation: Answer: D. SBA in SURGERY Darren 2e p44: Published studies have shown that over 30% of acute pancreatitis inpatients are malnourished and that poor nutritional status prolongs admission. Nasojejunal feeding is preferred to TPN in all patients; IV nutrition should be a reserve for patients in whom enteral feeding is impossible.

items.question: 44. During liver surgery, Pringle Maneuver was required, all of the following structures are involved in this maneuver EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Answer: E? During liver surgery, bleeding may be controlled using the Pringle maneuver; this involves placing a vascular clamp across the anterior aspect of the epiploic foramen. The portal vein, hepatic artery and common bile duct are occluded... The inferior vena cava is NOT involved.

items.question: 45. Which of the following statements regarding splenic anatomy is TRUE?
options: The splenic artery has a straight course unlike the vein.
The normal weight of the spleen is up to 250 g.
The inferior mesenteric vein joins the splenic vein.
The spleen lies alongside left 11th and 12th ribs.
items.explanation: Answer: D? SBA and EMIs for the General Surgery FRCS p192: The inferior mesenteric vein joins the splenic vein behind the neck of the pancreas to form the portal vein.

items.question: 46. Insulinoma is characterized by all of the followings EXCEPT:
options: Associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia in 8%.
items.explanation: Answer: C? Rush6 p418: Insulinoma is the most common functional neoplasm of the endocrine pancreas... 90% are solitary... 10% are malignant... size < 2 cm in 90%.

items.question: 47. One of the following would exclude a patient with HCC from becoming a transplant candidate:
options: A single 1-cm lesion in the liver with microvascular invasion.
Two lesions each less than 2 cm.
A single 4.8-cm HCC lesion in segment VIII.
items.explanation: Answer: D? Milan criteria specify that for liver transplantation, HCC patients should have a single lesion ≤ 5 cm OR up to 3 lesions each ≤ 3 cm, without extrahepatic involvement or major vascular (portal vein) invasion.

items.question: 48. With regard to gall bladder stones (CBS), which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Pure cholesterol stones are usually multiple
Black pigmented stones occur mostly in the biliary tree
The main component of brown pigmented stones is calcium palmitate
Brown pigmented stones are associated with hemolysis
Risk of gallbladder adenocarcinoma is more with small tiny stones than large stones
items.explanation: Answer: C? ABSITE Virgilio 1e p95. Brown pigment stones are defined as either black or brown. Brown pigment stones are composed of calcium bilirubinate and calcium soaps (palmitate).

items.question: 49. The BEST treatment option for perforated duodenal ulcer secondary to chronic use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) is:
items.explanation: Answer: C? ABSITE Virgilio 2e p81: The majority of perforated ulcers can be managed by simple ulcer closure with an omental (Graham) patch.

items.question: 50. What is the most commonly associated risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
items.explanation: Answer: A. Cigarette smoking is the most consistently observed risk factor for pancreatic cancer.

items.question: 82. Which of the following have been shown to be risk factors for development of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas?
items.explanation: Answer: AE, Medicosmos Hepatobiliary pancreatic surgery. Most cases of pancreatic cancer have no obvious predisposing host factors. Smoking, long-standing diabetes, and prior gastrectomy have been shown to increase risk.

items.question: 51. Which one of the following types of cholecystitis mimic gallbladder adenocarcinoma?
items.explanation: Answer: B? Medicosmos Hepatobiliary & pancreatic surgery Q41: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is a rare form of chronic cholecystitis believed to be associated with a higher incidence of cancer. This form of cholecystitis is also important because, grossly, it may mimic cancer of the gallbladder.

items.question: 52. The commonest complication of a liver hydatid cyst is:
options: Free rupture to the peritoneal cavity.
items.explanation: Answer: C? Complications in about 40% of cases. The most common complications in order of frequency are infection, rupture to the biliary tree, rupture to the peritoneal cavity, and rupture to the pleural cavity.

items.question: 53. One is TRUE in regarding trauma of the spleen:
options: This organ is rarely involved in blunt trauma.
Splenic preservation should be the rule when there are associated significant injuries.
Vaccine should be given 1-2 weeks after splenectomy.
Overwhelming postsplenectomy sepsis (OPSS) is more than 10%.
Non-operative management is limited to grades 1&2.
items.explanation: Answer: C? Surgery Review Illustrated 2e p791: Vaccine should be given 1-2 weeks after splenectomy.

items.question: 54. A 23-year old man sustained bilateral femoral fractures and open tibia fracture in a motorcycle accident. Before proceeding with surgery. What is the BEST measure of the patient's resuscitation?
items.explanation: Answer: C? In trauma resuscitation, urine output is a reliable clinical indicator of organ perfusion.

items.question: 55. The therapeutic rationale for early (within 24 hours) stabilization of femoral shaft fractures for multiple trauma patients is to decrease:
items.explanation: Answer: B? Early stabilization of long bone fractures in multiple trauma patients is associated with a decrease in pulmonary complications like ARDS.

items.question: 56. In early assessment and resuscitation of a trauma patient which of the following is FALSE:
options: A tourniquet is applied in life threatening bleeding when digital pressure fails
Airway patency should be maintained with control of cervical spine
A urinary catheter should be inserted in unconscious patients
A normal cervical spine lateral view x-ray excludes cervical spine injury
Endotrachael intubation should be done in apneic patients
items.explanation: Answer: B? SURGERY MCQS AND EMQS p16: (Note: The provided answer key says B, but standard ATLS teaching emphasizes maintaining airway with C-spine control. In many exams, D is the usual 'FALSE' statement as one view is insufficient).

items.question: 57. All true about compartment syndrome EXCEPT:
options: Neural tissues demonstrate functional abnormalities (paresthesia and hyperesthesia) within 30 min of the onset of ischemia
Ischemia of 4 h gives rise to significant myoglobinuria
Compartment syndromes lasting longer than 12h produce chronic functional deficits.
items.explanation: Answer: D? Essentials of Vascular Surgery for the General Surgeon p56: Irreversible muscular changes beginning after 4-12 h... (Note: The answer key in image says D).

items.question: 58. All the following are important clinical features to diagnose compartment syndrome EXCEPT:
options: Pain out of proportion to the stimulus
Pain on passive stretch of the affected muscle compartment
items.explanation: Answer: D? Critical Care Handbook for Global Surgery Page 176: Loss of pulse is usually a late finding and its absence does not rule out compartment syndrome.

items.question: 59. If a patient sustains trauma of all his fingers of one hand, then the sequence of attempted replantation would be in the following order:
items.explanation: Answer: A. Thumb replantation is the highest priority followed by the other digits in anatomical order.

items.question: 60. A 43-year-old man is admitted following an RTA... found in respiratory distress, he is intubated and... pressure to ventilate the patient, there is reduced... to the left side of the chest and the trachea is shifted... right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
options: Needle decompression of the left side of the chest.
items.explanation: Answer: C. The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of a tension pneumothorax, requiring immediate needle decompression.

items.question: 61. All of the following types of shock are distributive EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Answer: B? Anesthesia: A Comprehensive Review 6e Q610: The four types of shock are hypovolemic (e.g., hemorrhagic shock), cardiogenic, obstructive, and distributive (septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic).

items.question: 62. A child who was involved in a road traffic accident has bleeding, open femur fracture. What is the first step in resuscitation in the emergency room?
options: Transfuse 20ml/kg of packed red blood cells
Transfuse 20m/kg of packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets
items.explanation: Answer: B? Initial fluid resuscitation in children should follow weight-based boluses of isotonic crystalloid (20 ml/kg).

items.question: 63. Regarding pneumothorax all are true EXCEPT:
options: Closed pneumothorax is relatively common and may not be clinically significant
In tension pneumothorax air can only escape via the bronchial tree
In tension pneumothorax there may be tracheal deviation towards the contralateral lung
There may be an increase of 40 mmHg in intrapleural pressure on the affected side
Tension pneumothorax is usually diagnosed by CXR
items.explanation: Answer: E? Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should not be delayed for a chest X-ray.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT useful in the treatment of keloids?
items.explanation: Answer: E, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e, p17 Q10. A keloid is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Management includes pressure garments, silicone gel, steroid injections, and sometimes radiotherapy. Vitamin D has no established role in treatment.

items.question: Treatment of surgical site infections. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Identification of the causative organism should be done before starting antibiotics
Wounds are best managed by delayed primary or secondary closure.
Subcuticular continuous skin closure decreases the incidence of wound infection
Polymeric films can be useful in infected wounds.
Administration of antibiotic preparations locally is more effective than the oral route.
items.explanation: Answer: B, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e, p23. For infected or highly contaminated wounds, the best management strategy to prevent further infection is to leave the wound open for delayed primary or secondary closure. Local antibiotics are generally avoided due to risks of allergy and resistance.

items.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding first-aid for chemical burns?
options: Copious water lavage is the best first-aid measure for phosphorus burns.
Elemental sodium burns should not be treated by water lavage.
Damage from alkalis is usually less than with acids.
Hydrofluoric acid burns can be associated with hypercalcemia.
Local radiation burns causing ulceration need excision and split-skin graft repair
items.explanation: Answer: B, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e, p199. With phosphorus and elemental sodium burns, washing with copious water is contraindicated. Alkali burns are generally deeper and more destructive than acid burns. Hydrofluoric acid is associated with HYPOcalcemia.

items.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding burn management?
options: Early surgery is indicated in the hands and axilla.
Contractures are best treated with full thickness skin grafts.
Tissue expansion is useful in treating alopecia caused by a burn.
A Z-plasty is a useful technique for reconstruction of broad areas of burn scarring causing restricted movement.
Full-thickness grafts or vascularized tissue are generally unnecessary when good vascularized tissue is available in the treated burn scar.
items.explanation: Answer: C, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e, p199. Early excision and grafting are indicated for burns of the hands and axillae. Contractures are usually treated by Z-plasty for narrow scars, while broad areas require grafts or flaps. Tissue expansion is particularly useful for scalp alopecia.

items.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE with regard to necrotizing fasciitis?
options: It is a polymicrobial synergistic infection.
To confirm the diagnosis a plain X-ray is done to look for air.
It can rapidly progress to septic shock.
A period of observation is advisable to see if the condition spreads.
items.explanation: Answer: E, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e, p273. Necrotizing fasciitis is a life-threatening surgical emergency requiring immediate resuscitation, antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. Observation is dangerous as the infection spreads rapidly along fascial planes.

items.question: Which are the optimal port positions for a laparoscopic fundoplication?
options: Supra umbilical, left flank, LUQ, epigastrium
Epigastrium, left and right UQ, left flank
Umbilical, left and right UQ, right flank
Epigastrium, left and right UQ, right flank
Supra umbilical, epigastrium, left and right UQ, left flank
items.explanation: Answer: E? Laparoscopic Surgery of the Abdomen p64. Typical port placement involves a camera port (supra-umbilical), an epigastric port for liver retraction, and working ports in the left and right upper quadrants and the left flank.

items.question: A 56-year-old man, who has recently had laparoscopic left colon resection secondary to sigmoid tumor. His surgery was 3 days ago and he now appears to have an ileus but is comfortable. Free air is apparent under his diaphragm. His abdomen is distended and he is tender in the midline. The free air is likely to be due to:
options: A normal finding three days post laparotomy
items.explanation: Answer: B, Intercollegiate MRCS: SBA Practice Paper p12. The presence of free intraperitoneal air is common following any intra-abdominal surgery, whether open or laparoscopic, and typically resolves within 5 days.

items.question: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to performing laparoscopic surgery?
options: Having symptomatic chronic obstructed pulmonary disease
items.explanation: Answer: E, Intercollegiate MRCS: SBA Practice Paper p15. An uncorrected coagulopathy is a major contraindication to any surgical procedure. Pregnancy and high BMI are relative contraindications.

items.question: Treatment options for bone metastases of prostate cancer include all of the following EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Answer: A? Radioiodine (I-131) is used for thyroid cancer, not prostate cancer. Treatments for metastatic prostate cancer include hormonal therapy (Goserelin, castration), chemotherapy, and bone-targeted therapies like strontium-89.

items.question: Four days following sleeve Gastrectomy for a 32-year-old female, she is febrile with shallow 30 per min breaths, pulse 115/min. CXR was done as shows a left pleural effusion, what is the most probable cause?
items.explanation: Answer: C? Bleeding from the staple line and gastric leakage (often presenting with a left-sided effusion or respiratory symptoms) are among the most serious and common early complications after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.

items.question: Following a 2-hour firefighting episode, a 36-year-old fireman begins complaining of a throbbing headache, nausea, dizziness, and visual disturbances. His carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) level is found to be 22%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his treatment?
options: Transfer the patient to a hyperbaric oxygen chamber.
Begin bicarbonate infusion and give 250 mg acetazolamide (Diamox) intravenously.
Perform flexible bronchoscopy with further treatment determined by findings.
items.explanation: Answer: D, Pretest13 Q150. For carbon monoxide poisoning, the immediate first-line treatment is 100% oxygen administered through a tightly fitting mask, which significantly reduces the half-life of COHb compared to room air. Hyperbaric oxygen is usually reserved for higher levels (>25% or pregnancy) or neurologic impairment.

items.question: A 5-year-old child presents with a small mass near the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The mass is associated with localized erythema and induration, and the child is febrile. Which of the followings is the definitive treatment of this problem?
options: Incision and drainage followed latter by complete excision
Partial excision followed by clinical observation
Immediate excision followed by postoperative antibiotic therapy for one week
items.explanation: Answer: C, Pretest13 Q484. The description is classic for an infected branchial cleft remnant. Acute management involves incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Definitive treatment requires complete excision after the inflammation has resolved to prevent recurrence.

items.question: All of the following hormones decrease lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Answer: A, Schwarz ABSITE 10e p191. Gastrin and motilin have been shown to increase LES pressure. Hormones like estrogen, glucagon, progesterone, somatostatin, and secretin decrease LES pressure.

items.question: Which of the followings is the preoperative imaging study of choice for gastrinoma?
items.explanation: Answer: E, Schwarz ABSITE 10e p205. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (Octreoscan) is the most sensitive imaging study for localizing both the primary gastrinoma and possible metastatic disease, with a sensitivity approaching 100% for many lesions.

items.question: Which of the following patients is suitable for sentinel lymph node biopsy?
options: Lower inner quadrant of breast carcinoma.
Proven lymph node metastasis by pre-op core biopsy
items.explanation: Answer: D, Schwarz ABSITE 10e p119. SLNB is indicated in patients with clinically node-negative breast cancer. It is not recommended for inflammatory breast cancer, patients with palpable axillary nodes, or those with biopsy-proven nodal or distant metastases.

items.question: A patient with an anterior mediastinal mass and elevated serum a-fetoprotein (AFP) most likely has:
items.explanation: Answer: B, Schwarz ABSITE 10e p131. Elevated AFP in a patient with a mediastinal germ-cell tumor is diagnostic of a nonseminomatous component (such as yolk sac tumor). Pure seminomas always have a normal AFP.

items.question: One of the following is an absolute contraindication to enteral nutrition:
options: Abdominal distension or severe protracted diarrhea
Active hemorrhage in upper gastrointestinal tract
items.explanation: Answer: A, MCQs in Critical Care Medicine p483. Absolute contraindications to enteral feeding include severe septic shock, generalized peritonitis, and intestinal obstruction.

items.question: Contraindication to percutaneous gastrostomy or jejunostomy are all EXCEPT:
options: Need of enteral nutrition for 4 weeks
items.explanation: Answer: A, MCQs in Critical Care Medicine p596. Percutaneous feeding tubes are indicated when enteral nutrition is needed for more than 4 weeks. Ascites, previous laparotomy (extensive adhesions), and abnormal motility are relative contraindications.

items.question: A 47-year-old woman is diagnosed with unifocal 2.5 cm Grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast. Following multi-disciplinary team discussion the consultant sees the patient in clinic to convey management options. Which of the followings would be the most appropriate management plan for this patient?
options: Wide local excision and axillary clearance
Wide local excision and sentinel node biopsy
items.explanation: Answer: D, SBA IN SURGERY Darren 2e p189. For a 2.5 cm tumor, breast-conserving surgery (wide local excision) combined with sentinel lymph node biopsy is the standard of care if the axilla is clinically node-negative.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE when comparing mesh repair with laparoscopic mesh repair of inguinal hernia?
options: Laparoscopic repair has a lower recurrence rate.
There is no difference in time to return to work.
There is no difference in postoperative pain.
Laparoscopic repair has a lower complication rate.
items.explanation: Answer: C? Actually, some trials suggest open repair has slightly lower recurrence rates in some contexts, while others favor laparoscopy for bilateral or recurrent cases. The source cited (Virgilio p1) notes that for recurrent hernias, the laparoscopic group had higher recurrence rates (10.1% vs 4.9%) in a large prospective study mentioned on the page.

items.question: Ischemic orchitis after inguinal hernia repair is often due to:
options: Too tight reconstruction of the inguinal ring.
Inadvertent ligation of the testicular artery.
Completely excising a large scrotal hernia sac.
Anomalous blood supply to the testicle.
items.explanation: Answer: D, ABSITE Virgilio 1e p1. Ischemic orchitis is most commonly attributed to thrombosis of the pampiniform plexus, often resulting from excessive dissection of a large, distal hernia sac in the scrotum.

items.question: Four months after inguinal hernia repair, a patient reports moderately severe persistent burning pain at the incision site that radiates to the groin. On examination, there is no evidence of recurrent hernia. Which of the following is TRUE about this condition?
options: Careful identification of all three sensory nerves will prevent this complication.
Local anesthetic nerve blocks is helpful in identifying the nerve involved.
Chronic pain after hernia repair is uncommon.
Re-operation for genitofemoral neuralgia is best approached via the groin.
items.explanation: Answer: C, ABSITE Virgilio 2e p10. Chronic pain after hernia repair (ingoingodynia) is a significant complication. Selective nerve blocks can help differentiate which nerve is involved (iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal, or genitofemoral).

items.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE of salivary gland carcinoma?
options: Typically occurs in the minor salivary glands
Occurring in the parotid gland results in Frey's syndrome
In the parotid gland can be reliably diagnosed by fine-needle aspiration
items.explanation: Answer: D, B&L MCQs and EMQs in Surgery 1e p10. FNA is highly accurate for diagnosing parotid tumors. Smoking is not a strong risk factor for salivary cancers (though it is for Warthin's tumor). Frey's syndrome is a postoperative complication, not a symptom of the cancer itself.

items.question: Which of the following about the submandibular salivary gland is TRUE?
options: The two lobes of the submandibular salivary gland communicate around the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
Eighty percent of salivary calculi occur in the submandibular duct.
Calculi identified posterior to the point where the duct crosses the lingual nerve should be removed via a transoral approach.
The external carotid artery is at risk during removal of the gland.
The lingual nerve is divided during removal of the gland to facilitate the dissection of the deep lobe of the gland.
items.explanation: Answer: B. Approximately 80% of salivary stones (calculi) occur in the submandibular gland. The lobes communicate around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle, not the digastric. Calculi posterior to the lingual nerve usually require a transcervical approach.

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding salivary gland calculi are true?
options: The two lobes of the submandibular gland communicate around the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
80% of salivary calculi occur in the submandibular duct.
Calculi identified posterior to the point where the duct crosses the lingual nerve should be removed via a transoral approach.
80% of salivary calculi occur in the submandibular gland.
Calculi identified posterior to the point where the duct crosses the lingual nerve should be removed via a transoral approach.
items.explanation: Answer: D. (Note: options in source are a bit repetitive). As noted previously, the submandibular gland is the most common site for salivary stones. Stones located very posteriorly in the duct or within the gland itself often require excision of the entire gland.

items.question: During laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallbladder stones in a 38-year-old female patient, a bleeding occurred from a spurter while the surgeon is trying to dissect the cystic duct and the field of surgery is obscured. What is the most appropriate next management?
options: Suction-irrigation and control of the bleeder under direct vision.
items.explanation: Answer: B, Nasr Redwan. In the event of bleeding during laparoscopy, the first step is to use suction and irrigation to clear the field and identify the exact source, followed by controlled hemostasis (clipping or coagulation) under direct vision. Uncontrolled blind clamping or coagulation can cause serious injury to the bile ducts.

items.question: An intraoperative cholangiogram is performed during an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for a 30-year-old woman. She has no previous surgical history. There is a 0.8-cm filling defect in the distal common bile duct (CBD). What the surgeon should do after completing the laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
options: Check liver function tests postoperatively. If they are normal, no further treatment is needed.
Repeat an ultrasound postoperatively. Observe the patient if no CBD stone is visualized.
Perform a CBD exploration either laparoscopically or open along with a cholecystectomy
Plan for a postoperative HIDA scan.
Complete the laparoscopic cholecystectomy and plan for a postoperative hydroxy iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan
items.explanation: Answer: C, Lange5 p158. The discovery of a common bile duct stone (filling defect) during cholecystectomy mandates its removal, either intraoperatively (via laparoscopic or open CBD exploration) or postoperatively via ERCP, to prevent complications like cholangitis or pancreatitis.

items.question: Which of the following is the commonest complication of laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
items.explanation: Answer: D, Intercollegiate MRCS SBA Practice Papers p11. Shoulder tip pain, caused by diaphragmatic irritation from the residual CO2 gas used for pneumoperitoneum, is a very common (though usually minor) complaint following laparoscopic surgery.

items.question: A 40-year-old woman undergoes elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which identifies a gallbladder carcinoma. Histologic examination reports invasion though submucosa and muscular layer with involvement of perimuscular connective tissue. What is the most appropriate management?
options: Resection of the gallbladder bed, regional lymphadenectomy, and resection of previous port sites
Resection of the gallbladder bed, regional lymphadenectomy, perioneal lymphadenectomy, perioneal resection of previous port sites, chemoradiotherapy
Resection of previous port sites, chemoradiotherapy
items.explanation: Answer: C, Sesap14 Category 4, Part I Q28. Gallbladder cancer staged as T2 (invading the perimuscular connective tissue) or higher requires an extended (radical) cholecystectomy, which includes resection of the gallbladder bed (liver segments IVb and V) and regional lymphadenectomy to improve survival.

items.question: Six months after laparoscopic splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), a 38-year-old woman with lupus remains thrombocytopenic (platelet count, 42,000 cells/mm3). What is the next step?
items.explanation: Answer: B, Sesap14 category4 part II Q14. In patients who fail to respond to splenectomy or have a relapse of ITP, the first step is to search for an accessory spleen, which can be identified using a technetium-99m-labeled heat-damaged red blood cell scan.

items.question: Four days after an uneventful laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a 28-year-old woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and nausea. Ultrasound examination reveals a small right upper quadrant fluid collection, and biliary excretion, eg, HIDA scan shows an active leak. After admission, nothing by mouth, and intravenous fluids. What is the next step?
options: Open exploration of the common bile duct
Laparoscopic placement of a T-tube in the common duct
items.explanation: Answer: D, Hopkins ABSITE 2e p207. For a postoperative bile leak (often from the cystic duct stump or a duct of Luschka), the treatment of choice is ERCP with sphincterotomy and/or stent placement to decrease the pressure in the biliary system and facilitate healing of the leak.

items.question: You are performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy on a 64-year-old woman with a history of cholelithiasis and abdominal pain. As you insert the camera through a supraumbilical trocar, you are surprised to find multiple small tumor nodules spreading from the left pelvis across the large intestine. What you should do next after performing a biopsy?
options: Perform a biopsy, convert to an open procedure and complete surgical staging
Perform a biopsy, convert to an open procedure and perform a left oophorectomy
Take a biopsy of the tumor, close, and await the pathology report to plan open surgery
Take a biopsy of the tumor, remove the gallbladder and finish the case
items.explanation: Answer: D? When unexpected metastatic disease is encountered during a planned laparoscopic procedure (like cholecystectomy), the appropriate management is to obtain a biopsy for tissue diagnosis and terminate the procedure until the primary tumor is identified and a comprehensive treatment plan is developed.

items.question: While visualizing the gallbladder during an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the anesthesiologist informs you that the patient has a heart rate of 130, and a dropping blood pressure. What is the FIRST step in management?
options: Position the patient in the left lateral decubitus position
items.explanation: Answer: E, Hopkins ABSITE p60. Sudden cardiovascular instability (tachycardia, hypotension) during laparoscopy is often related to the pneumoperitoneum (decreased venous return or gas embolism). The immediate first step is to stop insufflation and release the pneumoperitoneum.

items.question: You are performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy on a 25-year-old woman with acute cholecystitis. The gallbladder is edematous and inflamed, and the tissue planes are difficult to discern. After clipping and dividing what you believed was the cystic duct, you realize that you have transected the common bile duct (CBD) with loss of length of the CBD. What operative procedure should be performed to repair this injury?
options: Direct end to end primary repair over a T-tube
Direct end to side primary repair over a T-tube
Kocher maneuver with end to end primary repair
items.explanation: Answer: E, Hopkins ABSITE 2e p399. For a major bile duct injury with loss of length, a tension-free Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is the preferred method of reconstruction to minimize the risk of biliary stricture.

items.question: Most major bile duct injuries during laparoscopic cholecystectomy occur in patients under which one of the following circumstances?
options: Conversion of a laparoscopic procedure to open
