options: wedge excision of the tumor with grossly clear margins
items.explanation: Current studies suggest that the prevalence of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) has increased. Surgical excision is the best treatment for most patients with these tumors. Lymphatic metastasis is rare, and simple excision with clear margin is appropriate. For many gastric GISTs, this can be accomplished with wedge resections. These tumors are best staged with abdominal computed tomographic (CT) scans to assess metastasis to the liver and/or direct invasion of adjacent structures. Although endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) effectively assesses the depth of invasion, it usually does not affect management, and would add nothing to the care of the patient described in this item.

items.question: Which of the following statements about laparoscopic adrenalectomy is NOT true?
options: The lateral decubitus position is superior to supine
The right adrenal vein is divided at its confluence with the right renal vein
This procedure can be used for resection of pheochromocytomas
Both right and left adrenal glands can be removed laparoscopically
Adrenal cortical cancer should not be removed laparoscopically
items.explanation: Various open approaches have traditionally been used for adrenal tumors requiring operation. However, these lesions are usually small and situated deep in the retroperitoneum, making them well suited to a laparoscopic approach. Snow and colleagues performed the first successful transabdominal laparoscopic adrenalectomy, and the lateral transabdominal approach for laparoscopic adrenalectomy was popularized in 1992. Since these initial reports, several studies have demonstrated the safety and advantages of laparoscopic adrenalectomy, and it has become the procedure of choice for the surgical management of many adrenal neoplasms. Recent reports have demonstrated that laparoscopic resection of pheochromocytomas can be accomplished safely by experienced surgeons. Adrenocortical carcinomas are characterized by large adrenal masses with invasion of adjacent structures requiring multi-visceral resection to achieve a negative margin and prevent local recurrence and subsequent cancer-related death. Although some early reports suggest that selected patients with primary adrenal malignancies can undergo laparoscopic adrenalectomy with acceptable results, there are too few patients with malignant adrenocortical carcinoma histology in these series to recommend routine use of laparoscopic adrenalectomy for patients with this disease. The adrenals can be removed laparoscopically via a transabdominal (anterior or lateral) or retroperitoneal (lateral or posterior) approach. The anterior transabdominal approach gives a conventional view of the abdominal cavity and allows a bilateral adrenalectomy to be performed without the necessity of repositioning the patient. However, it requires insertion of additional ports and has been reported to be associated with increased operative times. The lateral approach is the most widely used method and provides the largest working space because gravity aids retraction of surrounding organs. Patients need to be repositioned for a bilateral procedure. During the procedure, the right adrenal vein is identified at its junction with the inferior vena cava (figure), ligated with clips, and divided using endoscopic scissors.

items.question: Controlled clinical trials comparing laparoscopic and open colectomy demonstrate that
options: time to recovery is not significantly different
incisional metastases are more common with laparoscopic resection
significantly fewer lymph nodes are retrieved with laparoscopic resections
overall survival is more favorable with open resections
items.explanation: In the mid-1990s, as surgeons were actively expanding the envelope for laparoscopic surgery, disturbing reports of problems with laparoscopic resection of colonic malignancies began to surface. Of particular concern were case reports of port site metastases in up to 20% of cases, as compared with an historical rate of only 1% in conventional laparotomy incisions. Concern was also expressed regarding the completeness of oncologic resection possible with the techniques and surgical skills of that era. A national moratorium was advised until prospective trials could demonstrate safety and efficacy. Trials comparing laparoscopic and open resections were completed and reported in 2004. They indicated that postoperative recovery is significantly faster in the laparoscopic group; recurrence rates in surgical wounds were less than 1% regardless of approach; in each group, the median number of nodes retrieved was 12; complications occurred with equal frequency; and overall survival was similar. Laparoscopic colon surgery is technically demanding, and operative times are significantly longer. Obesity and previous abdominal operation increase difficulty, operating times, and conversion to open resection. Long operating times associated with laparoscopy may be inadvisable in the very elderly and/or infirm, but age is not an absolute contraindication.

items.question: Which of the following statements about diaphragmatic hernias of Moagani is TRUE?
options: Women present at a younger age than men
They more commonly occur on the left side
Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
Laparoscopic or open repair is possible
Morgagni hernias make up 50% of all diaphragmatic hernias
items.explanation: The incidence of congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH) is 1 in 2000 to 5000 births. The cause of this sporadic developmental anomaly is unknown. The most common CDH is hernia of Bochdalek, which occurs on the left side in 80% of cases and involves a posterolateral defect in the diaphragm. Morgagni's foramen are small triangular areas at the anterior aspect of the diaphragm on either side of the inferior end of the sternum. Morgagni hernia is a congenital defect between the costal and sternal portions of the diaphragm muscle. Morgagni hernias make up 3% of all diaphragmatic hernias. They occur far more commonly on the right side (91%) despite protection from the liver. The defect itself usually has a greater transverse dimension than the anteroposterior dimension. Morgagni hernias occur more commonly in women (62%) than men. The average patient age at presentation is 53. The average age at presentation is 58 for women and 50 for men. In women, 15% of cases present between 56 and 60 years of age; men have a more bimodal distribution, with peaks at 31 to 35 and 66 to 70. The most common symptoms are pressure in the chest or abdomen (37%) followed closely by pulmonary symptoms (36%); 28% of patients are asymptomatic at presentation and the hernia is usually found on chest x-ray. Acute presentations occur more frequently in children. Morgagni hernias can be repaired via laparotomy, thoracotomy, thoracoscopy. Surgical repair is indicated in all cases due to incarceration. items.question: Six months after laparoscopic splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura, a 38-year-old woman with lupus remains thrombocytopenic (platelet count, 42,000 cells/mm3). The next step should be
items.explanation: The treatment of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is generally medical. Corticosteroids achieve a response in about two thirds of patients. Intravenous IgG and plasmapheresis have also been used acutely to increase platelet levels in patients with bleeding due to severely reduced platelet counts (typically seen with platelet counts < 20,000/μL). Spontaneous bleeding with a platelet count above this level is unusual, and platelet transfusion is not needed. Intravenous IgG and plasmapheresis have only short-term effects, and are not definitive treatment for thrombocytopenia. The diagnosis of ITP might be in doubt, but the presence of an accessory spleen must first be excluded. The presence of splenic tissue can be diagnosed by examination of the blood smear for Howell-Jolly bodies, which appear in the red cells of asplenic patients. Persistent splenic tissue can be confirmed by a technetium radionuclide scan. There is no indication that this patient is at risk for thrombotic events, and aspirin is not indicated.

items.question: A 25-year-old woman who is 23 weeks pregnant presents with epigastric pain. Serum amylase is 653 U/L and lipase is 922 U/L. Ultrasound study shows gallstones within the gallbladder and a normal common bile duct, and gallstone pancreatitis is diagnosed. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: After successful conservative treatment, the risk of recurrent pancreatitis during the same pregnancy is less than 15%
ERCP with common bile duct stone extraction is contraindicated in this patient
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy can be performed with low risk to the mother and fetus
Most cases of gallstone pancreatitis occur in the first trimester
MR cholangiography is contraindicated in the second trimester
items.explanation: Acute pancreatitis occurs in 1:1000 to 4000 pregnancies. Fifty percent of cases occur in the second trimester, with pancreatitis in the first trimester being relatively uncommon. Concern over the potential for harm to the fetus has led many to adopt a conservative approach to the management of patients with gallstone pancreatitis during pregnancy, but conservative management will result in recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in 50% of cases. Experience with laparoscopic cholecystectomy has shown that this procedure can be performed safely during the second trimester of pregnancy. If necessary, the bile ducts can be evaluated without risk to the fetus by magnetic resonance cholangiography (MRC). If MRC demonstrates the presence of common bile ducts stones, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can be performed with shielding of the fetus. With appropriate shielding for the fetus, average fetal exposure from fluoroscopy and spot films is 300 rad, well below the 5 to 10-rad level considered to be concerning for teratogenesis.

items.question: Prospective, randomized trials comparing laparoscopic versus open colectomy for cancer suggest all of the following are true EXCEPT:
options: no statistical difference in overall and 5-year survival
no statistical difference in intraoperative complications
items.explanation: Laparoscopic colectomy is now an acceptable treatment for colon cancer in experienced hands. Retrospective analyses have demonstrated its safety, with similar overall survival and disease-free survival as open colectomies. The first prospective, randomized multicenter trial comparing laparoscopic colectomy with open colectomy for treatment of cancer was published in 2004 (Clinical Outcomes of Surgical Therapy Study Group). Three-year recurrence rates were similar for both techniques, as was the overall survival (86% and 85%, respectively). Recurrences at surgical wounds were rare, but similar between the two groups, debunking the idea of trocar site recurrences. Laparoscopic colectomy also resulted in a shorter median hospital stay (5 days versus 6 days) and decreased parenteral and oral analgesic utilization. The overall complication rate and 30-day mortality were similar for both techniques. A trend toward higher intraoperative complications such as bleeding and bowel injury was noted with the laparoscopic technique, but was not significant.

items.question: A security guard sustains a left thoracoabdominal stab wound. He is alert, talking, and hemodynamically stable. On examination the abdomen is soft and nontender. The most appropriate management would be
items.explanation: The thoracoabdominal region, defined as the area between the nipple and the costal margin, was once considered the ultimate blind spot in penetrating thoracoabdominal injuries. No conventional diagnostic study (CT scan, ultrasound, plain x-ray, diagnostic peritoneal lavage, etc) could reliably detect a diaphragm injury. Expectant management is problematic because diaphragmatic injuries can be asymptomatic for an extended period but eventually lead to visceral herniation and obstruction. Diagnostic laparoscopy is now the best diagnostic and therapeutic procedure in hemodynamically stable patients with penetrating thoracoabdominal injuries.

items.question: Which of the following is more common after laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass than an open procedure?
items.explanation: Although third-party payers have begun taking steps to limit eligibility of patients, both laparoscopic and open Roux-en-Y gastric bypasses are being performed in record numbers. Laparoscopic and open procedures have equivalent effectiveness of weight loss, anastomotic leak rates, and in most studies, mortality. Mortality has been higher for open procedures in some studies. Wound complications, specifically wound infection and incisional hernia, are more prevalent with open procedures, and hospital stay is predictably longer. The laparoscopic approach requires slightly longer operative times and is costlier, although overall hospital costs are equivalent for both approaches because of the shortened stay after laparoscopic bypass. Bowel obstruction is also more common, likely due to the higher incidence of internal hernias seen after laparoscopic procedures. Internal hernia occurs after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass through three defects: at the jejunojejunal anastomosis, at the opening in the transverse mesocolon through which the retrocolic Roux limb is passed, and behind the Roux limb (Petersen hernia). The laparoscopic approach has a higher rate of internal hernia because these defects are more difficult to close laparoscopically and also because adhesion formation is decreased compared with the open procedure. The incidence of internal hernia is lower when the Roux limb is placed in an antecolic position. Diagnosis of internal hernia requires a high index of suspicion. Internal hernia can cause chronic abdominal pain (typically periumbilical) and can be difficult to diagnose because contrast studies and computed tomography (CT) are often normal. Left untreated, internal hernia can lead to bowel obstruction and/or small bowel necrosis. Most repairs can be performed laparoscopically.

items.question: A laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed in a 55-year-old woman. Pathology reveals gallbladder adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosal lamina propria. Appropriate management includes
options: excision of gallbladder fossa and laparoscopic port sites
excision of gallbladder fossa, porta lymphadenectomy
excision of gallbladder fossa, port sites, and lymphadenectomy, excision of common bile duct
items.explanation: A, Sesap13 category14 Q5 Long-term survival in patients with gallbladder carcinoma is generally limited to those with isolated, incidentally discovered disease confined to the mucosa. In the setting of an incidential discovered gallbladder carcinoma confined to the mucosal lamina propria (stage T1a) following laparoscopic cholecystectomy, no further surgical treatment is required. Patients must be followed-up closely for the potential development of port site metastases or locoregional recurrence.

items.question: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman undergoes successful laparoscopic appendectomy for nonperforated appendicitis with no other pelvic pathology. The final histopathologic report describes mucinous cystadenoma. The next step should be
options: staging laparotomy with lymph node biopsies
items.explanation: Sesap13 category14 Q21 Appendicitis is the most common presenting symptom of appendiceal neoplasms. They can be found in up to 5% of appendices, with only half recognized at the time of operation. Mucoeles are the most common neoplasm and are divided into 4 histologic types. Retention cysts, mucosal hyperplasia, cystadenoma are benign, whereas cystadenocarcinoma and malignant tumors has a 5-year survival rate of 55%. Malignant neoplasms will generally be recognized by cellular atypia or invasion of the cyst wall. Benign lesions of the appendix in any location and malignant lesions confined to the distal two thirds of the appendix without invasion may be managed by appendectomy alone. Right hemicolectomy and tumor staging are recommended for malignant lesions that are invasive or involve the proximal one third of the appendix.

items.question: The appearance of cholestatic liver disease in the neonatal period can be related to which disorder except:
A 3-week-old, first-born male develops forceful, nonbilious emesis. Which of these findings establishes the diagnosis?
options: ultrasonographic pyloric muscle thickness of 2.5 mm
ultrasonographic pyloric antrum ratio greater than 1.5 cm
ultrasonographic pyloric diameter of 1.0 cm or less
an UGI series showing a classic “double bubble” sign
palpable pyloric mass (olive) midline of the abdomen
items.explanation: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is one of the most common surgical conditions of infancy. It occurs in 1–3 of every 1000 live births. Boys are affected four times more often than girls. Pathogenesis involves pyloric muscle fiber hypertrophy causing a mechanical obstruction of the gastric outlet. The etiology of HPS remains elusive but family history, sex, birth order, and maternal feeding patterns all have been implicated. Various theories support the pathophysiology of HPS including compensatory work hypertrophy, neurodegeneration/immaturity, and abnormal endocrine signals. Some reports also link early erythromycin exposure and HPS. It is hypothesized that erythromycin interacts with motilin receptors inducing pyloric contractions that result in hypertrophy. HPS most commonly develops from 2 to 12 weeks (peak incidence of 3–6 weeks) of age in an otherwise healthy infant who feeds normally at birth. A pattern of vomiting ensues which varies but classically progresses to projectile nonbilious emesis. Diagnosis of HPS is primarily made by history and physical. Physical examination findings include peristaltic waves in the epigastric area and the presence of a palpable mass in the upper abdomen (Figs. 34-24 and 34-25). The absence of these findings with a strong history of HPS should prompt an US or an UGI contrast study. US criteria include a pyloric muscle thickness >4 mm, pyloric muscle diameter >14 mm, and a channel length >17 mm, but are adjusted by age. If US is nondiagnostic, an UGI contrast study can aid in ruling out reflux, malrotation, or obstruction. UGI finding consistent with HPS include a “string” sign, a “double track” sign, or “shoulders” at the proximal end of the pyloris. When the diagnosis has been confirmed and the child’s fluid and electrolyte status has been corrected, operative intervention is undertaken. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the procedure of choice and can be performed via an open or laparoscopic approach.

items.question: The appearance of cholestatic jaundice in the newborn period can be related to which of the following disorders except:
items.explanation: Jaundice in the newborn period is a relatively common occurrence in infants. For many newborn infants, jaundice may represent a manifestation of an ongoing adaptation to the extrauterine environment. Nevertheless, it cannot be automatically assumed to be a mild or physiologic condition. Generally, jaundice refers to an elevated blood concentration of bilirubin. Hyperbilirubinemia can be due to indirect or accumulation of unconjugated, lipid soluble bilirubin pigment in the serum or be due to direct bilirubin or conjugated, water soluble form. When the serum concentration of conjugated bilirubin and/or bile salts is elevated, it denotes a pathologic state (cholestasis) of reduced bile flow. While initial workup for the jaundiced infant is medically oriented, surgeons should be aware of the wide differential diagnosis of cholestatic jaundice and be cognizant of the surgically treated causes of cholestasis (biliary atresia, choledochocysts, congenital anomalies of the biliary tree, and perforation of the common bile duct). Cholestasis may develop due to a variety of insults. These include drugs (flecanide), parenteral nutrition (most common cause in the NICU), ECMO, infectious agents (e.g., bacterial sepsis, viral causes, and toxoplasmosis), inherited/metabolic causes, endocrine abnormalities, and chromosomal aberrations (trisomies 18 and 21). For example, a lipid metabolic disorder such as Niemann-Pick’s disease (NPD) (sphingomyelinase deficiency) can present with neonatal cholestasis. NPD is a heterogeneous group of lysosomal lipid storage diseases. Patients afflicted with NPD can present with neonatal cholestasis, hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, and death between 3 and 9 months. Two metabolic classification groups exist: NP types A/B, which are primarily sphingomyelinase deficiencies, and type C, which refers to alterations of trafficking of endocytosed cholesterol. While liver pathology is unknown, histology resembles neonatal hepatitis. As the disease progresses, hepatic lobules become progressively distended with portal cholestasis. CF may be confused with inspissated bile syndrome or ductal atresia and causes neonatal cholestasis. CF is most commonly caused by a mutation which results in deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (delta F508 mutation). The gene product is cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) and mutation in the protein results in the impaired ability of CFTR to increase chloride channel activity that leads to paucity of water in mucous secretions. α1AT deficiency results in neonatal cholestasis due to hepatocellular and bile duct injury. α1AT deficiency is the most common genetic cause of liver disease in children. α1AT, a member of the serine proteinase inhibitor superfamily, is the principle blood borne inhibitor of destructive neutrophil proteases which include elastase, cathepsin G, and proteinase 3. Most α1AT is synthesized in the liver where it translocates to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). When α1AT associates with a binding protein, it can fold into its native conformation and traverse the secretory pathway. Mutations in the gene responsible for α1AT result in misfolded molecules, which accumulate in the liver and cause hepatocyte injury due to resultant release of lysosomal enzymes and cause ductular proliferation and luminal bile plugging.

items.question: 29. A 3-week-old infant has had persistent jaundice since birth. The physical examination reveals an active infant with obvious jaundice, mild hepatomegaly, and the presence of acholic stools. Abdominal US results were equivocal. The HIDA scan was performed and suggests what abnormality?
items.explanation: Persistence of neonatal jaundice beyond 2 weeks of age or once biochemical tests have confirmed pathologic jaundice (conjugated bilirubin greater than 2 mg/dL or over 15% of the total bilirubin concentration) warrants radiologic evaluation. US is usually the first modality used to evaluate pathologic jaundice. US can examine the liver, bile ducts, gall bladder, pancreas, spleen, and portal vein. In BA, US may show hepatomegaly and increasing echogenicity, a small or absent gall bladder, and nonvisible biliary ducts. The presence of polyspenia also supports the diagnosis. CC at US appear as simple cysts (I, II, and III) in the region of the gall bladder. The presence of a dilated extrahepatic biliary tree in conjunction with a cyst highly suggests this pathology. Depending on the type of choledochal cyst, other intrahepatic cysts may be shown on US. Cholithiasis and choledocholithiasis in the newborn period are rare and if suspected on US, stones appear as freely movable, bright echoic shadowing foci within the gall bladder lumen while bright echoic structures within the biliary ducts is usually associated with ductal dilatation (the common bile duct should measure less than 1 mm in neonates, less than 2 mm in infants up to 1-year-old, less than 4 mm in older children, and less than 7 mm in adolescents). In most cases of biliary dyskinesia, the US is normal. Suspected biliary fistulas should be evaluated in patients who have sustained hepatic injury or undergone recent hepatobiliary surgery. An US may show free intraperitoneal fluid and subsequent paracentesis would reveal biliary fluid. If US is unable to exclude hepatobiliary pathology, a nuclear hepatobiliary scan (HIDA scan) should be the next imaging test for studying the hepatic parenchyma and associated biliary tree. In BA, particularly early, the uptake of the nucleotide is rapid but excretion into the bowel is absent. Moreover, failure to show gut excretion is nondiagnostic and HIDA is unable to distinguish BA versus other causes of cholestasis. Cholangiography would be the next study to investigate exact areas in question; demonstration of duodenal contrast and intrahepatic ducts would exclude BA. In CC, HIDA and endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) can be used after US in order to gain additional information concerning biliary anatomy. ERCP has the advantage of delineating biliary and pancreatic duct definition and may aid in preoperative decision making. In cases of suspected choledocholithiasis, the most favorable treatment in children remains controversial. Options include an open cholecystectomy with simultaneous common bile duct (CBD) exploration, laparoscopic cholecystectomy with preoperative/postoperative ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone removal, or laparoscopic cholecystectomy and laparoscopic removal of CBD stones. Some consider the complication rate for pediatric ERCP higher and recommend strict selection criteria be done prior to subjecting a pediatric patient to ERCP, especially biliary lithiasis. The advent of cholecystokinin (CCK)-HIDA has made the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia more accurately. Using CCK (peptide hormone produced by the I cells of duodenum and upper jejunum that acts on the gall bladder wall musculature) to stimulate the gall bladder measures the degree of emptying (ejection fraction). An ejection fraction of <35% denotes biliary dyskinesia. Cholecystectomy should be considered in children with chronic upper abdominal pain and delayed ejection fraction on CCK-HIDA scintigraphy. Hepatic biliary scanning (HIDA) is a sensitive test for documenting the presence or absence of biliary leaks (fistulas) because the tracer is concentrated and excreted into the biliary ductal system. Because it cannot pinpoint injuries to the extrahepatic ducts, cholangiography would be employed to detect exact injuries. In this case, US fails to show a detectable sonographic abnormality yet the HIDA scan demonstrates inability to visualize radiolabelled iminodiacetic acid derivative into the small intestine after 19h. The scan suggests a diagnosis of BA.

items.question: 30. An 8-year-old child is referred to a pediatric surgeon because of localized right lower quadrant pain. The pain has been ongoing for approximately 10 h and the child appears toxic. Which of the following is incorrect regarding appendicitis in children?

items.question: A 12-month-old full-term male is diagnosed with an inguinal and an umbilical hernia (ring diameter >2 cm). During the discussion of pediatric hernias with parents, select the CORRECT statement.
options: The most common cause of indirect hernia in this age group is due to a connective tissue disorder.
Laparoscopy has aided in evaluation of the contralateral inguinal area for hernias.
Routine laparoscopic evaluation for a patent contralateral processus vaginalis should be advocated for all patients.
The inguinal hernia should be repaired and the umbilical defect left alone.
Repair of both inguinal and umbilical hernias (UH), Femoral hernias (FH) in children are easier to detect as compared to an adult.
items.explanation: Repair of pediatric hernias constitutes one of the most common congenital anomalies that pediatric surgeons are confronted with. The majority of inguinal hernias in infants and children are indirect and are a result of the failure of the processus vaginalis (a diverticulum of peritoneum) to involute as the process of gonad descent proceeds into the scrotum in males and the lower pelvis in females. The processus vaginalis is an anteromedial structure that appears to aid in testicular descent by providing the hydrolic force that positions the testis into the scrotum; it later regresses and thereby obliterates the entrance of the peritoneal cavity into the inguinal canal. Various other conditions are associated with inguinal hernias and include a positive family history, undescended testis (UDT), prematurity, ascites, hypospadias or epispadias, presence of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, misuse of continuous peritoneal dialysis, ambiguous genitalia, and children with connective tissue disorders (Ehlers-Danlos and Hunter-Suhle syndrome). Because this type of hernia will not close spontaneously and of the high risk of incarceration (especially in infants under 1 year of age), inguinal hernias should be repaired within 4 weeks of diagnosis. While repair of inguinal hernias involves high suture ligation of the sac at the level of the internal ring, the issue of contralateral exploration continues to be a subject of debate. There seems to have evolved a selective approach to managing the opposite groin based on age, gender, and patent processes vaginalis. In children less than 2 years of age, the patency of the PV is high and some advocate contralateral exploration because of the frequent occurrence of unsuspected hernias. Recent studies have not shown significant differences in determining the presence of a contralateral PPV in cases of unilateral inguinal hernia. Laparoscopy has aided in detection of a contralateral PPV. Yet the issue of a PPV is that it is a potential factor for inguinal hernia development, it does not represent a true hernia. Spontaneous closure occurs in the majority of cases (60% by 2 years of age) and it appears that not all PPVs develop into inguinal hernias. Nevertheless, some justify a contralateral exploration in children who are at high anesthetic risk, when distance and transportation issues may impede the return of an infant to the hospital, and if the child is at risk for subsequent development for an inguinal hernia (children with VP shunts, connective tissue disorders, family history of bilateral inguinal hernias). UH are a result of intestinal protrusion through an incompletely closed, contracting umbilical ring. Some conditions that predispose an infant to UH include low birth weight infants, Beckwith-Weidemann's syndrome (BWS), Down's syndrome, and ascites. Most UH close after birth and the risk of strangulation or incarceration is extremely low. Most pediatric surgeons defer treatment until 4 or 5 years of age before operating on asymptomatic patients. A relative surgical indication is related to size of the defect: a defect greater than 2 cm is not likely to close spontaneously. items.question: Neonatal presacral mass is most likely:
items.explanation: Sacrococcygeal teratoma is the most common neonatal solid tumor occurring in the presacral region. These are typically benign, mature teratomas composed of elements of the three embryonic germ layers. Complete surgical excision with coccygectomy is essential to reduce local recurrence rates.

items.question: Most common pediatric abdominal malignancy is:
items.explanation: Neuroblastoma is the most common pediatric abdominal malignancy. Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and these tumors occur in the adrenal medulla and in the paravertebral sympathetic chain in the chest and abdomen. Most children present with regional or distant metastases at the time of diagnosis.

In a recent longitudinal cohort study to determine the long-term outcome of children with PSC, 81% had concomitant inflammatory bowel disease. items.question: 36. Which of the following is a component of VACTERL?
items.explanation: Intestinal obstruction may occur from a variety of causes in the first month of life. Prompt diagnosis and treatment is vital, because delay may be life-threatening. Plain abdominal x-rays show an air-fluid level in the stomach, and another smaller air-fluid level in the dilated, obstructed duodenum—the classic double-bubble. Seventy percent of infants with anorectal malformations have associated anomalies, identified by the acronym VACTERL (or VATER): Vertebral dysplasia or agenesis, Anorectal malformations, Cardiac lesions, Tracheo-esophageal fistula, Renal or lower urogenital anomalies, and Limb abnormalities. Physostigmine antagonizes atropine more than neostigmine
items.explanation: Neostigmine produces fewer secretions and less severe bradycardia

items.question: 56. What is the diagnosis in a patient who presents to the emergency department with facial deformity following a car crash. Palpation of the maxillary and nasal bones with the index finger reveals step and mobility in the middle of the face just below the zygomatic arch?
items.explanation: LeFort I fracture, occasionally complicated by palatal split, where the right and left maxillary bones are separated just above the teeth. This fracture causes the maxilla and palate to be mobile as a unit but remains attached to the nasal bones

items.question: A 45-year-old male developed swelling in the right temporal region and aggravation of headache,   Following are true in the temporal region swelling, except?
options: Abscess without involving the temporomandibular joint.
If swelling involves the angle of the mouth, deflects the mouth to the opposite side
Color changes over the facial nerve may pass below the ear in the submandibular region.
Swelling with hypoesthesia of the lower facial muscle, including paralysis of those acting on the angle of the mouth
items.explanation: (Answer: D) Large parotid duct. Color changes over the facial nerve may pass below the ear in the submandibular region. Swelling with hypoesthesia of the lower facial muscle, including paralysis of those acting on the angle of the mouth.

items.question: Regarding renal trauma, TRUE statement is:
options: Grade 1-3 injuries are minor (class I and II) and can be managed by observation.
Class III injuries require urgent exploration
Stab penetration with a small handle like incision and debris should be excised
Class III injuries should be treated by laparoscopic haematuria
items.explanation: Grade 1-3 injuries are minor (Class I/II) and can be managed conservatively.

items.explanation: Aortic rupture with retroperitoneal fibrosis which of the following structures is involved first?

items.question: Percentage injuries to Zone I carry the best prognosis?
options: Percentages to Zone I are the most common and carry the highest mortality
Percentages to Zone I are the most common and carry the highest morbidity
Prooperative angiography is generally not required for Zone I injuries
All zones should have angiography with penetrating injury
Most vascular lesions in Zone III are best treated by surgical exploration
items.explanation: Answer D. Meckelsson et al int J Surg 2012. There are three zones defined by the zone of the neck. Zone I represents the base of the neck, at the thoracic inlet. Zone II is between the clavicles to the floor of the mouth. Zone III is the mid-body and largest portion of the neck. Injuries in Zone I have highest mortality and morbidity. Zone I injuries are the most common but carry a lower mortality because of low exposure of the vital structures readily accessible with direct visualization. Zone I injuries generally appear on exposure of the vital structures readily accessible with direct visualization of the vital structures. Zone II injuries generally the highest coronary artery injuries and the highest rate of penetrating neck injury to the distal carotid artery, jugular vein, and thoracic inlet. Zone II injuries are the most common but carry a lower mortality due to accessibility for surgery. Most surgical groups treat Zone II injuries surgically. Zone I and III patients with penetrating neck injuries often require angiography for the evaluation of injury to great vessels and this is important.

items.question: Which of the following statements about cervical rib is correct?
options: It is a common cause of subclavian vein thrombosis
It represents an extension of the transverse process of C8
It is better to remove it if symptomatic
It is usually incidental radiological finding
It is associated with brachial plexus injury immediately after trauma
items.explanation: Answer D is correct. Cervical ribs are an occasional anatomical variant usually found incidentally on chest x-ray or cervical spine films. They may cause thoracic outlet syndrome if they compress neurovascular structures.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding B. Nonmelanoma skin cancer?
items.explanation: Nonmelanoma skin cancer is correct as per the context provided.

items.question: The basic component of each immunoglobulin contains ten

items.question: The constant region of heavy chain forms an antigen-binding site.

items.question: In hematopoietic progenitor formation an antigen-binding site remains the most important factor in reducing alloreactivity.

items.question: The main function of immunoglobulin E is release of
items.explanation: Immunoglobulin E is the major immunoglobulin of the organ procurement organization (OPO).

items.question: The variable regions of heavy chains and one light chain offered regionally followed by nationally local centers is list
items.explanation: This describes the function of the organ procurement organization (OPO).

items.question: 70. The MOST APPROPRIATE treatment of a lymphocele is
options: Laparoscopic or open peritoneal window along with sclerosing agents
items.explanation: Lymphocele post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder is unlikely to regress spontaneously. Percutaneous aspiration has a high recurrence rate; laparoscopic or open peritoneal window along with sclerosing agents are effective.

items.question: 71. The reported incidence of lymphoceles (fluid collections of cellular lymph) following renal transplantation is about
items.explanation: Reported incidence of lymphoceles usually do not exceed 1% in most centers but overall ranges from 6-18%.

items.question: 72. PTLD (post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder) is
options: A syndrome with lymphoid proliferation and tumor formation
items.explanation: PTLD is associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection and occurs in association with immunosuppression.

items.question: 73. The most common indication for pediatric liver transplantation is
items.explanation: Biliary atresia is the most common indication for pediatric liver transplant, accounting for about 50% of cases.

items.question: 74. The most common vascular complication after liver transplantation is
items.explanation: Hepatic artery thrombosis is the most common early vascular complication after liver transplantation.

items.question: A 46-year-old woman has diffuse, indeterminate, suspicious, malignant, non-mass-like enhancement (NMLE) involving all four quadrants of the breast. The three BEST managements are:
options: Incisional biopsy of 3 cm clusters in the lower outer quadrant.
Needle localization lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy and postoperative radiotherapy.
items.explanation: Incisional biopsy of 3 cm clusters in the lower outer quadrant is the best option for diagnosis and further management in this scenario.

items.question: Immunophenotypical medullary lymph node (SLN) biopsy with sentinel node biopsy, postoperative radiotherapy, and axillary LN dissection are contraindicated after:
items.explanation: Complete mastectomy contraindicates further axillary lymph node dissection or sentinel node biopsy.

items.question: A 63-year-old woman with a 3.5 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast, large enough to disrupt the normal lymphatic drainage of the breast and the left axilla. The most appropriate management is:
options: Lumpectomy and sentinel LN biopsy with postoperative radiotherapy.
Axillary LN dissection and postoperative radiotherapy.
Modified radical mastectomy and postoperative radiotherapy.
Axillary LN dissection and modified radical mastectomy.
items.explanation: Modified radical mastectomy with level I and II axillary LN dissection and postoperative radiotherapy is the standard treatment for a large infiltrating ductal carcinoma disrupting normal lymphatic drainage.

items.question: 78. Increased breast cancer risk is NOT associated with which of the following factors?
options: ATM, BRCA1, BRCA2, and TP53 gene mutations
Prolonged hormone replacement therapy after hysterectomy
items.explanation: Nipple adenoma is a benign growth and is not associated with an increased risk for breast cancer.

items.question: 79. Which of the following statements about risk factors for the development of breast cancer are correct?
options: Applies to male breast cancer only
Some are hormone dependent and receptor positive
Estrogen and progesterone receptors are inversely proportional to prognosis
Conjugated estrogen therapy after hysterectomy increases risk
Important risk factor for breast cancer history is age
items.explanation: Some breast cancers express hormone receptors, and positivity is linked to prognosis and treatment options.

items.question: 80. A 40-year-old premenopausal woman underwent small area of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). In the management list, extending to one margin is noted. In small area of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), what is the next step in management?
options: Remove further tissue from the positive margin side with reoperation
Remove further tissue from the negative margin side with reoperation
items.explanation: In small area of LCIS extending to one margin, the next step is observation and follow up rather than reoperation.

items.question: 81. Select the BEST treatment option for a 5-cm phyllodes
options: Excision with 2-cm margin with sentinel lymph node biopsy
Total mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection
items.explanation: Adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy is not warranted for phyllodes tumors; excision with 2-cm margin is the treatment of choice.

items.question: 82. A 47-year-old woman underwent
options: Fine needle aspiration cytology and ultrasound
items.explanation: Patients with inflammatory carcinoma of the breast require biopsy of involved skin, not fine needle aspiration or ultrasound alone; axillary lymph node biopsy is appropriate.

items.question: 83. A 21-year-old woman with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease presents with right breast pain and swelling. She has a tender, fluctuant mass, right axillary lymphadenopathy, fever, chills, and malaise. She is diagnosed with breast abscess. She is afebrile with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease. She is found to have a perianal fistula and abscess. The patient is started on antibiotics and TPN. What is the BEST option for treatment?
items.explanation: Surgical drainage is the best option for breast abscess in a patient with inflammatory disease and systemic symptoms; antibiotics and TPN are adjuncts but surgical treatment is necessary.

items.question: Regarding paracolostomy hernia, the risk of perforation and incarceration as complications of colostomy is:
items.explanation: Obstruction is unusual, but may also occur with parastomal hernia. Herniation or prolapse occurs less frequently than parastomal hernias. Perforation, ischemia and incarceration are extremely rare and less prevalent complications than in stomal prolapse.

items.question: Schwartz 10e p1193: Complications of colostomy include all of the following except
items.explanation: Complications of colostomy include stoma ischemia, necrosis, prolapse, parastomal hernia, fistula, obstruction and colostomy colitis is rare but can be seen with diversion colitis affecting the colon distal to the stoma.

items.question: A 65-year-old man presents to the physician's office for routine colon cancer screening. His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and smoking. He underwent a sigmoid colon cancer 3 years ago for which he underwent a sigmoid colostomy. A routine physical examination 3 months ago was negative. His recent complete blood counts shows anemia; colonoscopy reveals a necrotic fungating mass at stoma site. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. This is most likely a complication of which of the following?
items.explanation: Colon cancer can develop at the site of colostomy as a result of chronic irritation. Chronic irritation by stool, frequent trauma to mucosa by continuous microscopic injury results in malignant transformation.

items.question: Diverting colostomy is indicated in all of the following except:
items.explanation: Diverting colostomy is used for fecal peritonitis, fistula opening of rectovaginal compartment, anastomotic leak, and therapeutic colonic rest but it can cause diversion colitis, which is a complication, not an indication.

items.question: 90. The best treatment for rectal cancer staged by MRI TNM as T3N1MO is ?
options: No further treatment, resection followed surgery
items.explanation: Preoperative chemo radiotherapy followed surgery is the best treatment for rectal cancer staged as T3N1MO by MRI, aiming to reduce tumor size and improve surgical outcomes.

items.question: After neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, a patient with rectal cancer was found to have complete clinical response on MRI and clinical examination. Which of the following is TRUE?
options: Accurate clinical assessment locally advanced rectal cancer that is > 2 cm from the anal verge is unreliable and inaccurate.
Tumour downsizing is correlated with the presence of mucinous adenocarcinoma.
Histological complete pathologic response rate is about 70-80%.
Histopathologic staging is more predictive of outcome versus clinical stage.
Local excision rates after transanal excision is associated with high local failure rates after radiation.
items.explanation: Histopathologic staging is indeed more predictive of outcome than clinical staging in rectal cancer after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding advanced rectal cancer?
options: MRI is better than CT in preoperative staging in locally advanced rectal cancer.
T3 tumour infiltration through muscularis propria into perirectal fat is best detected by endorectal ultrasound.
MRI can accurately assess circumferential resection margin.
Postoperative local excision is standard treatment for T3 or N1-2 by ultrasound or MRI.
Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is the best option for early T2N0 rectal cancer.
items.explanation: MRI is superior to CT for preoperative staging and assessment of locally advanced rectal cancer because it better visualizes soft tissue planes and the mesorectal fascia.

items.question: Which of the following statements about nonpolypoid colorectal neoplasms is correct?
options: Are defined by a height equal to the diameter of the lesion
Are classified as type IIc (Paris classification) lesions
Are common in patients who have colonoscopy for invasive cancer (T1)
Have a precursor to colorectal cancer secondary to DNA methylation
Detection rate requires no special techniques during colonoscopy
items.explanation: Nonpolypoid neoplasms are generally flat or slightly elevated mucosal lesions with a height less than 3 mm. They are classified as type IIc according to the Paris classification.

items.question: A villous adenoma 4 cm in diameter, giving has a 30-50% risk of cancer, should be treated with:
items.explanation: A villous adenoma 4 cm in diameter has a significant risk of cancer (30-50%) and should be treated with segmental colectomy to ensure complete removal and to address the risk of malignancy.

items.question: 94. A 50-year-old gentleman, recently underwent a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Postoperatively, he was given regular amlodipine, furosemide and nil tablets for calcium supplements with following biochemical report: Serum calcium 6.2, albumin 4.0, serum phosphate 3.5, urine calcium 80, and serum parathormone assay 6 pg/ml (normal 10-65). Which of the following surgical wound complications is most likely in this patient?
items.explanation: Postop hematoma is a common complication of thyroidectomy in patients given drugs such as amlodipine and furosemide which tend to increase the bleeding risk.

items.question: 95. Choose the CORRECT statement regarding papillary carcinoma of thyroid?
options: Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy
Is often associated with lymph node metastases
Papillary carcinoma responds poorly to radio-iodine therapy
Usually does not recur in the time of operation
Psammoma bodies are seen in papillary microcarcinoma
items.explanation: Papillary carcinoma is commonly associated with lymph node metastases resulting in high recurrence rates and is the most common thyroid malignancy.

items.question: 96. Hamartoma most commonly occurs in which of the following locations?
items.explanation: Pulmonary hamartomas are the most commonly seen type of hamartomas, benign lesions often composed of cartilage, fat, and connective tissue.

items.question: 97. What is the preferred treatment for a hereditary case of medullary thyroid carcinoma?
items.explanation: Bilateral total thyroidectomy is the preferred treatment in hereditary medullary thyroid carcinoma to avoid recurrence and bilateral involvement.

items.question: 98. A patient with familial medullary thyroid carcinoma requires the following genetic test:
items.explanation: RET proto-oncogene mutation is involved in familial medullary thyroid carcinoma and its exclusion or identification is important for diagnosis and family screening.

items.question: 100. A 43-year-old teacher underwent left parotidectomy. Dyspnea was observed. This complication was most likely due to injury to which one of the following?
items.explanation: Facial nerve cervical branch innervates the lower lip including mandibular part of the mentalis. As no cross innervation exists to other branches of the facial nerve, the same and left side lower lip injuries always yields paralysis of the mentalis. Injuries of the main trunk of the facial nerve or temporal branch would usually produce upper facial paralysis as well.

items.question: 101. A 30-year-old male presents with a large, well-marked midline abdominal mass and complains of abdominal pain over the epigastrium. He had worsening abdominal pain over the last 6 weeks prior to surgery. The abdominal CT reveals a multicystic pancreatic mass in the tail of the pancreas. What would be the most likely diagnosis to explain these findings?
items.explanation: Pseudocysts is an area of necrosis with a wall composed of fibrous and granulation tissue. It is a complication of chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic trauma.

items.question: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food. Esophagography shows a diverticulum at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. The diagnosis is
items.explanation: Zenker's diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal diverticulum occurring at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It causes progressive dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food.

options: Is associated with chronic gastritis and H pylori infection
Consists of squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma
items.explanation: Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with chronic gastritis and H pylori infection, which is more relevant for gastric carcinoma.

items.question: The type of esophageal motility disorder that presents with intermittent solid and liquid dysphagia, is associated with a 'corkscrew' esophagus on barium swallow, and is a primary esophageal motility disorder is
items.explanation: Diffuse esophageal spasm causes intermittent solid and liquid dysphagia with a 'corkscrew' appearance on barium swallow.

items.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of esophageal perforation?
options: Gastrografin swallow is the initial investigation with high sensitivity
Barium swallow is preferred due to better radiographic detail
CT neck and chest have no role in diagnosis
Endoscopy is the best initial test
MRI is the gold standard imaging to detect perforation
items.explanation: Gastrografin swallow is the initial imaging investigation for suspected esophageal perforation because it is safe and has good sensitivity. Barium swallow can cause mediastinitis if leak is present.

items.question: Extended lymph node dissection improves survival rates in

items.explanation: Most of them are asymptomatic and found incidentally, from the first plastica should be resected to histologically negative margins.

items.question: Is statement is true? With regard to the following statements is true?
options: Static disruption for lesions results in longer survival
Routinely splenectomy does not improve survival rates
Total gastrectomy is usually accomplished with an esophagojejunostomy
Delay from angiographic embolization to surgery may be greater than 3 months
items.explanation: With regard to the surgical treatment of severe nausea with an inability to tolerate oral medications usually accomplished with an esophagojejunostomy.

items.question: 10. Which type of gastric ulcer corresponds with the following description?
items.explanation: Type I ulcers are the most common and occur on the lesser curvature of the stomach, in the region of the incisura angularis. Most gastric ulcers are type I.

items.question: 11. Concerning the treatment of patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which of the following is true?
options: Surgical excision of tumors is not indicated
Long term medical therapy is not successful
Surgical excision is necessary in all cases
Total gastrectomy is indicated if the tumor cannot be found
items.explanation: If the tumor cannot be located, total gastrectomy is indicated to control acid secretion and acid-related complications.

items.question: When a bile leak is confirmed, cholangiography during an elective ERCP study can help:
options: identify severity and site of leakage and help determine further therapy.
establish the site of leakage and rule out stones.
rule out bile leaks that originate from cystic duct stump.
confirm and relieve obstruction from stones and sludge.
items.explanation: Cholangiography during an elective ERCP study can help to identify the severity and site of leakage and help determine further therapy.

items.question: Which of the following procedures is the most appropriate for delineation of bile duct anatomy in complex situations?
items.explanation: MRCP is a noninvasive diagnostic examination but can be useful for delineation of bile duct anatomy in complex situations.

items.question: Hospitalized with gallstone pancreatitis and recovers after 2 weeks, which of the following recommendations is the most appropriate?
items.explanation: Hospitalized with gallstone pancreatitis and recovers after 2 weeks, elective cholecystectomy 6 weeks postdischarge is the most appropriate.

items.question: During the latter half of the first trimester and immediate postpartum, there is increased risk of which condition?
items.explanation: Symptomatic gallstone disease is second to appendicitis as the most common nonobstetric cause for hospital admission during all stages of pregnancy.

items.question: During pregnancy, what cystic duct diameter is considered diagnostic for obstruction?
items.explanation: Cystic duct diameter greater than 6 mm is diagnostic of obstruction.

items.question: Following laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis, the best option regarding the timing of tube cholangiography for a patient with difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomy is:
options: Placement of drains and termination of the procedure
items.explanation: Following laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis, the best option is placement of drains and termination of the procedure for posttransjugular tube cholangiography during the interval.

items.question: For a patient with difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which management approach is acceptable?
items.explanation: Management of a patient with difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomy includes several options such as conversion to open cholecystectomy, percutaneous cholecystostomy, laparoscopic subtotal cholecystectomy, and other approaches.

items.question: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) should be performed after:
items.explanation: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography should be performed after 3 days to allow adequate drainage.

items.question: Which of the following choices is true regarding management of choledocholithiasis?
options: Endoscopic sphincterotomy is the treatment of choice
Immediate open surgery is the preferred intervention
items.explanation: Endoscopic sphincterotomy is the treatment of choice for choledocholithiasis.

items.question: Treatment of the following statements is true regarding pseudocyst of pancreas?
options: Simple, solitary, unilocular true cyst of pancreas, non-neoplastic, lined by epithelium
Indication is acceptable for localized pancreatic abscess
Pseudocyst can be treated by percutaneous drainage, total excision, and marsupialisation
Pancreatectomy is generally necessary for pseudocyst
items.explanation: Pseudocyst of pancreas is a simple, solitary, and unilocular cyst without a true epithelial lining (not A). Indication is acceptable for localized pancreatic abscess. Pseudocyst can be treated by percutaneous drainage, total excision, and marsupialisation (B and C). Pancreatectomy is not generally necessary (not D). Hence, correct answer is E (B and C only).

items.question: Which of the following complication can occur in pancreatic pseudocyst?
items.explanation: Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include infected pseudocyst, hemorrhage from pseudocyst, secondary infection, and sterile pancreatic necrosis. Thus, all options are correct.

items.question: 22. Which of the following does NOT routinely increase during laparoscopic surgery?
items.explanation: Vital capacity and tidal volume decrease almost all respiratory variables such as peak inspiratory pressure, mean airway pressure, mechanical effects of increased intra-abdominal pressure, and changes of cardiac output. Cardiac index decreases while systemic vascular resistance increases. Combination of these factors typically requires a 15% increase in minute ventilation for compensation, even in healthy subjects.

items.question: 23. Thirty minutes into a laparoscopic procedure, capnography monitor shows an intra-abdominal pressure of 20 mmHg; end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) is 54 mmHg (normal, 35-45); arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) is 52 mmHg (normal, 35-45). What is the most likely explanation?
options: CO2 leak from the abdominal wall
items.explanation: Improper insuflator settings commonly result in excessive intra-abdominal pressure, which increases the amount of CO2 absorbed and can lead to high ETCO2 and PaCO2 levels. This requires adjustments to the insufflator settings rather than immediate termination or other diagnoses.

items.question: 24. Which of the following is NOT a potential advantage of laparoscopic surgery?
items.explanation: Laparoscopic surgery generally results in longer operative times due to the complexity of the technique, although it improves cosmetic results, reduces pain, shortens hospital stays, and improves pulmonary function compared to open surgery.

items.question: A 65-year-old man undergoes a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. Roux-en-Y has been shown to produce and maintain a weight loss of 60% to 80% at 5 years. Potentially serious complication of Gastric bypass is
items.explanation: Answer: C. Ssajips (category3) part II Q20

items.question: 25. A 52-year-old woman with a BMI of 45 undergoes a laparoscopic Sleeve gastrectomy. She loses 60% of her excess body weight. Complications of this operation include all of the following except
options: Prastitis for which of the following complications?
items.explanation: Answer: E. Ssajips (category3) part I Q14

items.question: 30. All of the following are advantages of gastric bypass except
options: Decreased dumping syndrome and greater net postmalabsorptive effect
Loss of weight greater than 5 years from surgery
Disadvantages include malabsorption of iron, B12, calcium, ascorbic acid, and vitamin D
Advantages include reduction of symptoms related to obesity nonmalabsorptive effect
items.explanation: Answer: B. 174 Surgery Review Questions Q266

items.question: 20. Compared with open appendectomy, patients undergoing laparoscopic appendectomy have
options: Equivalent hospital length of stay and equivalent hospital cost
Higher late rates of septic shock
Lower rates of surgical site infection
items.explanation: Answer: C. Ssajips (category3) part I Q17

items.question: 27. One-year after laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, a 45-year-old patient presents with a bowel obstruction. He had an open repair of incisional hernia 10 years before. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
items.explanation: Answer: C. Ssajips (category3) part II Q20

items.question: The advantage of sleeve gastrectomy over the Gastric band is
items.explanation: Needs less follow up

items.question: All the following are pure restrictive Bariatric procedures EXCEPT
items.explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy involves putting an adjustable band around the upper part of the stomach below the GE junction to produce less food entry and feeling of fullness. In fact, it involves putting an adjustable band around the upper part of the stomach below the GE junction to produce less food entry and feeling of fullness.

items.question: 35. Ileostomy - Roux-en-y gastric bypass and 75% distal gastrectomy with duodenal switch: A 47-year-old woman underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and was discharged on postoperative day 2. One year later, she presents with diarrhea, steatorrhea, fecal urgency, and weight loss. Her serum levels are low. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies most likely causes her symptoms and signs? Assumption: she is compliant with vitamin supplementation.
items.explanation: The most likely cause of her neurologic symptoms (peripheral neuropathy and anemia) coupled with the surgery description and malabsorption is vitamin B12 deficiency. This is typical following surgeries involving distal gastrectomy and bypass which interfere with intrinsic factor and vitamin B12 absorption.

items.question: 36. Breast cancer: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the treatment of breast cancer?
options: Painful bony metastases respond to chemotherapy
Conservative therapy is applied for T1 lesions
The management of primary breast cancer is initially best treated with endocrine therapy
items.explanation: Conservative therapy, including breast conserving surgery and radiotherapy, is appropriate for T1 breast cancers. Adjuvant chemotherapy can cause cardiomyopathy but is not the best initial treatment for primary breast cancer, which requires surgery first.

items.question: 37. Appropriate excisional margin for a 3.5 cm lesion:
items.explanation: An appropriate excisional margin for a 3.5 cm lesion is 2 cm, balancing adequate clearance of malignant tissue while preserving healthy tissue.

items.question: 38. A 5-year-old female patient with a liver abscess associated with the liver fluke underwent partial liver resection. The histopathology showed granulomatous inflammation with necrosis and fibrosis. No evidence of malignant cells or ova were seen. What is the MOST probable etiology?
items.explanation: A liver abscess caused by amebic infection is the most common cause of liver abscess associated with liver fluke infection, characterized by granulomatous inflammation with necrosis and fibrosis. There is no evidence of malignant cells or ova, ruling out parasitic and malignant causes.

items.question: 39. Which statement is TRUE about adjuvant chemotherapy in T1a bladder cancer?
options: Adjuvant chemotherapy offers a 5-year survival benefit
Adjuvant chemotherapy should be given to all patients
Adjuvant chemotherapy is recommended for high-grade T1 tumors
Adjuvant chemotherapy is unnecessary if complete transurethral resection is achieved
Adjuvant chemotherapy is contraindicated in bladder cancer
items.explanation: Adjuvant chemotherapy is recommended for high-grade T1 tumors of the bladder due to the high risk of progression and metastasis. Complete resection alone is often inadequate, and chemotherapy improves disease control.

items.question: 40. Principles of management of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) include all EXCEPT:
options: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed in T1 ≤ 5.5 cm and confined to the mucosa in GISTs
Excision of gastrointestinal stromal tumors with a segmental resection with negative margins
Adjuvant imatinib (Gleevec) in patients with high-risk tumors
Endoscopic biopsy is not indicated prior to surgery
items.explanation: Observation and surveillance alone are insufficient for managing gastrointestinal stromal tumors, as surgical excision with negative margins is required. Laparoscopic or segmental resection is indicated, and adjuvant imatinib improves survival in high-risk patients.

items.question: 41. A 40-year-old premenopausal woman underwent surgery for breast cancer. The final pathology showed vascular invasion and positive lymph nodes. All estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) were both positive (90% of tumor cells). What is the recommended adjuvant therapy?
items.explanation: Patients with breast cancer showing vascular invasion, positive lymph nodes, and positive ER/PR receptors benefit from combined adjuvant chemotherapy and hormonal therapy to reduce recurrence and improve survival.

items.question: 42. Tumor of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin (ulceration or fixation to the chest wall) is classified as which T stage?
items.explanation: T4a stage includes tumors of any size with direct extension to the chest wall (including pectoralis muscles) or to the skin resulting in ulceration or fixation but no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastases.

items.question: 42. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor affecting survival after treatment of colorectal cancer patients?
items.explanation: Analysis of the large perfect cure of patients with colon carcinoma showed that the status of the lymph nodes has consistently remained because the most important prognostic factor.
