items.question: 45. The clinical features which suggest the diagnosis of chronic ulcerative colitis as opposed to Crohn's colitis, include:
options: Suggestive of both Crohn's and ulcerative colitis.
items.explanation: Answer: D. Medicosmos Large Intestine Q25.

items.question: 47. When evaluating a patient for anal cancer, the distal edge of the anal sphincter ring is defined as the:
items.explanation: Anal canal cancer typically consists of squamous, transitional and columnar epithelial cells. The distal end of the anal canal is the inter-sphincteric groove.

items.question: 48. Which of the following is not a generally useful slice for bowel obstruction indication for surgery secondary to colorectal carcinoma:
items.explanation: Endoscopic biopsies are not generally useful since inflammation and granulomas are usually patchy. Transmural inflammation and granulomas on biopsy pathologic specimens are pathognomonic of Crohn's disease.

items.question: What are the main advantages of restorative proctocolectomy with ileal-pouch anal anastomosis as compared to other forms of surgery for ulcerative colitis?
options: Restoration of both nutrition and early anastomotic function
Avoidance of mesenteric venous thrombosis and pancreatic sepsis
Resection segments of grossly involved segments of bowel
items.explanation: Restoration of both nutrition and early anastomotic function after restorative proctocolectomy with ileal-pouch anal anastomosis is a main advantage as compared to other forms of surgery.

items.question: For the patient in question 49, which one of the following statements is most accurate?
options: The main cause of obstruction is small bowel volvulus
Small bowel intussusception is a likely cause
Localised small bowel obstruction is unlikely
items.explanation: Small bowel intussusception is a possible cause of obstruction in this patient and must be considered.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding colorectal anastomotic leaks?
options: Is most commonly caused by colon cancer
Is most commonly caused by anastomotic stricture
Is mostly treated by Hartmann's procedure
Is readily diagnosed by colonoscopy and partial cystectomy for fistula repair
Pretreatment with radiotherapy does not significantly increase the risk
items.explanation: Pretreatment with radiotherapy has little effect on the risk of anastomotic leaks.

items.question: Management of intestinal failure related to inflammatory bowel disease most commonly involves which of the following?
items.explanation: Total parenteral nutrition is the mainstay of management for intestinal failure in inflammatory bowel disease.

items.question: Which of the following statements about pseudomembranous colitis is TRUE?
options: It is caused by Clostridium difficile
It primarily affects the small intestine
items.explanation: Pseudomembranous colitis is an inflammatory condition caused by Clostridium difficile infection.

items.question: Small bowel obstruction in an elderly female without previous abdominal surgeries is most likely caused by:
items.explanation: External hernia is the most common cause of small bowel obstruction in an elderly female without previous abdominal surgeries.

items.question: Adhesions or strictures in an elderly female without previous neoplasm and previous surgery is most likely caused by:
items.explanation: Adhesions or strictures in an elderly female without previous neoplasm and previous surgery is most likely caused by adhesions.

items.question: The single most common abdominal operation in elderly patients is:
items.explanation: Cholecystectomy is the single most common abdominal operation in elderly patients.

items.question: During colonoscopy, a polyp was removed by snare and the pathology revealed colon cancer. What is the next step?
items.explanation: Colon cancer detected at the base of the polyp requires abdominal colectomy, ileostomy is performed to treat it adequately.

items.question: What is the appropriate operative treatment for anorectal prolapse?
items.explanation: Perineal proctosigmoidectomy (Riesen procedure) is an appropriate operative treatment for anorectal prolapse.

items.question: Q9. A 51-year-old patient presents with a basal anal ulcer. Biopsy reveals a chronic granulation tissue with transmural lymphocytic infiltrate and numerous plasma cells. Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural lymphocytic infiltration and non-caseating granulomas, presenting as chronic inflammation in any segment of the gastrointestinal tract including the anus.

items.question: Q10. The distal margin of resection for sigmoid diverticulitis should be:
options: 2 cm distal to the colon inflammation
1 cm distal to the colon inflammation
items.explanation: The distal margin should be taken at the uninvolved distal colon to avoid leaving inflamed or diseased tissue which could cause recurrence or complications.

items.question: Q11. The most common cystic disease of the spleen is:
items.explanation: Pseudocysts are the most common cystic lesions of the spleen, typically resulting from trauma or infarction; they lack an epithelial lining.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding accessory spleen?
options: Accessory spleen is normal, most common supernumerary splenic tissue.
Accessory spleen is often located at splenic hilus and pancreatic tail.
Accessory spleen can cause recurrent pancreatitis.
Accessory spleen can cause idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.
items.explanation: Accessory spleen is not true regarding 'Accessory spleen can cause hypersplenism'.

items.question: Regarding IV injuries of spleen, which of the following management is NOT recommended?
options: Mesh wrapping is recommended for Grade IV injuries.
Nonoperative management for hemodynamically stable patients is preferred.
Splenectomy is preferred to the conventional techniques.
Splenic artery embolization can be utilized.
Grade IV injuries are best managed operatively.
items.explanation: Splenectomy is generally not preferred to the conventional techniques in Grade IV spleen injuries.

items.question: Regarding organisms in lymphadenitis in the neck, the most common organism is
items.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus and group A beta-streptococcus are the most common organisms for lymphadenitis in the neck.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding psoas abscess?
options: Primary psoas abscess is most frequently polymicrobial.
The spinal origin to the right hepatic duct.
Psoas abscess results from tuberculosis of the spine.
Purely pyogenic abscess is secondary to tuberculosis.
Psoas abscess is caused mainly by fungi.
items.explanation: Primary psoas abscess is most frequently polymicrobial due to multiple etiologies.

items.question: 68. If torsion of the testicle is suspected, surgical be so great as to damage even the pelvis, hip, vertebral column and sacrum.
options: Can be delayed 24 hours and limited to the affected side.
Should be immediate and for the affected side only.
Inguinal approach is the ideal one for symptomatic side.
Can be delayed 24 hours and limited to the affected side.
Should be immediate and for the affected side only.
items.explanation: Should be immediate and for the affected side only.

items.question: 69. After renal transplantation patient develops lymph leakage, what is the most common cause ?
items.explanation: Lymphocele

items.question: 70. Prostate specific or which marker is a tumor marker for prostatic cancer?
items.explanation: PSA

items.question: 71. After injury of the testis if torsion is suspected, surgical intervention is accomplished within?
items.explanation: 12 hours

items.question: 72. One week after receiving a cadaver recipient remains oliguric and dialysis safe;
items.explanation: Acute tubular necrosis

items.question: 69. Following are common causes for patients with high voltage electric injury except?
items.explanation: ECG monitoring

items.question: 15. A 60-year-old male with end stage renal failure is scheduled for renal transplant. Which of the following is a contraindication for renal transplant?
options: His age is a contraindication for renal transplant.
Damage to transplanted kidney by anti-glomerulonephritis antibodies.
items.explanation: Anti-glomerulonephritis antibodies is a contraindication to transplantation of transplanted kidney.

items.question: 16. The availability factor in liver grafting is:
options: Donor availability is good for only few hours.
Appropriate storage of organ is important.
Patients are frequently critically ill with multi system failure.
One graft supports less than 70% liver.
items.explanation: Donor availability is good for only few hours.

items.question: 17. The main vascular factor in liver grafting is:
options: Inferior vena cava is most important.
Segment I inferior vena cava is important for end to end anastomosis.
Right portal vein is important for liver transplantation.
Portal vein mostly arises from the main renal vein.
Hepatic veins are contraindicated in anastomosis.
items.explanation: Inferior vena cava is most important for liver grafting.

items.question: 18. The situations where transplantation of kidneys is contraindicated include all except:
options: Renal arteries are contraindication for elective use in transplantation.
items.explanation: Renal arteries are not contraindicated for elective use in transplantation.

items.question: 19. Segmental arteries supplying each separate segment of kidney include:
options: Renal artery and lower segmental arteries.
Segmental arteries arise from the main renal artery.
Segmental arteries are directly from the aorta.
Segmental arteries arise from inferior vena cava.
Segmental arteries arise from the kidney veins.
items.explanation: Segmental arteries arise from the main renal artery.

items.question: 20. A 85-year-old ventilator-dependent male was brought to you and is suspected to have acute rejection. The most reliable test for early detection was reported to be:
items.explanation: Renal biopsy is the most reliable test for early detection of acute rejection.

items.question: 21. The responsive study is not a candidate for early extubation. This means that the course of treatment is most likely due to:
options: Anastomosis of the bedside during the procedure option.
items.explanation: Anastomosis of the bedside during the procedure is the most likely cause.

items.question: While shaving, a 45-year-old teacher notices a marble-sized mass beneath his left ear. The mass is eventually excised and histology showed frequent lymphocyte in parotid tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency
items.explanation: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is also called Warthin's tumor. It occurs mainly in men. The epithelial component is interspersed with lymphoid tissue that shows germinal centers. The most common tumor of the parotid gland is a pleomorphic adenoma, with papillary cystadenoma (although much less frequent) as the second most common tumor. Mikulicz's disease involves chronic inflammation and swelling of the salivary glands, which is benign and usually painless.

items.question: A 43-year-old male develops squamous cell carcinoma of the lip. What is true of this condition?
options: It involves the upper lip in 90% of patients.
It is more common at the lateral commissure than in the middle.
It usually occurs beyond the vermilion border.
It results in cure in about 60% of cases.
items.explanation: If the lesion is treated early, patients will achieve a cure in most cases. The upper lip is involved in 10% of patients.

items.question: A 24-year-old computer technician notes a progressive increase in the size of his left jaw. After x-rays are taken and a biopsy is done, a diagnosis of ameloblastoma is established. What should be the next step in management?
options: Excision of lesions with 1-2 cm of normal mandible
Mandibulectomy with bilateral radical neck dissection
items.explanation: Ameloblastoma is a benign tumor and usually occurs at the junction of the body and ramus of the mandible. Although it is a benign tumor, it recurs if inadequately excised. It is relatively radioresistant. Histologically, odontogenic epithelium is seen in connective tissue stroma with extensive areas of cystic degeneration.

items.question: A 62-year-old man undergoes excision of submandibular gland for cylindroma. He is most likely to have an injury to which of the following?
options: Maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve
Frontozygomatic branch of the facial nerve

items.question: The classical block dissection includes which of the following?
items.explanation: The classic block dissection includes sternocleidomastoid muscle, the external and internal jugular veins, the spinal accessory nerve, the submandibular gland, and the lymphatic tissue of the lateral compartment of the neck. Procedures that preserve muscle, nerve, or vessels are called modified neck dissection.

items.question: A 40-year-old woman is suspected of having a carotid body tumor. Which one of the following is most characteristic of such a tumor?
options: They are more common at sea level.
They arise from structures that respond to changes in blood volume.
They arise from the structures that respond to changes in PO2.
items.explanation: Carotid body tumor is the most common type of paraganglioma in the head and neck region, followed by the glomus jugular tumor. Carotid body tumor grows slowly, rarely metastasizes, and may secrete catecholamines. The tumor usually is supplied by the external carotid artery, and dissection to remove it off the carotid bifurcation may be difficult and cause bleeding. Malignancy occurs in 6% of patients.

items.question: A 33-year-old female noted a discharge from a sinus in the overlying skin below the right angle of the mandible, with previous episodes of fullness and mild pain in this region over the past several years. What is the most likely cause?
items.explanation: Pharyngeal (branchial arch) remnants account for many cysts or fistulas in the lateral neck. The associated tract can be found in various locations. Thyroglossal duct cysts associated with the recent of the thyroid gland are usually midline, extending as high as the base of tongue.

items.question: A 24-year-old male is hit in the left eye with a hard-hit eye drive. He is rushed to the nearest emergency department where CT scan reveals left orbital rim and floor fractures and fluid in the left maxillary sinus. What are physical findings likely to include?
items.explanation: Blowout fractures of the orbit exhibit epistaxis; subcutaneous emphysema and periorbital ecchymosis are also frequently encountered. Treatment of most severe injuries is by surgical repair, often by a lower lid blepharoplasty incision. Enophthalmos, lateral diplopia and blindness do not generally occur.

items.question: A 65-year-old man undergoes cardiac surgery for triple vessel coronary artery disease. What can he anticipate?
options: 95% chance his grafts will occlude after 12 months.
If the internal mammary artery is used as a conduit, patency is increased.
Functional improvement with the saphenous vein graft is better than internal memory artery.
items.explanation: Internal thoracic artery. The internal thoracic artery is the conduit of choice especially for grafting the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Arterial and venous grafts 95% of the time do not occlude after 12. Seventy-five percent of patients under coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) survive 5 years. Mortality is 2% or lower in most centers.

items.question: A 58-year-old man is in cardiogenic shock in the emergency department after sustaining an acute myocardial infarction (MI). An intraaortic balloon pump (IABP) is inserted. Which statement is TRUE about IABP?
options: The balloon increases coronary perfusion during diastole.
The balloon increases coronary perfusion during systole.
The balloon is inflated in systole and diastole.
The pump must be removed after 24 hours.
items.explanation: IABP increases coronary perfusion during diastole. The IABP inflates during diastole and propels blood into the coronary circulation. IABP decreases peripheral resistance and decreases afterload on the heart. The IABP can stay in the patient for longer than 24 hours.

items.question: Following recovery from an acute MI, a 44-year-old embryology lecturer is discharged from the hospital with what instructions?
options: Angiogram every 3 months to evaluate the degree of atherosclerosis
items.explanation: Following recovery from an acute MI, patients are usually instructed to take nitroglycerin three times a day as part of their medical management.

items.question: 91. Sudden onset of breath, chest pain and fever. A contrast study should?
options: Stop oral intake, insert a chest tube and begin high doses of antibiotics
Insert a bronchoscopic tube and begin high dose antibiotics
Perform immediate left thoracotomy and repair the tube damage
Do pleural washing for cytology to diagnose a retained foreign body
items.explanation: Stop all ingestion of food, insert chest tube and begin high doses of antibiotics.

items.question: 92. A 75-year-old female student was found to have a large anterior mediastinal mass on chest X-ray for a persistent cough on the right side. Which is the best next initial investigation?
options: Needle biopsy through chest wall, under fluoroscopic guidance
CT scan of chest and upper abdomen
items.explanation: Transthoracic needle biopsy is contraindicated in anterior mediastinal mass due to vascular structures. CT scan helps in localization and staging. Bronchoscopy is usually done through median sternotomy. Histologic diagnosis is done usually through mediastinoscopy. Transthoracic biopsy is contraindicated due to high risk of vascular injury.

items.question: 93. A young male is shot at the level of the fifth intercostal space left parasternal join. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, with increased jugular venous pressure and diminished heart sounds. The first step should be?
options: Insert a chest tube and observe for drainage
items.explanation: The presentation is severe pneumococcal infection when removed in..

items.question: 98. The most serious complication of neglected choledochal cyst is :
items.explanation: Biliary cysts (BC) are rare dilatations of different parts of a biliary tree. They occur most frequently in Asians and infants, not in Westerners. Their most important problem for long-term follow-up is the development of cholangiocarcinoma complicating biliary cysts. They are managed depending on the BC type.

items.question: 99. Commonest complication of laparoscopic band procedure is :
items.explanation: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding has been the commonest problem associated with band surgery. The studies showed the frequency of prolapse and erosion was 4.7% and 5.0% respectively. The most common early and late complications is band prolapse (25%) and band erosion (15%) respectively.

items.question: 100. Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is indicated for all of the patients except :
items.explanation: Laparoscopic adrenal surgery is safe and definitive for hormonally active tumors, incidental tumors, benign tumors, and tumors < 10 cm. It is contraindicated in hyperplasia, pregnancy, and very large tumors. Thus, hyperplasia and pregnancy are exceptions.

items.question: Which of the following is the 1st presentation of a rectus sheath hematoma?
options: Rigidity of the abdominal wall m3.
Pain and discoloration of the skin.
items.explanation:
Answer: A (Schwartz ABSITE Joe 283)
Hematoma of the rectus sheath is a non-traumatizing process within the rectus sheath that may occur sporadically or be precipitated by coughing, sneezing, or trauma. They usually begin as vague abdominal tenderness signs, later hematoma and muscle can result in a rectus sheath hematoma that may be confused with acute abdominal process  as many of the features overlap (fever, leukocytosis, abdominal tenderness referred to as the 'seat belt sign,' the anterior abdominal wall mass, and guarding). The acute abdomen signs usually do not occur, but the hematoma is immediately found to have blunt small bowel injury.

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding diagnosis of blunt abdominal trauma is true?
options: CT, US and DPI are more helpful than X Ray.
Plain films is the most important test.
D Tilt chest X-ray hemation is usually apparent on initial upright chest X-ray.
CT is diagnostically more useful usually than either the left or right side of the diaphragm.
Diaphragmatic viscus into hemoracic tube suggests hemation of the thoracic cavity.
items.explanation:
Answer: A
Difficult diagnosis of blunt abdominal trauma. The earliest sign of diaphragmatic injury may be the development of atelectasis, followed by elevation of the hemidiaphragm on an upright chest projection. However, the initial chest X-ray may be within normal limits or reveal other associated injuries. CT chest scanning is more sensitive and specific than other tests for detection of diaphragmatic injury.

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding diaphragm traumatic injury is MOST correct?
options: Diaphragmatic rupture and injury are usually underestimated on initial chest x-ray.
The diagnosis of diaphragmatic injury is most often missed on initial x-ray.
The typical radiographic feature of a patient with diaphragmatic rupture is an elevated ipsilateral hemidiaphragm.
The best diagnosis is usually helpul in diagnosis a sudden abdominal viscera into the chest tube suggests hemation of the thoracic cavity.
Assessment of diaphragmatic integrity is a critical issue.
items.explanation:
Answer: B. Pretest Q 2017
Chest x-ray of diaphragmatic injury may be normal during the initial evaluation of the patient. Diaphragmatic rupture injury diagnosis is frequently missed initially and made at the time of surgery or autopsy.

items.question: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and CT Scan clarify diagnostic of?
options: The presence of bridging veins or pleural fluid.
items.explanation:
Answer: A
MRI and CT Scan clarify diagnosis and extent of injury of the diaphragm.

items.question: In a repair of a femoral hernia, the structure is most likely to be injured is:
items.explanation: Careful attention to this structure is essential. What is the structure? The femoral vein lies immediately posterior to the femoral canal.

items.question: Which of the following statements about diaphragmatic hernia is correct?
options: Women present at a younger age than men
Acquired hernias account for the majority of cases
Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
Morgagni hernias make up 50% of all diaphragmatic hernias
Incidence of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is 1:5000
items.explanation: Incidence of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is 1:5000. Congenital diaphragmatic hernias are mostly prenatally diagnosed, but exact etiology is unknown. The most common diaphragmatic hernia is left posterolateral defect, present in 85% of cases and known as Bochdalek hernia. Morgagni hernias account for only 2% of cases.

items.question: Previously: 8 months old infant is admitted to hospital with 3 days history of intermittent low grade fever, loose motions, and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals tender right upper quadrant mass. The most likely diagnosis is
items.explanation: Acute intussusception is telescoping of one portion of the intestine into an adjacent segment. The initial symptoms are sometimes intestinal ischemia. The initial symptom is usually crampy abdominal pain, vomiting, and sometimes bloody mucoid stools on rectal exam with palpable sausage-shaped mass in right upper quadrant. Usually it occurs between 6 months and 2 years.

items.question: Two months old child presents with left sided abdominal mass, described as sausage-shaped. The most likely diagnosis is
items.explanation: Congenital mesoblastic nephroma is may present with palpable left upper quadrant mass in infants. It is the most common renal tumor in infancy. It is cured by surgery without chemotherapy and radiotherapy in most cases.

items.question: Child presents with a hard non-tender palpable abdominal mass in right lumbar region, weight loss, fever, pallor and multiple skin petechiae. Histopathological diagnosis is
items.explanation: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood. It presents as a hard mass usually in the abdomen with systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, pallor and skin petechiae due to bone marrow involvement.

items.question: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is
options: Most common thyroid tumor in children and adults
items.explanation: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer, arises in all age groups including children, is associated with radiation exposure, especially in childhood, and has an excellent prognosis compared to other thyroid cancers.

items.question: A 14-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Examination reveals a mildly tender palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. What is the recommended management?
items.explanation: The presence of a tender palpable mass and findings suggest an acute abdomen requiring surgical exploration to prevent testicular torsion or necrosis.

items.question: In previously vomiting children with a distended cecum on plain abdominal x-ray, which of the following is the most common diagnosis?
items.explanation: Intussusception is the most common cause of a distended cecum in children presenting with vomiting and abdominal pain.

items.question: Which type of intestinal atresia is characterized by obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater found in infants with a history of normal feeding and bilious vomiting during the first few weeks of life?
items.explanation: Type IIIb atresia (apple peel or Christmas tree deformity) causes obstruction distal to the ampulla and presents with bilious vomiting in the first weeks of life.

items.question: In patients with a suspected biliary atresia, which investigation is the most important for confirming the diagnosis?
items.explanation: Cholangiogram is considered the gold standard investigation to confirm biliary atresia by demonstrating absence of bile ducts.

items.question: 18. An 8-year-old boy presented with a pathological fracture of the left femur. He was noted to have abdominal distension, loss of weight and a persistent cough over a three-month period. Additional lytic lesions were seen in the vertebral bodies and in the pelvis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
items.explanation: Surgery Essence5, P103: Lung metastasis are rare in neuroblastoma. Metastasis is present in 60-70% of patients at the diagnosis. Common sites of metastasis: Long bones (MC), Liver, Lymph nodes and Skin. Encasement of abdominal aorta and IVC by tumor is common. Some neuroblastomas are sharply demarcated with a pseudocapsule but others are far more infiltrative and invade surrounding strictures including the kidney, renal vein, IVC, and envelop the aorta.

items.question: 19. A 7 years old boy presents with recurrent pneumonia. Culture showed Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Mother confirms that he had meconium ileus in the neonatal period. Which of the following is the most likely finding in this boy?
items.explanation: Cystic fibrosis

items.question: 20. The BEST diagnostic modality for retroperitoneal injuries is:
items.explanation: B&L 26e p352: Injury to the retroperitoneum is often difficult to diagnose, especially in the presence of other injuries. Physical signs may be masked. Intraperitoneal diagnostic peritoneal lavage (ultrasound and diagnostic peritoneal lavage) may be helpful. The best diagnostic modality is the computed tomography scan, but this requires a physiologically stable patient. The retroperitoneum is divided into three zones.

items.question: Symptoms from a retroperitoneal sarcoma are usually produced by
items.explanation: Retroperitoneal sarcomas grow along fascial planes and envelop rather than invade retroperitoneal organs. Lymph node metastases are unusual. The tumor does not usually grow rapidly enough to outgrow its blood supply, and major hemorrhage into the tumor mass is uncommon.

items.question: Abdominal free fluid will collect in the lowest part of the peritoneal cavity. At operation with the patient supine, in which of the following will the fluid collect first?
items.explanation: The hepatorenal pouch lies between the right lobe of the liver and right kidney. It forms the lowest part of the peritoneal cavity, apart from the pelvis, in the supine abdomen and communicates freely with the lesser sac and the right paracolic gutter. So, peritoneal fluid or pus can easily accumulate in the hepatorenal pouch. The space is closed superiorly by the inferior coronary ligament and so does not directly communicate with the right subphrenic space.

items.question: The FIRST-choice treatment for chylous ascites due to intraabdominal trauma is:
options: Exploratory laparotomy and suturing of the tear
Ligation of the thoracic duct in the abdomen
Anastomosis of the thoracic duct to the IVC
items.explanation: There are few data on optimal management of patients with chylous ascites. The general approach is to focus on evaluating and treating the underlying causes, especially for patients with infectious, inflammatory, or hemodynamic etiologies for this condition. Total parenteral nutrition along with somatostatin can relieve symptoms and close the fistula in patients with chylous ascites rapidly. Overall, two thirds of patients will respond to conservative therapy, but one third will require surgical repair.

items.question: Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm a diagnosis of tuberculous peritonitis?
options: CT of the abdomen and pelvis
items.explanation: Tuberculous peritonitis is most commonly associated with individuals with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome; however, it can also occur in the setting of cirrhosis (especially alcoholic) and chronic renal failure. Most cases result from reactivation of latent peritoneal disease in patients with previous pulmonary TB. Typical complaints include abdominal distention from ascites and generalized abdominal discomfort. Constitutional symptoms including fever, night sweats, anorexia, and malaise, may also be present. Most patients have a positive PPD skin test. In the absence of cirrhosis, the ascites has a low serum-ascites albumin gradient, high glucose, high protein, and high fluid WBCs, mainly lymphocytes. Abdominal ultrasound may show echogenic material within the ascites. Diagnostic laparoscopy and peritoneal biopsy are the most appropriate to confirm diagnosis.

items.question: 26. A 60-year-old man is found to have a 6-cm mass in a retroperitoneum. The most likely diagnosis is
items.explanation: Liposarcomas are the commonest retroperitoneal mass in adults.

items.question: 27. Which of the following statements about idiopathic (primary) retroperitoneal fibrosis is TRUE?
options: It occurs most frequently in marines
The most common presentation is as asymptomatic
Malignant change is the most common complication of primary retroperitoneal fibrosis
Surgical biopsy under fluoroscopic control is the best diagnostic investigation
A corticosteroid is an important role in treatment of idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
items.explanation: Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis may occur frequently. Surgical biopsy in retroperitoneal fibrosis is rarely required. The initial approach is medical management with corticosteroids, is important in treatment.

items.question: 28. Which of the following is TRUE regarding spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP)?
options: It typically presents with abdominal pain, and is caused by abdominal trauma
It is a complication in cirrhotics with ascites
Neutrophil concentrations with abdominal pain are not diagnostic
Patients typically have a negative ascitic fluid culture
Gram stain reveals an ovarian mass. The most likely diagnosis
items.explanation: SBP is a common complication in cirrhotic ascites, typically characterized by an infection in ascitic fluid with neutrophil predominance, frequently presenting with abdominal pain. Neutrophil count (>250 cells/mm3) is diagnostic, even if culture is negative due to prior antibiotics.

items.question: 29. Which statement is TRUE regarding ascites in patients with ascitic fluid with low gradient and high protein?
options: It is indicative of tuberculous peritonitis
items.explanation: Low Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG <1.1 g/dL) and high protein (>2.5 g/dL) are typically seen in cases such as peritoneal carcinomatosis, tuberculosis, and pancreatic ascites.

items.question: 31. Impairment of the following conditions is the enteral route of feeding contraindicated?
items.explanation: Upper gastrointestinal obstruction.

items.question: 32. Which of the following has been associated with glucose intolerance and peripheral neuropathy?
items.explanation: Selenium.

items.question: Which of the following is most commonly isolated by the culture in patients with Clostridium difficile-associated pseudomembranous colitis?
options: Most commonly isolated by culture is C. perfringens
Most commonly isolated by culture is C. septicum
Most commonly isolated by culture is C. difficile
Most commonly isolated by culture is C. histolyticum
Most commonly isolated by culture is C. tetani
items.explanation: Pseudomembranous colitis is associated with C. difficile, a toxin-producing anaerobe that can colonize the colon following antibiotic use and cause diarrhea.

items.question: Which is TRUE regarding enteral feeding?
options: Increased risk of bacterial translocation is a contraindication
Maintains the integrity of the mucosal barrier function
May be safely administered to patients with intestinal obstruction
Is the first choice of feeding for critically ill patients
items.explanation: Enteral feeding maintains the integrity of the mucosal barrier function, preventing bacterial translocation and preserving gut-associated lymphoid tissue.

items.question: The most common cause of iron deficiency anemia in patients with inflammatory bowel disease is?
items.explanation: Chronic GI blood loss is the most common cause of iron deficiency anemia in inflammatory bowel disease due to mucosal ulceration and bleeding.

items.question: An 18-year-old male who undergoes extensive small bowel resection after a gunshot wound to abdomen develops jaundice and abnormal liver function tests. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
items.explanation: TPN is indicated in patients with extensive small bowel resection to prevent malnutrition and manage intestinal failure, but it can lead to liver dysfunction requiring careful management.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding TPN (total parenteral nutrition)?
options: Suitable for long-term support of bowel dysfunction
Can be given through a peripheral vein safely
Prevent fatty liver if used for prolonged periods
items.explanation: TPN solutions are hyperosmolar and require central venous access for safe administration; peripheral vein administration is not suitable for long-term TPN.

items.question: Which one of the following gut hormones is responsible for promoting appetite? (Ghrelin)
items.explanation: Most commonly is administered via large central veins

items.question: A 54-year-old woman with a low rectal cancer undergoes challenging procedure that lasts 19 hours. Which of the following is a reliable early indicator of compartment syndrome in the lower extremities?
items.explanation: Hopkins ABSITE 2e p257

items.question: Which of the following nutritional factors has been shown to BEST predict long term morbidity and/or mortality after cessation of TPN?
options: Percent of body weight gain in the previous months
Total protein intake <40% of consumed calories
items.explanation: Serum albumin has been shown to best predict long-term mortality

items.question: Which of the following is NOT a clinical consequence of absolute nutrient deficiency?
items.explanation: Question not fully clear; Hypoglycemia is not typical clinical consequence of absolute nutrient deficiency

items.question: A victim of blunt abdominal trauma who undergoes a partial splenectomy during surgery, he receives twelve units of packed blood cells and multiple sites mod surgical injections regarding the blood volume most likely TRUE?
options: The patient is most likely TRU?
Hypoproteinemia is secondary to hepatic insufficiency
The coagulation deficiency of clotting factors from the massive blood transfusion
The treatment is oral vitamin. K
items.explanation: Langes inference

items.question: A cystic patient with dysmotility requires an urgent transfusion due to anemia. A single unit of this transfusion requires an agent to be added to minimize the risk of lled trg due to surgery?
options: A hyperconcentrate of this transfusion meanl plasma
items.explanation: The risk of transfusion-related complications can be minimized by using erythrocyte suspension only for patients requiring urgent transfusion due to anemia.

items.question: The lithothrix patient with abnormal hemostatic studies who is ,a candidate of elective surgery in the absence of active bleeding, the careful perioperative and annual transfusion replacement planned to minimize the risk of
options: Frozen plasma is planned to minimize the risk of 12001819
Fresh plasma is planned to minimize the risk of 12001618
Specific recovery planning of this transfusion 120716186
Frozen plasma is planned to minimize the risk of fibrynolisis
items.explanation: Frozen plasma is planned perioperatively to minimize the risk of bleeding in patients with abnormal hemostatic studies undergoing elective surgery.

items.question: A 63-year-old man is going to undergo liver biopsy. Which one of the following essential preoperative investigations is important?
options: Liver biopsy technique of this procedures
items.explanation: Screening for viral hepatitis is essential before invasive procedures such as liver biopsy to prevent transmission of infectious diseases.

items.question: A patient develops wound erythema, swelling and discharge 3 days after an otherwise uneventful abdominal hysterectomy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Pseudomembranous colitis is a common cause of wound infection after abdominal surgery, characterized by severe diarrhea and signs of colitis.

items.question: In the management of a patient who recently had an episode of hemobilirubin due to severe hemolytic anemia, what is the best treatment for the acute hemolytic episode?
items.explanation: Fluid and alkalinizing are recommended as long as the patient is not in hemolysis state or urinary output is adequate.

items.question: Which of the following statements about polymyxin B is true?

It is useful for treatment of systemic infections only.
It is used for prophylaxis in surgical wound infections.
It has poor activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

items.question: Used to treat exposure to benzalkonium chloride, which one of these agents is recommended?

items.question: In hyperkalemia, what is the preferred initial therapy?
items.explanation: Intravenous calcium gluconate is preferred to antagonize cardiac effects of hyperkalemia.

items.question: Which one of the following findings is most consistent with severe magnesium deficiency?
items.explanation: Severe magnesium deficiency causes severe neuromuscular hyperexcitability, which is characterized by hyperreflexia, tetany, and seizures. Depression, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest are not classical features of severe magnesium deficiency.

items.question: The combination of ascites, pleural effusion, low serum albumin (1.3–2.1 g/dL), and an elevated intra-abdominal pressure is known as:
items.explanation: Abdominal compartment syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by increased intra-abdominal pressure, tense ascites, and associated pleural effusions, leading to organ dysfunction.

items.question: A 53-year-old man is assisted from a cardiopulmonary arrest. He is tachycardic with a blood pressure of 90/40 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 45/min, and sluggish pupillary light reflexes. items.explanation: Signs of right ventricular dilation and hypokinesia with hypotension suggest a massive pulmonary embolism causing obstructive shock.

items.question: A 12-year-old boy who was 3rd floor falls and hit the head. Injury increased gut motility and response to surgery. As compared to parental nutrition, which of the following would NOT be increased with enteral nutrition?
items.explanation: Enteral nutrition maintains gut integrity and motility and promotes immune functions. It does not cause expanded extracellular fluid volume, which is more likely with overhydration.

items.question: A 36-year-old diabetic woman developed metabolic encephalopathy. Some causes of metabolic encephalopathy are shock, sepsis, hyponatremia, etc. A blood gas analysis from serum values of which of the following can be calculated?
items.explanation: Arterial blood gases (ABGs) analysis includes measurement of pH, partial pressure of oxygen (pO2), partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2), and bicarbonate (HCO3-). These values are essential to assess metabolic and respiratory components of acid-base balance.

items.question: Mean pulmonary occlusion (wedge) pressure is an indicator of?
items.explanation: Mean pulmonary occlusion (wedge) pressure (PAWP) provides an indirect measurement of left atrial pressure. These pressures can be measured using a balloon-tipped catheter that is inserted into the pulmonary artery and wedged in a small pulmonary artery branch.

items.question: Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) means pulmonary occlusion (wedge) pressure is an indicator of?
items.explanation: Pulmonary occlusion (wedge) pressure represents an indirect measure of left atrial pressure, reflecting left heart function, not systemic vascular resistance or mean arterial pressure.

items.question: Neurogenic Shock refers to?
options: A condition characterized by stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system within the spinal cord with pain, exposure to unpleasant sensory stimuli like pinching
A state involving uncontrolled sympathetic activity in the spinal cord leading to hypertension
Shock due to injury of the spinal cord leading to loss of sympathetic tone, causing hypotension and bradycardia
Shock caused by infection leading to low blood pressure
Shock caused by severe blood loss
items.explanation: Neurogenic shock is due to spinal cord injury resulting in loss of sympathetic tone leading to hypotension and bradycardia, commonly occurring above the level of T4.

items.question: 59. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of acute pulmonary aspergillosis?

items.question: 61. A 54-year-old man sees you because of a 6-week history of dyspnea. items.question: 63. In adult tuberculosis patients, which of the following fluoroquinolones is recommended as part of the treatment regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis?

items.question: 64. The agent most effective in treating hydrofluoric acid burns is:

items.question: 65. What is the central zone of a burn called?
items.explanation: Following a burn injury, three different zones of tissue injury develop: a zone of coagulation, a zone of stasis, and a zone of hyperemia (Fig. 33-1). The zone of coagulation is the most severely injured zone with irreversible cell destruction and ischemia. Adequate tissue perfusion in this zone cannot be restored.

items.question: Which of the following structures is NOT affected by Fournier gangrene?

items.question: During tissue expansion, what happens to the skin over the tissue expander?

items.question: Improved functional and cosmetic outcomes can be best obtained after tissue expansion by which of the following?
options: Delayed transplant of the expanded skin
Any of the above options if performed during the first two weeks
items.explanation: Full-thickness skin grafts contain the epidermis and dermis and have better characteristics in terms of color match, thickness, and less contraction, leading to improved functional and cosmetic outcomes.

items.question: A 28-year-old man presents with a gunshot wound just above his right elbow. The entrance wound is small, and he appears excited. The first step in the management is a
items.explanation: Absent radial, ulnar, and brachial pulses, a hard and swollen right forearm, and a cool hand point to vascular injury. Proximal ligation is not beneficial; if there is revelation of vascular injury, the brachial artery should be repaired or reconstructed. Passive arm motion of the wrist and elbow is important. The ABCs should be addressed first, massive hemorrhage controlled, and airway and breathing adequately maintained.

items.question: A 25-year-old man presents with an on-duty head injury (GCS 14/15). CT scan shows multiple small cortical contusions in the left temporal and parietal lobes. Which of the following is the best initial management option?
items.explanation: Blunt trauma with mild head injury is best managed conservatively unless deterioration occurs. Observation is appropriate if there is no mass effect or significant neurological deficit.

items.question: Abdominal trauma is classified as penetrating or blunt. Which of the following is true regarding abdominal injuries?
options: Penetrating trauma has a lower mortality rate than blunt trauma
Blunt trauma requires liberal use of laparotomy
Abdominal compartment syndrome is common in penetrating trauma
Wound contamination is more in penetrating trauma
Blunt trauma is never associated with vascular injury
items.explanation: Penetrating trauma usually results in contaminated wounds due to the passage of foreign material and bacterial flora. Blunt trauma has a higher risk of missed injuries and may require imaging or surgical exploration depending on clinical presentation.

items.question: Which of the following conditions is most likely to follow severe blunt abdominal injury?
items.explanation: Stress-induced catecholamine release causes a decrease in insulin secretion. Therefore, there is a significant drop in insulin levels shortly thereafter.

items.question: Optimal surgical management of spleen in blunt abdominal trauma is, EXCEPT:

Vascular injuries are easy to control
Primary repair is recommended in many cases

items.question: A 25-year-old woman arrives in the ER complaining of severe left upper abdomen pain following a fall from 6th floor. Breath sounds are markedly diminished on the left side. Which case is a subsequent nephrectomy can be performed?

items.question: 81. In the setting of trauma, ligation is BEST in all the following vessels EXCEPT
items.explanation: Suprarenal IVC. Ligations at the suprarenal inferior vena cava have a high risk of death and therefore ligation is not recommended there; other vessels listed are more tolerant to ligation in trauma.

items.question: Which of the following is true regarding compartment syndrome?

The soleus muscle does not need to be detached from the tibia to decompress the deep posterior compartment, and compartment syndrome does occur in the buttocks.

items.question: A 17-year-old man sustains a single gunshot wound to the left tibia in the emergency room. He is noted to have a pulse palpable distal to the injury. items.question: An unrestrained 45-year-old female involved in a rapid decelerating motor vehicle collision arrives hemodynamically stable. Paramedics noted a severely bent steering wheel. Initial primary survey reveals no abnormalities. A chest radiograph is performed, revealing a questionable widened mediastinum. There is a high index of suspicion of a possible thoracic aortic injury. The BEST method to diagnose this major vascular injury is
items.explanation: The thoracic aorta is particularly susceptible to injury from blunt trauma. These injuries usually involve proximal descending aorta (54-65% cases), but often involve other segments such as the ascending aorta or transverse aortic arch, and mid or distal descending thoracic aorta. The typical injury is seen when the mechanism of injury is rapid deceleration, resulting in differential forces on the proximal descending aorta between fixed and more mobile portions (Rogers et al., 1996). The most common site of injury is just beyond the ligamentum arteriosum. Blunt aortic injuries may be partial thickness, histologically similar to an intimal tear in aortic dissection, or full thickness and therefore equivalent to ruptured aortic aneurysm, which is contained by surrounding tissues (Williams et al., 1994). The hallmark radiographic sign is a widened mediastinum seen on chest radiograph, related to advential hematoma. Other findings include obliteration of the aortic knob, deviation of the trachea to the right, depression of the left mainstem bronchus, obliteration of the space between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, widened paratracheal stripe, presence of a pleural or apical cap. When the initial chest x-ray demonstrates findings suggestive of a mediastinal hematoma some clinicians require additional screening by CT scan to delineate changes seen on chest radiography and to substantiate a request for a diagnostic arteriogram. The gold standard for the diagnosis, however, remains arterial angiography. It allows precise localization of the injury and provides information regarding vascular anatomy and other factors that profoundly influence operative strategy (Moore, Feliciano, and Mattox, 2004). Transesophageal echocardiographic evaluation (TEE) contains numerous poorly visualized areas of the aorta, thus a negative TEE does not rule out an aortic injury (Horton et al., 2000). Initial treatment involves permitting moderate hypotension (SBP 80-100 mmHg) and limiting fluid administration until operative control is achieved. Currently, it is difficult to make substantiated recommendations regarding the use of beta-blockers in patients with suspected or proven blunt aortic injury. While retrospective studies suggest that it is safe, no prospective studies have demonstrated either safety or

items.question: A patient is taken to the operating room after a failed attempt at nonoperative management for a splenic laceration. The surgeon enters the peritoneum, packs all four quadrants, and notes on initial survey that there is active bleeding from the left upper quadrant. What is the first step in mobilizing the spleen?
options: Clamp and tie of the short gastric vessels
Mobilize the spleen and tail of the pancreas from lateral to medial
Divide the splenorenal and splenophrenic ligaments
Mass clamping of the hilum of the spleen
items.explanation: The mobilization of the spleen is performed in a stepwise approach to avoid further injury and provide improved visualization of the left hemidiaphragm, left kidney, and posterior distal pancreas and spleen (see Fig. 8-23). The first step is to divide the splenorenal and splenophrenic ligaments initially by sharp dissection and continue with sharp and blunt dissection. Once these lateral attachments are divided, mobilizing the spleen and tail of the pancreas medially is the next step. The two structures should be moved as a unit to avoid any injuries to either structure. The next step is to clamp and tie of the short gastric vessels. Avoid dividing these vessels with only scissors or Bovie electrocautery because of the risk of delayed bleeding. The last step is to divide the splenocolic ligament. If bleeding is encountered during removal of the spleen, digital compression is preferred. Mass clamping of the hilum should be reserved for instances of extreme hemorrhage because of the increased risk for damage of the tail of the pancreas during this maneuver.

items.question: A 41-year-old male is shot in the abdomen multiple times undergoes an extensive exploratory laparotomy with multiple bowel resections. Following surgery, he is taken to the ICU for further resuscitation. Which of the following signs would not be consistent with the development of an abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS)?
items.explanation: ACS is the increase of intraabdominal pressure seen in a variety of clinical situations including abdominal trauma and severe sepsis. ACS leads to difficulties with ventilation, hypoxia, and renal failure (Moore, Feliciano, and Mattox, 2004). Leaving the fascia open prevents ACS in high-risk patients. These include patients with extensive intraabdominal injuries, prolonged surgical intervention, and massive resuscitation efforts. Placing catheters into the bladder, stomach, or inferior vena cava makes indirect measurements of intraabdominal pressures. Based on these measurements, recommendations regarding management have been proposed.

items.question: A 22-year-old man involved in a motor vehicle accident is found to have a thoracic spine fracture (T6) and paraplegia. The patient is hypotensive with a systolic BP of 70 mmHg, is bradycardic with a pulse of 48/m, and breathing comfortably. Which of the following would the most appropriate initial treatment?
options: Steroid administration within 24 hours of the injury
items.explanation: Neurogenic shock refers to a condition characterized by hypotension and bradycardia that results from the interruption of the sympathetic nervous system pathways within the spinal cord. Common causes include sensory stimulation, such as severe pain, exposure to unpleasant events or sights, high spinal anesthesia, and traumatic spinal cord injury. Clinical characteristics include a BP that is often low, as in other forms of shock. However, the pulse rate is usually slower than normal, and the skin is flushed, warm, and dry. CO is reduced secondary to decreased blood return to the heart because of the increased capacitance of the arterioles and venules. Since the heart receives sympathetic input, there is a difference between injuries above and below T4. The former depresses cardiac function and decreases venous return. The bradycardia is caused by sympathectomy of the spinal injury above the level of T4 with no capacity for compensatory tachycardia. Treatment of neurogenic shock secondary to spinal cord injury is usually more complicated not only because of more prolonged hypotension but also because of the presence of coincident hypovolemic shock resulting from associated injuries. Such patients often require ventilatory support as a result of decreased spontaneous respiration and loss of the accessory muscles for breathing. Aggressive fluid therapy should be instituted early under continuous cardiovascular monitoring. Persistent hypotension necessitates recognition of possible hemorrhagic shock, and a vasopressor such as ephedrine or phenylephrine may be needed. If the injury is below T4, a pure α-agonist may aggravate the reflex bradycardia. Thus a drug with mixed chronotropic and inotropic effects (e.g., norepinephrine or dopamine) is preferred. A nasogastric tube should be inserted because gastric atony, dilation, and hypersecretion develop in these patients. Treatment of milder forms of neurogenic shock consists of removing the nociceptive stimulus. Neurogenic shock resulting from high spinal anesthesia can usually be treated with a vasopressor such as ephedrine or phenylephrine, each of which increases CO by direct effects on the heart and by increasing peripheral vasoconstriction. Although the administration of steroids remains controversial, their usefulness for blunt spinal cord injury has been suggested when they are given within 8 h of injury and their administration is extended for 48 h.

They represent disruption of drainage into the gallbladder and require reoperation
Usually seen after cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis

items.question: A 7-year old woman is found to have psoriasic secretion from her nose. CT shows pansinusitis and subcutaneous edema, chest X-ray shows multiple cavitary nodules and mild pleural effusion. Which one of the following is TRUE about diagnosis?

The incidence of endocarditis is high in this disease
Antibody and antibody dependent cell cytotoxicity are mediators

Mucosal biopsy should be reserved for cases larger than 4cm

items.question: A 30-year-old man presents with a painless neck mass persisting for 3 months. He is a nonsmoker and has no history of tuberculosis or other systemic diseases. Physical examination reveals a soft, mobile, non-tender 3 cm enlarged lymph node in the left cervical region without overlying inflammation. items.explanation: Answer: C. Kikuchi disease is a necrotizing histiocytic lymphadenitis characterized by a self-limited course, often seen in young adults with persistent painful lymphadenopathy and mild systemic symptoms. It is diagnosed by lymph node biopsy showing necrotizing areas without granulomas.

items.question: A 34-year-old man developed a month history of fever, productive cough and pleuritic chest pain. Fascial plane block on the anterior chest wall

items.question: A 35-year-old alcoholic with end-stage liver disease was managed for cholestatic jaundice. His bilirubin was 12 mg/dL. He had shown no clinical evidence of cholangitis. He was admitted to the hospital 3 times for bleeding esophageal varices previously. He undergoes ERCP. Which of the following is the best management option?
items.explanation: Answer: c. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement is the treatment of choice for cholestasis and cholangitis in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis and cholangiocarcinoma, as surgery is often contraindicated in end-stage liver disease.

items.question: A 42-year-old asymptomatic woman is incidentally found to have an echogenic lesion in the head of the pancreas. Serum CA 19-9 level is normal and ultrasound shows a cystic lesion. CT scan reveals a 3 cm multilocular cyst. What is the best next step?
items.explanation: Answer: c. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) with fine needle aspiration (FNA) is used for characterization of cystic pancreatic lesions to distinguish between benign and malignant lesions.

items.question: A 49-year-old woman with evidence of cirrhosis develops an ultrasound finding of hypoechoic lesions in the gallbladder. What is the best management option?
items.explanation: Answer: e. Patients with suspected gallbladder polyps less than 10 mm size, and no features suspicious of malignancy should be observed with serial ultrasounds. Immediate surgery is indicated if the lesion increases in size or presents with other suspicious features.

items.question: A 50-year-old man who is symptomatic is incidentally noted on CT scan to have a 3-cm lesion in the periphery of the right liver lobe. The lesion has central scar characteristics on imaging and a central scar suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). The RECOMMENDED next step of this lesion is?
items.explanation: Right hepatectomy is recommended for a symptomatic lesion with central scar characteristics suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

items.question: A 35-year-old man sustained a gunshot wound to the right upper quadrant with complete transection of the common bile duct with significant tissue loss was found. The optimal management for this patient's injury is the following?
items.explanation: Roux-en-y choledochojejunostomy is the optimal management for complete transection of the common bile duct with significant tissue loss.

items.question: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is indicated in all the following EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Liver failure is a contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

items.question: Which of the following is the most severe coronary artery disease and brain metastases from lung cancer in a 50-year-old woman with a history of renal failure?
items.explanation: Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is indicated despite severe systemic conditions.

items.question: 73. A 35-year-old man who is symptomatic is incidentally found to have a cystic lesion in the right lobe of the liver. The lesion enhances on the arterial phase and slowly washes out on delayed phases with no pancreatic or biliary communication. What is the diagnosis?
items.explanation: Biliary cystadenoma enhances on the arterial phase and slowly washes out on delayed phases and has no communication with the pancreatic or biliary tree.

items.question: 74. A female who is 4 cm in size is incidentally noted primary noncystic hepatic mass which is hypodense on CT. What is the best approach for this lesion?
options: Radiofrequency ablation of the liver lesion
items.explanation: Primary noncystic hepatic mass which is less than 5 cm and incidentally noted does not require further treatment.

items.question: 75. A 53-year-old man sustained an injury to the right upper quadrant in operating room after liver injury was clinically suspected but no active bleeding or bile was found. The optimal management of this patient is:
items.explanation: Choledochojejunostomy is the optimal management of bile duct injury in the right upper quadrant.

items.question: 76. Which of the following is the best imaging modality to differentiate focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) from adenoma?
items.explanation: MRI with gadolinium is the recommended imaging modality to differentiate FNH from adenoma.

items.question: 77. A 35-year-old man presents with significant past medical history of amenorrhea, breast tenderness, and liver mass. CT scan shows an irregular lesion involving the right lobe of the liver. Definite diagnosis can be made by:
items.explanation: Definite diagnosis of hepatic adenoma requires tissue diagnosis by biopsy.

items.question: 78. A 43-year-old man has multiple enhancing liver lesions with history of oral contraceptive use. The patient also suffers from anorexia, nausea, and notable weight loss. The lesion involvement has replaced most of a lobe of the liver. The best course of action is:
options: Stop oral contraceptive pills and serial CT scans
items.explanation: Hepatic adenomas associated with oral contraceptive use may have a risk of hemorrhage and malignant transformation and require surgical resection in symptomatic patients.

items.question: 79. An 89-year-old man with history of chronic renal failure presents with recurrent biliary colic and gallbladder mass. He has had multiple upper abdominal surgeries. The best management of this patient is:
items.explanation: Percutaneous cholecystostomy is preferred in elderly patients with multiple comorbidities and history of multiple abdominal surgeries who have acute cholecystitis.

items.question: 75. If the main pancreatic duct is injured to the left of the splenic artery during resection of the proximal stump, what is the most appropriate surgical management?
items.explanation: Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy is preferred for reconstruction of the main pancreatic duct injury left of the splenic artery.

items.question: 81. A 75-year-old man with longstanding and active alcohol use is admitted with progressive jaundice, pruritus, weight loss, and fatigue. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following tumor markers is most helpful in the diagnosis?
items.explanation: CA 19-9 is the most useful tumor marker for pancreatic adenocarcinoma. It is elevated in 70-90% of patients and used primarily for diagnosis and monitoring treatment response.

items.question: 82. Which of the following is the true statement about common bile duct injuries during laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
options: They always require a Roux-en Y hepaticojejunostomy
Common bile duct injury is more common in open cholecystectomy than laparoscopic
The injury is commonly recognized intraoperatively
Primary repair is the procedure of choice if the common bile duct is lacerated or only partially transected
items.explanation: Primary repair under tension is associated with an increased risk of stricture, so it is the procedure of choice if the common bile duct is lacerated or only partially transected.

items.question: 83. Which of the following is TRUE regarding the management of pancreatic pseudocyst?
options: Aspiration is the best initial treatment of all pseudocysts
Pseudocysts without symptoms or complications do not require intervention
Surgical drainage is always preferred over endoscopic treatment
Pseudocysts typically resolve within 2 weeks without treatment
items.explanation: Asymptomatic pancreatic pseudocysts may resolve spontaneously and do not always need intervention. Treatment is reserved for symptomatic or complicated pseudocysts.

items.question: 84. Which of the following statements about neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas is true?
options: Glucagonoma is usually associated with anemia
Gastrinomas are common in the pancreas and duodenum
Insulinoma is associated with weight loss and diarrhea
items.explanation: Gastrinomas commonly arise in the pancreas and duodenum, producing Zollinger-Ellison syndrome with hypergastrinemia.

items.question: Best treatment for a symptomatic nonparasitic splenic cyst is _____
options: Percutaneous urografin and argon beam coagulation
items.explanation: Best treatment for a symptomatic nonparasitic splenic cyst is partial splenectomy.

items.question: Nonparasitic Splenic cyst are classified as
options: Primary (true cyst) (epithelial lined) or secondary pseudocyst (no epithelial lining) of secondary traumatic or ischemic etiology
Nonparasitic cyst with or without symptoms
items.explanation: Nonparasitic Splenic cyst are classified as primary (true cyst) (epithelial lined) or secondary pseudocyst (no epithelial lining) of secondary traumatic or ischemic etiology.

items.question: TRUE regarding the ________ is
options: Watershed area of splenic artery in the upper window including the medial left upper lobe
Including renal perfusion of kidney otherwise approached
Systolic, diastolic blood pressure and rigid arterial sclerosis are associated with
The remaining cyst, and partial splenectomy will control
items.explanation: Watershed area of splenic artery in the upper window including the medial left upper lobe.

items.question: 94. Regarding congenital duodenal atresia, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Less than 50% of cases are associated with trisomy 21.
Postnatal presentation is with non-bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.
A plain x-ray may show an intra-luminal ground glass appearance.
items.explanation: It causes proximal intestinal obstruction.

items.question: 95. Meconium ileus, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Less than 50% of cases are associated with cystic fibrosis.
Distal ileum usually occurs in the distal ileum site of fibrosis.
Postnatal presentation is with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.
A plain X-ray may show an intra-luminal ground glass appearance.
items.explanation: A plain X-ray may show an intra-luminal ground glass appearance.

items.question: 96. Regarding intussusception, which of the following is TRUE?
options: It is very uncommon cause of intestinal obstruction in children.
Usually occurs in the ileum, ileocolic being the most common site.
Ultrasound is very sensitive in diagnosing intussusception.
items.explanation: Usually occurs in the ileum, ileocolic being the most common site.

items.question: 97. Dysplasic congenital tracheo-esophageal fistula confirmed by passing a small volume of water into stomach through a catheter might confirm diagnosis by which of the following?
options: Radiological evidence of gas in the stomach and proximal bowel.
Radiological evidence of gas in the stomach.
items.explanation: Radiological evidence of gas in the stomach and proximal bowel.

items.question: 98. Regarding infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Usually presents at 15 days to 3 months of age.
The typical projectile vomiting is bilious.
Involves diffuse hypertrophy of the longitudinal muscle layer of the pylorus.
items.explanation: Has a strong familial predisposition.

items.question: 98. Which of the following is the most common malignancy in childhood?
items.explanation: Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy and is the third most frequent cause of childhood death. In infants, it is the third most frequent cause of death after neuroblastoma and leukemia. Approximately 40% of childhood malignancies are leukemia, 30% are a solid tumor. The next 30% have a sausage-shaped abdominal mass. The common solid tumor is Wilms tumor.

items.question: 99. A 2-month-old boy found with history and examination of an umbilical hernia. All of the followings are possible diagnosis regarding Hirschsprung's disease, which of the following is right?
items.explanation: Hirschsprung's disease involves large bowel obstruction. Results from the absence of ganglion cells to the distal colon. Diagnosis is confirmed by histological evidence of achalasia of the intestinal nerve plexus in the affected segment involving an empty rectal ampulla and absence of ganglion cells. Umbilical hernia commonly associated with Hirschsprung's disease due to increased intra-abdominal pressure.

items.question: 100. The diagnosis can be confirmed histological evidence of:
items.explanation: Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by identifying the absence of ganglion cells in affected bowel segment, confirmed by histology showing aganglionic intestinal segment.

items.question: 101. If examination of an inguinal hernia is suspected and irreducible, tender, with systemic manifestation such as fever and leukocytosis, and findings of bowel distension and abdominal wall erythema. What is the next step?
items.explanation: Acute strangulation or incarceration of an inguinal hernia is a surgical emergency. Manual reduction is contraindicated due to risk of bowel injury and content necrosis. Immediate laparotomy is required.

items.question: Which one of the following is the most common cause of intestinal atresia at birth?
items.explanation: Jejunoileal atresia is the most common cause of intestinal atresia at birth.

items.question: Which of the following findings are characteristics of "apple peel" intestinal atresia?
items.explanation: Characteristics of apple peel intestinal atresia include absence of mesentery.

items.question: The following conditions are associated with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), except:
items.explanation: Typical umbilical hernia is not associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.

items.question: 4. Strategies to limit the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in brain injured patients includes all of the following EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Early discontinuation of antibiotics is not recommended.

items.question: 5. The need for fasciotomy after electrical injury to an extremity is best diagnosed by:
options: Pain on passive stretch of the involved muscle compartment
items.explanation: Pain on passive stretch of the involved muscle compartment is the best diagnostic sign.

items.question: 6. Which of the following statements by parents is most typical of the toddler age?
options: I have problems with my son's speech
My son shows intention to learn to talk
I am worried the child is deaf
items.explanation: Separation anxiety is a salient symptom during the toddler age.

items.question: 7. A 60-year-old woman with oliguria and a history of recent hysterectomy has developed lethargy and poor responsiveness. The most sensitive indicator of her neurological status is:
items.explanation: Motor response is the most sensitive and reliable indicator of neurological status.

items.question: Regarding cervical spine injury which of the following statements is NOT true?
options: Cervical spine injury usually caused by an axial load and hyper flexion.
C1, C2 fractures are unstable type.
Odontoid (dens) fracture is unstable and treated by halo or rigid collar.
Pure spinal subluxation or dislocation usually treated by collar.
Anterior spinal subluxation or dislocation is unstable.
items.explanation: Pure spinal subluxation or dislocation is unstable and usually requires more than just collar immobilization.

items.question: Regarding neck injury which of the following statements is true?
options: The internal jugular vein may be ligated until the patient stabilizes.
Anterior jugular vein ligation needs shunts.
Unilateral ligation of the internal jugular vein is mostly associated with transient neurological deficits.
Type 1 internal jugular vein injuries are fatal.
items.explanation: The internal jugular vein may be ligated and the patient stabilized, being a large vein with many collaterals.

items.question: Any patient who presents with neck injury above the clavicle must be assessed for which of the following?
items.explanation: Thyroid gland must be drained if injured in neck trauma to prevent complications.

items.question: Regarding pharyngoesophageal injuries which of the following is correct?
options: Stenting of common canal is routine.
Esophageal injury does not require drainage.
items.explanation: Primary repair of pharyngoesophageal injuries is usually indicated for better healing.

items.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding a neck hematoma?
options: Requires urgent evacuation and securing airway.
Does not pose risk if small.
items.explanation: A neck hematoma can compress airway and requires urgent evacuation and securing the airway.

A 68-year-old male patient with history of epigastric pain, weight loss and anemia. Upper gi endoscopy shows a large ulcer with hard base and irregular margin at mid transverse body (along the greater curvature) causes upper gastric bleeding. Biopsy examination of the ulcer most likely histologic finding is:
items.explanation:
Answer: E, gastric adenocarcinoma
Explanation: The clinical presentation and endoscopy findings suggest gastric adenocarcinoma which is a common malignancy in the stomach presenting with epigastric pain, weight loss, anemia and ulcer with hard base and irregular margin.

items.question:
A 21-year-old male presents with 3 months history of weight loss, jaundice and persistent vomiting.
Uppergi series shows barium filling defect in the distal duodenum with proximal dilatation of stomach. What is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation:
Answer: D, Duodenal web
Explanation: Barium study findings of an obstructing filling defect in the distal duodenum with proximal dilatation of stomach in a young adult suggests duodenal web causing partial obstruction and leading to symptoms of persistent vomiting and weight loss.

items.question: A female patient was operated for carcinoma stomach. Postoperatively she developed obstructive jaundice. Which of the following is the common cause of jaundice post subtotal gastrectomy?
items.explanation:
Answer: D, External compression by lymph nodes
Explanation: In carcinoma stomach post subtotal gastrectomy, obstructive jaundice is commonly caused by external compression of bile duct by metastatic lymph nodes.

items.question: A 65-year-old man presents with upper abdominal discomfort for 3 months. Endoscopy reveals a large polypoidal mass in the body of stomach. Biopsy shows adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor?
items.explanation:
Answer: E, Lymph node involvement
Explanation: In gastric adenocarcinoma, lymph node involvement is the most important prognostic factor determining survival.

items.question: 12. A 67-year-old man with dyspepsia undergoes endoscopy with biopsy at a local hospital. The diagnosis is mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma involving the stomach. Which is the most appropriate therapy for this patient would be?
items.explanation: Antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice for MALT lymphoma involving the stomach, especially when Helicobacter pylori infection has been identified, as eradication can lead to remission.

items.question: 13. A 33-year-old otherwise healthy woman presents with abdominal pain or constipation for 3 months. She has no abdominal pain or constipation, weight loss, or night sweats. Physical examination is unremarkable. Colonoscopy reveals that her colon is normal. She is negative for Helicobacter pylori. She has microcytic anemia (hemoglobin 7.5 g/dL), an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 65 mm/hr, and vitamin B12 and folate levels are normal. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
items.explanation: Capsule endoscopy is indicated for evaluation of small bowel pathology in patients with unexplained iron deficiency anemia and negative colonoscopy and upper endoscopy.

items.question: 14. A 22-year-old erects a fresh-hand-made plastic bag of ridicule. A scar from the right rib region and trauma is accompanied by a sharp wound. He was selected from the tribe as a prisoner. What is the likely site of this predominant lesion?
items.explanation: Bowel perforation would be predominant with a sharp wound and trauma. The plastic bag scenario suggests a penetrating trauma most consistent with bowel injury.

items.question: Which of the following statements about diaphragmatic hernias of Moiganqi is TRUE?
options: Women present at a younger age than men
They more commonly occur on the left side
Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
Laparoscopic or open repair is possible
Morgagni hernias make up 50% of all diaphragmatic hernias
items.explanation: The incidence of congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH) is 1 in 2000 to 5000 births. The cause of this sporadic developmental anomaly is unknown. The most common CDH is hernia of Bochdalek, which occurs on the left side in 80% of cases and involves a posterolateral defect in the diaphragm. Morgagni's foramina are small triangular areas at the anterior aspect of the diaphragm on either side of the inferior end of the sternum. Morgagni hernia is a congenital defect between the costal and sternal portions of the diaphragm muscle. Morgagni hernias make up 3% of all diaphragmatic hernias. They occur far more commonly on the right side (91%) despite protection from the liver. The defect itself usually has a greater transverse dimension than the anteroposterior dimension Morgagni hernias occur more commonly in women (62%) than men. The average patient age at presentation is 53. The average age at presentation is 58 for women and 50 for men. In women, 15% of cases present between 56 and 60 years of age; men have a more bimodal distribution, with peaks at 31 to 35 and 66 to 70. The most common symptoms are pressure in the chest or abdomen (37%) followed closely by pulmonary symptoms (36%); 28% of patients are asymptomatic at presentation and the hernia is usually found on chest x-ray. Acute presentations occur more frequently in children. Morgagni hernias can be repaired via laparotomy, thoracotomy, thoracoscopy. Surgical repair is indicated in all cases due to incarceration. items.question: A 25-year-old woman who is 23 weeks with epigastric pain. Serum amylase is 922 U/L. Ultrasound study shows gallbladder and a normal common bile pancreatic is diagnosed. Which of the is TRUE?
options: After successful conservative treatment, pancreatitis during the same pregnancy is
ERCP with common bile duct contraindicated in this patient
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy can be risk to the mother and fetus
Most cases of gallstone pancreatitis trimester
