items.explanation: Acute pancreatitis occurs in 1:1000 to 4000 percent of cases occur in the second trimester. In the first trimester being relatively uncommon, the potential for harm to the management gallstone pancreatitis during pregnancy.

items.question: LN metastasis is most common in:
items.explanation:
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Reference: Shah JP, et al 1995.

items.question: Treatment of Mitis Osteoporosis,Q2
options: Provide antibiotics, immobilization, and wound irrigation with 10% povidone iodine or hydrogen peroxide mouth rinsing
Complete resection of mandible and mycologyscides and 3rd mandibular nerve ligation
items.explanation: Immediate excision and skin graft.

items.question: What is the more complex technique to obtain soft tissue transfer
items.explanation: Free flap is the more complex technique to obtain soft tissue transfer.

items.question: 1-2 days, the graft undergoes inhibition: a thin layer of fibrin and necrotic tissue may cause all these EXCEPT
items.explanation: Review illustrated 2-273(Q)

items.question: 2- What is the first stage of full thickness skin graft ?
options: Imbibition - Serum absorption of graft to the host bed
Adhesion attachment of the graft to the host bed
Revascularization - ingrowth of new blood vessels between the graft and host bed
Inoscelulation - Anastomosies between the graft and host vessels
items.explanation: Inhibition, Attachment of graft to the host bed

items.question: A paraplegic patient developed pressure sore at sacrum after 6 months with hypertonic spasms following healing of first degree burn. What is the ideal treatment to down to bone to decrease the pressure sore?
items.explanation: Sartorius maximum muscle is ideal as it improves closure of the wound and pressure sore without deformity.

items.question: Sacsral pressure sore develops due to (Pick ONE)
options: Excessive pressure on bone and because of the bone pressure
Bony prominence which are exposed to pressure
Bony cover of the bony spine prominence is highly vascular
Friction on the bony prominence and the soft tissue
items.explanation: Sacsral pressure sore develops because of the bony prominence which is exposed to pressure from sitting and lying on the sacrum.

items.question: Which of the following surgical procedures is rare?
items.explanation: Fasciotomy is rare in surgery, other procedures are common.

items.question: Full-thickness burns of the lower extremity usually require excision and grafting because of
items.explanation: Full-thickness burns require excision and grafting because of the lack of dermal elements necessary for regeneration.

items.question: 37. Which of the followings is NOT a prerequisite for the use of recombinant factor VIIa in bleeding trauma patients?
options: Bleeding cannot be controlled by blood component administration
items.explanation: Temperature > 36 °C is NOT a prerequisite for the use of recombinant factor VIIa. The other options are prerequisites.

items.question: 38. Which of the followings may occur after operating on a descending thoracic aorta and perhaps the most devastating is
items.explanation: Paraplegia with parathorax is considered the most devastating complication after operating on the descending thoracic aorta.

items.question: 39. The most effective means of preventing the development of Kawasaki disease and ameliorating the sequelae affecting the coronary arteries and preventing the development of giant coronary artery aneurysms is the administration of
items.explanation: The administration of IV gamma globulins is the most effective means of preventing Kawasaki disease sequelae, including coronary artery aneurysms.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding anterior mediastinoscopy (visual surgery)?
options: Visual inspection can be stretched and hoarseness occurs due to injury of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.
Tracheal insufficiency can occur after operating on a descending thoracic aorta.
Injury to the thoracic duct is rare but can cause chylothorax.
Paraplegia is the most devastating consequence of aortic surgery.
Compression of anomalous left coronary artery is a common complication.
items.explanation: Compression of anomalous left coronary artery is not a common complication of anterior mediastinoscopy.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true in large burn wounds?
options: There is a rapid increase in size especially of superficial burns.
Infection may occur due to loss of skin barrier.
Extensive skin grafting is usually required.
Burn wound contraction is prevented by skin grafting.
items.explanation: Rapid increase in size is not typically seen in large burn wounds; rather, infection and tissue loss contribute to complications.

items.question: When performing aortic reconstruction. aortocoronary shunt may be inserted to preserve sexual function by
options: Near the bifurcation of the right common iliac artery
As they cross the proximal right CIA
Near the bifurcation of right CIA
Posterior to the aorta and iliac arteries at the origin
items.explanation: Aortocoronary shunt is inserted at the proximal right common iliac artery (CIA) to preserve sexual function during aortic reconstruction.

items.question: Purpose of medical therapy in ameliorating the development of Kawasaki's disease and coronary artery aneurysms is
items.explanation: The use of gamma globulin in high doses (2 gm/kg) along with aspirin reduces the incidence and severity of Kawasaki's disease and coronary artery aneurysms.

items.question: Which of the following is most accurate?
options: 40% mortality rate in men with acute right ventricular infarction.
Sexual dysfunction persists in about 10% of patients after AAA repair.
Impotence following AAA repair is usually caused by psychological factors.
Pericardial air embolism is the most common cause of carbon dioxide embolism.
During lung transplantation, fluid infusion can be shown to increase pulmonary vascular resistance.
items.explanation: The mortality rate in men with acute right ventricular infarction is approximately 40%, associated with poor prognosis.

items.question: When repairing juxtarenal abdominal aortic aneurysms, which of the following is the most effective measure to prevent renal failure?
options: Maintaining a blood pressure of 70 to 80 mmHG
Controlling the aortic clamp degrees cold
Infusing the renal arteries with renal preservation cold solution
items.explanation: Infusing the renal arteries with renal preservation cold solution has been reported to improve postoperative renal function and reduces the likelihood of renal failure.

items.question: When measuring systolic foot perfusion pressure in the big toe, the accepted normal range is:
items.explanation: Using a photoplethysmographic technique at the toe, a systolic foot perfusion pressure of above 50 mmHg is considered normal.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)?
options: HIT is an immune-mediated or less commonly nonimmune disorder of platelet activation caused by IgG antibodies formed against PF4-heparin complexes.
Platelet count typically falls to 100,000/µL or it drops by 50% from baseline.
The majority of patients with HIT develop venous thrombosis in less than 24 hours after exposure to heparin.
Platelet count usually begins to recover 5 to 7 days after stopping heparin.
The platelet count does not usually drop below 20,000/µL.
items.explanation: The majority of patients with HIT develop venous thrombosis usually between 5 and 10 days after initiation of heparin, not within the first 24 hours.

items.question: A diabetic patient developed a severe pruritic maculopapular rash affecting extremities 10 days after starting several antibiotics. The rash is described as confluent erythematous papules with pruritus and mild fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Gram stain of the mid-vessel segment skin biopsy shows small percentage of eosinophils with few necrotic keratinocytes.
The rash associated with exfoliative dermatitis is attributed to increased small percentage of eosinophils in perivascular infiltrate of skin biopsy and absence of necrotic keratinocytes.
Diabetic patients with pruritic rash following antibiotics require Tzanck smear for herpes simplex virus.
The best treatment for this condition is desensitization and continuation of the implicated antibiotics.
The condition is likely Stevens-Johnson syndrome and requires intravenous corticosteroids.
items.explanation: The rash described is characteristic of exfoliative dermatitis commonly caused by drugs such as antibiotics and is associated with perivascular infiltrate of eosinophils in skin biopsy without necrotic keratinocytes.

items.question: ARDS is characterized by which of the following clinical features?
options: Increased dead space and decreased lung compliance
Elevated cardiac output and low PEEP requirement
Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis in the first 24 hours
High base deficit is normal and related to body temperature
Improvement with inspiratory holds and CPAP
items.explanation: ARDS is characterized by an increase in dead space, decreased lung compliance, hypoxemia refractory to oxygen therapy, and the need for positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

items.question: In the management of patients with base deficit greater than 10, which of the following statements is correct?
options: Volume of fluid infusion should be restricted
Base deficit is not related to body temperature
Correction of base deficit is more important than correcting arterial oxygenation
High base deficit indicates respiratory alkalosis
Base deficit correlates closely with the severity of shock but does not predict survival
items.explanation: Base deficit is a useful prognostic indicator reflecting the severity of shock and metabolic acidosis; it helps predict survival and is important in guiding fluid resuscitation.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding ARDS?
options: Conservative fluid strategy for patients with established ARDS (grade 1A)
Conservative fluid strategy for patients with established ARDS who do not have evidence of tissue hypoperfusion
ARDS develops a severe, diffuse inflammatory lung injury with increased permeability pulmonary edema and loss of aerated lung tissue
ARDS (grade 1B) diagnosis is based on the timing of insult, chest radiograph appearance, and degree of hypoxemia according to the PaO2/FiO2 blood oxygen ratio
ARDS is associated with increased extravascular lung water and pulmonary dead space
items.explanation: Answer C. ARDS develops a severe, diffuse inflammatory lung injury with increased permeability pulmonary edema and loss of aerated lung tissue, but it is not 'not true' as option C states; this is a true statement about ARDS.

items.question: All of the following parts or upper limb EXCEPT?
items.explanation: Elbow is part of lower arm, not upper limb.

items.question: Amputation at this level is also generally not considered be mutilating?
items.explanation: Amputation at elbow joint is generally not considered mutilating.

items.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the upper limb amputations?
options: Facial transplantation is a universal phenomenon in shock trauma amputations.
Bacterial translocation is universal phenomenon in shock trauma amputations.
The gastrointestinal tract has the major role in multi-organ dysfunction syndrome in shock.
Purpose of parenteral enteral nutrition is associated with circulatory failure.
The nutritional circulation is maintained when circulatory failure occurs in shock.
items.explanation: Facial transplantation is NOT a universal phenomenon in shock trauma amputations.

items.question: Which artery cerebral coronary lesion most likely to cause death?
options: Left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
Right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
items.explanation: Left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery is most likely to cause death.

items.question: Management of coronary artery lesion?
items.explanation: Surgical coronary artery repair is indicated for coronary artery lesions.

items.question: Multi organ dysfunction syndrome?
options: Increased oxygen consumption increases lactic acidosis
Development of multiple organ dysfunction correlates with increasing age
items.explanation: Hypoxia resulting from microcirculation changes leads to multi organ dysfunction syndrome.

items.question: A middle-aged man is undergoing laparotomy for blunt abdominal trauma. Both liver and kidneys are found to be injured. Which of the following are both included in ICU Protocols for the initial treatment of the patient?
options: Adequate surgical hemostasis and Proper correction of acid-base disturbance
All liver injuries regardless of their grade
items.explanation: A Stepwise Approach p620: Causes of abdominal Solid Organ Trauma and its ICU Protocols include: -Inadequate surgical hemostasis -Inadequate resuscitation -Hepatic reperfusion injury -Hemobilia -Obstruction of bile duct by blood clot or bile duct stricture -Coagulopathy

items.question: All of the following statements about follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is NOT true?
options: Is the most common type of well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma in Haemodialysis patients
I-complete surgical resection (lobectomy or total thyroidectomy) is required
Follicular carcinoma is more common in older patients (>peak incidence 45-55 years)
Follicular carcinoma less commonly intracapsular papillary carcinoma is the most common type of well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma
items.explanation: Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is NOT more common in haemodialysis patients (incorrect statement). It is frequently multifocal, it spreads by hematogenous route, mostly affects older patients, and requires complete surgical resection.

items.question: Which of the followings is NOT true regarding the replacement of a tube in a biliary fistula involving the common bile duct after unsuccessful ERCP?
options: The replacement tube is usually placed in the jejunum through the fistula to prevent bile leakage
The tube placed in the ducts usually will close spontaneously
Some fistulas are refractory to non-operative biliary fistula management
The Tube placed in the patient's abdomen should be placed from the left lateral side
Principal therapy is maintaining adequate bile drainage
items.explanation: Tube placement from left lateral side is NOT appropriate because tubes are usually placed from the right in ERCP or surgical interventions to allow for optimal drainage and avoid complications.

items.question: Which of the followings is NOT true regarding the esophageal tumor with dysphagia?
options: Epidural body tumor is most commonly found in middle third
The tumor is infiltrated by tumor cells leading to dysphagia
Cervical body tumor is mostly located at cricopharyngeal region
Extrathoracic tumors spread by lymphatic metastasis
Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of well-differentiated carcinoma
items.explanation: Epidural body tumor most commonly occurs in middle third of esophagus is NOT true. Typically, tumors occur most commonly in the lower third.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT a complication of total thyroidectomy?
items.explanation: Pneumothorax is not a common complication of total thyroidectomy. Total thyroidectomy can lead to vascular injury, recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (causing hoarseness), and oesophageal injuries due to the anatomical proximity of these structures to the thyroid gland.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true in regard to salivary cyst formation?
options: Usually found in the neonatal period and does lead at the birth, often disappears spontaneously and does not require treatment
items.explanation: Wound infection is not a type of salivary cyst. Salivary cysts include mucous cysts, salivary fistulae and mucous retention cysts. They are usually found in the neonatal period and mostly disappear spontaneously without treatment.

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding papillary thyroid carcinoma is true?
options: Total thyroidectomy and isthmus resection are sufficient for papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Total thyroidectomy or lobectomy and isthmus resection are standard surgical procedures for papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Isolated isthmusectomy is the recommended operation for papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Total thyroidectomy is rarely performed in papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Lobectomy and resection of the isthmus are necessary in all cases.
items.explanation: The correct standard surgical procedure for papillary thyroid carcinoma is either total thyroidectomy or lobectomy and isthmus resection. This approach ensures adequate management of the tumor while preserving thyroid function when possible. In contrast, isolated isthmusectomy or lobectomy without resection of the isthmus is not sufficient, and total thyroidectomy may not be required in all cases.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding papillary thyroid carcinoma?
options: Nodule with no cervical lymph node enlargement.
Total thyroidectomy and resection of the isthmus.
Total thyroid lobectomy, resection of the isthmus, and adequate therapy for micrometastasis node metastases as needed.
Total thyroid lobectomy and resection of the isthmus.
items.explanation: Option D is incorrect because while nodal metastases in papillary thyroid carcinoma are common, adequate therapy for micrometastases is not always required and the statement is not fully accurate as a treatment approach. The other options correctly describe accepted management strategies for papillary thyroid carcinoma depending on the clinical presentation.

items.question: Which of the following is BEST differentiated from cold abscess by calcium?
items.explanation: Bronchial cysts are best differentiated from cold abscess by the presence of calcium within the cyst. Cold abscesses generally do not contain calcifications, whereas bronchial cysts can show calcifications, which aids in differentiation.

items.question: Postoperative management is BEST illustrated by which protocol of serum calcium measurement?
items.explanation: Postoperative monitoring of serum calcium is best conducted by serial measurements at 4, 8, and 12 hours post-surgery to detect hypocalcemia early and manage accordingly.

items.question: All of the following are TRUE regarding secondary hyperparathyroidism EXCEPT:
options: It is caused initially by subtotal parathyroidectomy
Is very low in post-operative period
items.explanation: Secondary hyperparathyroidism usually causes decreased intestinal calcium absorption, not increased. The other options accurately describe features of secondary hyperparathyroidism, such as hypocalcemia and decreased active vitamin D levels.

items.question: 67. Colorectal cancer, which of the following statements is NOT correct?
options: Colonic distension in toxic megacolon is most prominent in ascending colon
Radiotherapy + Radioablation is equivalent to resection as therapy
Tumor debulking does not improve the efficacy of chemotherapy
Bilobar metastases are not a contraindication to resection
items.explanation: Bilobar metastases (metastases in both lobes of the liver) are often considered a challenge but are not an absolute contraindication to liver resection in colorectal cancer metastasis. Options A, C, and D relate to aspects of treatment or pathology that are established: colonic distension in toxic megacolon is most prominent in the ascending colon; radiotherapy plus radioablation can be equivalent to resection; tumor debulking does not improve chemotherapy efficacy.

items.question: 68. Aim tubular adenoma, the highest malignant potential is:
items.explanation: Villous adenomas have a higher malignant potential compared to tubular adenomas, and size matters as well. Therefore, a 3 cm villous polyp has the highest chance of malignancy among the listed options.

items.question: 69. Aim tubular adenoma, the highest malignant potential is:
items.explanation: There seems to be repetition or error in the options listed, but according to the source, the correct answer indicated is C. This may reflect the classification in the question set; generally, larger and villous-type adenomas have higher malignancy risk.

items.question: 70. Screening position emission tomography (PET) for liver metastases lesion detects improved 3- and 5-year survival compared with historical controls:
items.explanation: PET scanning improves the detection of liver metastases, and its use has been shown to improve survival rates in cases involving the sigmoid colon compared to historical controls.

items.question: 71. Colonic distension in toxic megacolon is most prominent in:
items.explanation: Toxic megacolon typically causes the most prominent colonic distension in the transverse colon due to the anatomical and physiological susceptibility of this segment.

items.question: ABC MCQs Part II 69. Aim tubular adenoma, the highest malignant potential is:
items.explanation: Villous adenomas and tubulovillous adenomas have higher malignant potential than simple tubular adenomas; among the options, 1 cm tubular polyp represents the highest malignant potential according to the provided key.

items.question: ABC MCQS Part II 70. Most commonly presents with intestinal pseudo-obstruction:
options: Most commonly presents with intestinal pseudo-obstruction
Most commonly present with ileal abscess
Requires excision of both organs involved for surgical treatment
Requires excision of both organs involved for surgical treatment
items.explanation: Intestinal pseudo-obstruction is a typical presentation in certain gastrointestinal diseases. This option fits best with the typical presentation described in the question set.

items.question: ABC MCQs Part II 71. Most commonly involves small bowel to small bowel fistula:
options: Requires surgical intervention as soon as the diagnosis is made
Most commonly involves small bowel to small bowel fistula
Requires excision of both organs involved for surgical treatment
Most commonly presents with intestinal pseudo-obstruction
items.explanation: Crohn's disease often leads to the formation of fistulas, most commonly between small bowel segments, which is a hallmark of the disease progression.

items.question: ABC MCQs Part II 72. Requires surgical intervention as soon as the diagnosis is made:
options: Most commonly involves small bowel to small bowel fistula
Most commonly presents with intestinal pseudo-obstruction
Requires surgical intervention as soon as the diagnosis is made
Requires excision of both organs involved for surgical treatment
items.explanation: Certain complications related to Crohn's disease or bowel fistulas may require prompt surgical intervention upon diagnosis to avoid further morbidity.

items.question: Which of the following genes is NOT part of the genetic mutations involved in the pathogenesis of colon malignancy?
items.explanation: The genetic mutations commonly involved in colon malignancy include APC, KRAS, p53, and DCC genes. BCL-2 gene is not typically part of the colon cancer mutation pathway. APC mutations initiate tumorigenesis, KRAS mutations help in progression, p53 mutations allow malignancy progression, and DCC mutations are related to progression. BCL-2 is more associated with inhibition of apoptosis in other cancers but is not a primary genetic mutation in colon malignancy.

items.question: In colon cancer (DCC), which of the following is NOT involved?
items.explanation: In colon cancer, the genes commonly involved are APC, p53, DCC, and TP53. PKC (Protein kinase C) is not listed as involved in colon cancer development. APC is a tumor suppressor gene responsible for familial colon cancer, p53 is important in tumor progression, DCC is involved in progression, and TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene. Hence, PKC is not part of the genetic mutations in colon cancer.

items.question: For a clinically aggressive malignant lesion of colorectal cancer, the main treatment modality would be:
items.explanation: Clinically aggressive malignant colorectal lesions usually require combined treatment approaches. Surgery alone may be insufficient due to metastasis or advanced disease. Combining chemotherapy and surgical resection improves outcomes, as chemotherapy can target systemic disease while surgery removes the tumor mass. Radiation alone or chemotherapy alone is usually inadequate for aggressive colorectal cancer. Palliative therapy is reserved for non-curable cases.

items.question: In colon malignancies, treatment resistant to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) is likely due to mutations in which gene?
items.explanation: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a fluoropyrimidine drug used in treating colon cancer. Resistance to 5-FU can occur due to mutations or deficiencies in dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD), an enzyme involved in metabolizing 5-FU. Deficiency in DPD leads to altered drug metabolism and resistance to chemotherapy. APC, KRAS, BCL-2, and p53 mutations relate to cancer development and progression but not directly to 5-FU resistance.

items.question: 74. For a patient with a T3N2 adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, what is the optimal therapy?
options: Less invasive operative interventions of the distal esophagus
items.explanation: The optimal approach for a patient with a T3N2 adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus is preoperative chemoradiotherapy followed by surgical resection. This approach has demonstrated a significant survival advantage compared to surgery alone, and it also improves resectability rates. Studies indicate that preoperative chemoradiotherapy and radiation therapy provide better outcomes than chemotherapy alone or postoperative treatment.

items.question: 75. A 55-year-old man presents with a pigmented lesion in the right malar area that measures 1.2 cm with irregular margins. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. The next step in management would include:
items.explanation: For a pigmented lesion of this size and characteristics, a wide local excision with appropriate margins is recommended. Resecting with 2-cm margins may be necessary depending on the lesion depth but typically comes after confirming the lesion type. Lymphoscintigraphy and immunohistochemical studies may be considered in suspected melanoma cases but are not the first step for a suspicious pigmented lesion. Vitamin A administration is not relevant here.

items.question: A 65-year-old woman has had spontaneous clear discharge from her left breast for 3 months. Examination of the left breast reveals a palpable 2 x 1.5 cm mass underlying the nipple-areolar complex. Which of the following is the best option for treatment?
items.explanation: A 65-year-old woman with spontaneous clear discharge from the nipple and a palpable mass in the nipple-areolar complex most likely has a central duct papilloma or other intraductal pathology. The best initial treatment is duct excision, which provides both diagnosis and treatment by removing the abnormal duct. Simple mastectomy or quadrantectomy are more extensive surgeries not usually needed initially. Core biopsy may not be diagnostic if the lesion is located deeply in the ducts. MRI may be useful for further evaluation but is not the immediate treatment choice.

items.question: A 65-year-old woman has a nonpalpable lump found on her screening mammogram. There is no nipple discharge or nipple retraction. The first step recommended is:
items.explanation: For a nonpalpable breast lump detected on mammogram without clinical signs such as nipple discharge, the next step is histological diagnosis to determine the nature of the lesion. Core biopsy is generally preferred over fine needle aspiration as it provides more tissue and allows for better pathological assessment. Observation without diagnosis is not appropriate, and surgical excision before diagnosis is usually not recommended. Mammographic magnification is useful but does not replace tissue diagnosis.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT a recommended management option following papillary breast lesions without atypia on core biopsy?
items.explanation: Papillary breast lesions without atypia detected on core biopsy typically require excision biopsy for definitive diagnosis and treatment. Observation and radiological follow-up may be an option in some cases but usually after excision. Repeat core biopsy can be considered if diagnosis is uncertain. Simple mastectomy is an overtreatment and not typically indicated for benign papillary lesions.

items.question: A 72-year-old Caucasian woman with a 2.5-cm mass noted on the initial mammogram of the right breast has undergone a core needle biopsy of a 2.7-mm black node on the right reveals a metastatic focus measuring 1.5 mm in size. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of the axillary lymph node?
items.explanation: The management depends on the size of the metastatic focus in the lymph node. A metastatic focus measuring 1.5 mm is within the range where further axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) may not be necessary, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) can be sufficient, especially given the low risk of non-sentinel node metastases. Generally, a metastatic focus less than 2 mm in a sentinel node is referred to as a micrometastasis, and no further axillary dissection is recommended, to avoid overtreatment.

items.question: 79. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed in a 55-year-old patient with cholelithiasis. Which of the following statements about adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosal lamina propria is true?
options: Observation and surveillance follow-up only for six months
Excision of gallbladder fossa, port sites, and portal lymphadenectomy
Excision of gallbladder fossa, port sites, and portal lymphadenectomy if > 2 cm
Excision of gallbladder fossa, port sites, portal lymphadenectomy, and re-excision of the gallbladder bed
items.explanation: Adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosal lamina propria has low risk of lymph node metastasis and excellent prognosis with simple cholecystectomy. Thus, observation and surveillance follow-up only are appropriate, without the need for additional radical surgery.

items.question: 80. Principles of treatment for gallbladder carcinoma include all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Segmental resection of liver segments IVb and V
Adjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine or fluorouracil
items.explanation: Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma typically involves cholecystectomy with regional lymphadenectomy, possible segmental liver resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy. Embolization of the hepatic artery is not recommended as it can cause liver ischemia and is not a standard treatment method.

items.question: 81. Risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the small bowel include all of the following EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and increases risk of colorectal cancer but is not a significant risk factor for small bowel adenocarcinoma. Crohn's disease, celiac disease, familial adenomatous polyposis, and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer are known risk factors for small bowel adenocarcinoma.

items.question: A 43-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, obstruction. At laparotomy, he has multiple tumors of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel, including desmoids tumors. Multiple masses of the small bowel. The most likely diagnosis is:
items.explanation: The presence of multiple small bowel tumors with desmoid tumors strongly indicates familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) with its extracolonic manifestations, including desmoids. However, the question's best fit answer among listed options for multiple small bowel tumors with desmoids is malignant melanoma, which can metastasize to the small bowel and present with multiple tumors. Adenocarcinoma and lymphoma are less commonly associated with multiple small bowel masses and desmoids; carcinoid tumors usually present as single lesions. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) usually present as solitary masses.

items.question: A 73-year-old man has small bowel obstruction. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?
items.explanation: In adults, the most common cause of small bowel obstruction is adhesions, typically from previous surgery or inflammation. Malignant melanoma can cause bowel metastases but is a less common cause of obstruction. Lymphoma, adenocarcinoma, and carcinoid tumors can cause obstruction but are less frequent etiologies compared to adhesions.

items.question: Wide local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy are the standard management for:
options: Breast lesion, Lt. axilla, COOP presents with stellate mass
items.explanation: Wide local excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy is the standard management for cutaneous melanoma to ensure complete tumor removal and regional lymph node evaluation for metastasis. Breast lesions and other cancers typically have different surgical approaches; Kaposi sarcoma treatment varies based on type and extent.

items.question: A 52-year-old woman undergoes an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy from a mammary mass and pathology reveals papillary adenoma. The next step in management is:
items.explanation: Papillary adenomas can harbor malignancy and the core needle biopsy might underestimate the lesion. Therefore, excisional biopsy is the next step for definitive diagnosis and management. Tamoxifen (likely referred here as Amoxifen) is hormone therapy used for certain breast cancers, not benign papillary adenoma. Observation alone is inadequate due to possible malignancy risk.

items.question: For which of the following is mastectomy with axillary node dissection recommended?
options: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) positive margins
Ductal carcinoma with sentinel lymph node biopsy
items.explanation: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with positive surgical margins after breast-conserving surgery often requires mastectomy and axillary node dissection to ensure complete tumor removal and address possible spread. LCIS is typically treated with observation or chemoprevention. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is done for invasive carcinoma, not DCIS alone. Mastitis and fibroadenomas do not require mastectomy.

items.question: All the following are characteristics of gastric band EXCEPT
items.explanation: A gastric band is adjustable, can be placed laparoscopically, is durable, and does not involve cutting the stomach. It works by placing an adjustable band around the upper stomach to create a small pouch. It does not multiply or divide the stomach; that is a characteristic of other procedures like gastric bypass.

items.question: Advantages of the adjustable gastric band include all EXCEPT
options: Avoidance of malabsorption and nutritional deficiencies
items.explanation: The adjustable gastric band is known for being safe, reversible, causing fewer postoperative complications, and avoiding malabsorption issues because it doesn't alter the intestines. It does not decrease the power of gastric emptying per se; rather, it restricts food intake by creating a small stomach pouch.

items.question: Primary weight loss failure is defined as
items.explanation: Primary weight loss failure is defined as a failure to achieve at least 25% loss of excess weight following a bariatric procedure. This threshold helps to identify patients who have not responded adequately to surgery and may need reassessment.

items.question: Postoperative leak in bariatric surgery
options: Upper gastrointestinal series fails to demonstrate a leak
Rare and seen mainly in band surgery
Leads to massive sepsis and death
items.explanation: A postoperative leak, especially after bariatric surgery like gastric bypass, is a serious and potentially life-threatening complication that can lead to massive sepsis and death if not detected and managed promptly.

items.question: Typical indications for bariatric surgery include all EXCEPT
options: Patients with previous major abdominal surgery
Failure of medical weight loss treatment
items.explanation: Previous major abdominal surgery is not an absolute contraindication but may complicate surgery. Typical indications focus on patients with BMI > 40, or BMI > 35 with obesity-related comorbidities, who have failed medical treatment and have appropriate motivation and understanding.

items.question: Which organ is the commonest complication of laparoscopic band procedure?
items.explanation: The most common complication of laparoscopic band procedure is gastric necrosis, which is serious and occurs due to compromised blood supply and ischemia.

items.question: The most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is?
items.explanation: Extrasystoles are the most common arrhythmia during laparoscopy due to increased sympathetic stimulation and insufflation effects.

items.question: The commonest rhythm seen during laparoscopy is?
items.explanation: Sinus tachycardia is the commonest rhythm seen during laparoscopy, caused by sympathetic stimulation and response to CO2 insufflation.

items.question: Which is true about Laparoscopic Adjustable Silicone Gastric Banding (LASGB)?
options: 1. It is considered a purely restrictive procedure
2. It has a low incidence of complications
3. It can be performed as a day case procedure
4. It involves placement of a band around the stomach
items.explanation: LASGB is a restrictive procedure involving placement of a band around the upper stomach. It is reversible, adjustable, and is sometimes done as a day-case procedure. However, it is not purely restrictive as it may have some effects on gastric emptying and requires ongoing adjustments.

items.question: The advantage of sleeve gastrectomy over the gastric band procedure is?
options: Similar weight loss rates 1 year after surgery
items.explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy has fewer wound-related complications compared to the gastric banding procedure, which involves leaving a foreign object inside the body and has other risks.

items.question: In laparoscopic humeral repair, one is TRUE:
options: Recurrence rate is lower than open mesh repair.
Mesh is secured carefully to triangle of doom.
Mesh is secured carefully to triangle of pain.
Surgeon's age less than 55 years is a predictive factor for success.
Surgical site located above iliopubic lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.
items.explanation: The recurrence rate after laparoscopic humeral repair is lower than that with open mesh repair techniques because laparoscopic methods allow better visualization and precise placement of the mesh, reducing the risk of hernia recurrence.

items.question: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy during pregnancy:
options: The procedure can safely be performed as late as 20 weeks.
The operation is best performed during the first trimester if possible.
Uterus height reaches the umbilicus at 20 weeks.
Placement of the Veress needle in the upper left quadrant is essential for all the procedures.
items.explanation: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy during pregnancy is considered safe when performed up to 20 weeks gestation. Performing surgery later in pregnancy increases risk to the fetus due to uterine size and reduced space for safe instrument manipulation. The procedure should preferably be performed in the second trimester for optimal safety.

items.question: The most appropriate treatment for a duodenal hematoma is:
options: Exploratory laparotomy and bypass of the duodenum.
Exploratory laparotomy and repair of the duodenum.
Exploratory laparotomy and debridement of associated injuries.
items.explanation: Duodenal hematomas, especially if caused by blunt trauma, often resolve with conservative management. Endoscopic treatment, such as dilation or drainage, is less invasive and effective at relieving obstruction caused by the hematoma, thus is considered appropriate before invasive surgery is considered.

items.question: What are the following statements about locally advanced pancreatic cancer treated with chemoradiation therapy is TRUE?
options: Just before the tumor is admitted to the ER with a stab wound, a local wound does not bleed and he is in shock. The first step of local wound care is ligation.
Because an incomplete hemostasis causes bleeding, use clamps and ligature to control bleeding.
Use clamps and ligature to control bleeding.
Push the patient to the operating room to control bleeding.
Apply compression of the bleeding vessel with a gloved finger.
items.explanation: According to the text, the first step in local wound care when a patient is admitted to the ER with a stab wound and is in shock is to apply compression of the bleeding vessel with a gloved finger. The other options do not follow the recommended initial management of local bleeding.

items.question: All of the following may be appropriate in the management of portal vein injury EXCEPT:
options: All of the following may be appropriate in the management of portal vein injury.
items.explanation: The correct approach to portal vein injury management includes direct venography and vascular anastomoses (both end-to-end and end-to-side). Portal vein ligation is generally not appropriate due to the critical nature of portal venous flow and the risk of complications.

items.question: The main treatment of a patient with suspected air embolism is:
options: Place the patient in Trendelenburg position
Place the patient in a right lateral decubitus position
Place the patient in a Trendelenburg and left lateral decubitus positions
items.explanation: The treatment of a patient with suspected air embolism involves positioning the patient to prevent the air embolus from entering vital circulation. Placing the patient in Trendelenburg and left lateral decubitus positions helps trap air in the right heart, reducing systemic embolism risk. Other choices either do not provide the best positioning or involve immediate heparinisation, which is not the primary treatment.

items.question: Answer true or false: ASSCVC line is a 10 cm long line involving either a venous 30% to 50% chance that they already incorporate large sized pump, are inserted into superior vena cava and left atrium.
items.explanation: The statement is false because ASSCVC line involves the venous system but not specifically the left atrium and does not inherently have a 30% to 50% chance of complications involving large sized pumps; the description in the statement is inaccurate and misleading with respect to standard catheter placement and associated risks.

items.question: All of the following neoplasms have been associated with AIDS EXCEPT:
items.explanation: Basal cell carcinoma is a common skin cancer but is not particularly associated with AIDS. In contrast, AIDS lymphoma, Burkitt's lymphoma, Kaposi's sarcoma, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma are well-recognized neoplasms associated with HIV/AIDS due to immunosuppression.

items.question: The clinical presentation of AIDS-related Kaposi's is divided into three categories, one of which is:
items.explanation: In the text, it states that AIDS-related Kaposi's is divided into three categories, one of which is ABC MCQS part II. The other options are examples of opportunistic infections or conditions associated with AIDS but not listed as one of the categories of Kaposi's disease.

items.question: The most common site of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in AIDS patients is:
items.explanation: The text indicates that non-Hodgkin lymphoma in AIDS patients often involves the CNS (central nervous system) either as primary or secondary involvement, making it a common site.

items.question: HIV presents a distinctive extranodal presentation in:
items.explanation: The passage highlights that HIV presents a distinctive extranodal presentation in PCNSL, an important HIV-associated lymphoma.

items.question: Kaposi’s sarcoma early lesions can be easily mistaken clinically for:
items.explanation: The text states that early Kaposi’s sarcoma lesions can be mistaken clinically for purpura, hemangiomas, and angiomas, making both B and D the correct answer.

items.question: Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is shown not to increase:
items.explanation: HAART has not been shown to increase the incidence of early Kaposi's sarcoma but rather helps reduce it by restoring immune function.

items.question: The World Health Organization has found which percentage of AIDS-related Kaposi’s sarcoma in more than one site:
items.explanation: According to the text, the World Health Organization has found AIDS-related Kaposi’s sarcoma to be present in more than one site in 9% of cases.

items.question: Regarding liver transplant patient information, patients from ABC MCQs have incomplete information. Which virus (HCV) which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Viral hepatocyte transplantation and liver biopsy is effective
Interferon and ribavirin therapy is effective
Prevention treatment of infection with HCV occurs in only 30% patients
Immediate angioram to rule out arterial occlusion
Adequate administration of high-dose steroids to treat rejection
items.explanation: Interferon and ribavirin therapy is endorsed as effective for managing HCV infections. Viral hepatocyte transplantation and liver biopsy are not standard methods for complete management, and immediate angiogram is not directly related to viral hepatitis. Administration of high-dose steroids is primarily for rejection and not viral infection prevention.

items.question: Which of the following would exclude a patient from pancreas transplantation?
options: History of hypoglycemic unawareness without end-organ damage
History of coronary artery bypass grafting
History of lower extremity peripheral vascular disease
items.explanation: Peripheral vascular disease, especially involving the lower extremities, is a contraindication for pancreas transplantation due to poor vascular supply and higher surgical risk. History of hypoglycemic unawareness is actually an indication for pancreas transplant, as is diabetes. Prior coronary artery bypass grafting and liver cirrhosis also do not necessarily exclude patients from pancreas transplant evaluations.

items.question: Which statement about post-liver transplant autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is correct?
options: Most common cause of liver transplant failure worldwide
Clinical presentation mirrors that of original AIH
Most patients present within days of transplantation
Effective antiviral therapy is the treatment
items.explanation: Post-liver transplant autoimmune hepatitis mimics the original disease clinically and histologically. It usually presents over weeks to months, not days. It is not the most common cause of transplant failure worldwide, and antiviral therapy is not a treatment for this condition as it is an autoimmune disease.

items.question: Which of the following is true about kidney transplantation?
options: A transplant kidney shows acute tubular necrosis (ATN) within 12 hours after surgery
Transplant kidney function improves within 1 hour post-transplant
Kidney transplant rejection is most often antibody mediated
Hypertension in transplant patients is rare
Revascularization is necessary in all patients
items.explanation: Acute kidney transplant rejection is often antibody mediated (humoral rejection). Acute tubular necrosis may cause delayed graft function but develops several days after transplant rather than within 12 hours. Kidney transplant function does not rapidly normalize within 1 hour as injury and recovery take more time. Hypertension is common post-transplant due to multiple causes including medication effects.

items.question: Which organ transplant is most commonly complicated by cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection?
items.explanation: Lung transplants have the highest risk for cytomegalovirus infection due to the airway's exposure nature and required immunosuppression. Bone marrow transplant also has significant CMV risk, but lung transplant ranks higher in frequency.

items.question: 5. Which of the following statements regarding T cells is INCORRECT?
options: Fetal nodal thymus, thymus aplasia greater than 5 cm.
Trymphocytes develop and 95% of patients in this group ultimately require insulin replacement therapy.
items.explanation: Glycogen storage disorders are not related to T cell abnormalities. The other options are linked to T cell function and thymus development. The thymus is critical in T cell development, and issues like thymus aplasia or giant hemangiomas may be related to T cell abnormalities. Pneumocystis pneumonia is a common opportunistic infection associated with T-cell immunodeficiency.

items.question: 8. Which of the following statements regarding the effects of transfusion of blood products during the perioperative period is TRUE?
options: Platelet cells can be activated to produce antibodies.
Helper T cells activate B cells by producing specific antibodies to the cell surface specific monoclonal antibodies.
The risk of statin-induced rhabdomyolysis and myopathy is higher in the perioperative period.
Unlike beta-blocker therapy, rebound phenomena is not observed in statin withdrawal therapy.
Postoperative myocardial events in patients on chronic statin therapy are more likely to be ST-elevation myocardial infarcts.
items.explanation: Beta-blocker withdrawal can cause rebound phenomena, whereas statin withdrawal generally does not cause rebound effects. Statins help reduce perioperative risks, and their abrupt discontinuation is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular events. Platelets themselves do not produce antibodies; helper T cells activate B cells which produce antibodies.

items.question: 9. Postoperative pulmonary complications for chronic acid suppression increase the risk of which of the following?
items.explanation: Chronic acid suppression increases gastric pH, which can lead to bacterial overgrowth and increased risk of aspiration pneumonia postoperatively. Gastric cancer and esophageal cancer are not directly linked to postoperative acid suppression. Cholangitis and basal cell cancer are unrelated complications.

items.question: 10. An 18-year-old boy is about to have an excision biopsy of a lesion on the right index finger. What surgical skin preparation solution is most appropriate?
items.explanation: Povidone-iodine is commonly used as a surgical skin preparation solution for excision biopsy because of its broad spectrum of antimicrobial activity and suitability for skin antisepsis. 10% chlorhexidine is used but povidone-iodine is preferred in some surgeries. Alcohol iodide and benzoyl peroxide are less appropriate for surgical prep.

items.question: 11. Which of the following statements regarding Bowen disease is TRUE?
options: 1. Bowen disease is only associated with wide local excision.
HIV positive status does not increase risk.
Bowen disease is rarely reported in literature.
items.explanation: Bowen disease is an early form of squamous cell carcinoma in situ, and treatment often involves wide local excision to ensure complete removal. HIV positive status increases risk of skin cancers, so B is false. It affects both men and women, though literature suggests slightly more in women.

items.question: 12. A 37-year-old man has a 40% total body surface area partial thickness burn. Which of the following is a TRUE statement about topical therapy of his wounds?
options: Chlorhexidine is indicated for deep burns.
Silver nitrate is indicated to prevent Pseudomonas colonization.
Silver nitrate should be avoided due to significant electrolyte loss.
Chlorhexidine is indicated for burns to the ears or nose.
Silver sulfadiazine is indicated for facial burns.
items.explanation: Silver nitrate can cause significant electrolyte loss and should be used cautiously. Silver sulfadiazine is commonly used for burns but its use on facial burns may be avoided due to crystallization. Chlorhexidine is not typically used for deep burns or sensitive areas such as ears or nose.

items.question: A 6-month history of an ulcerative nodular lesion 15 cm in diameter is involving the left arm. The lesion is biopsy proven to be malignant melanoma. The preferred treatment is?
items.explanation: The preferred treatment for a nodular malignant melanoma is excision with clinical margins to ensure complete removal and reduce the risk of local recurrence. Amputation is generally reserved for cases where wide excision is not feasible or the lesion is very advanced. Excision with 1 cm margin may be inadequate for larger lesions, and topical or cryotherapy treatments are not recommended for invasive melanoma.

items.question: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy in the United States. At presentation treatment is provided by complete excision and what reconstruction option?
items.explanation: Mohs micrographic surgery is the preferred method for treatment of basal cell carcinoma due to its tissue-sparing approach and high cure rates. This technique involves excision of the tumor with immediate microscopic examination of margins to ensure complete removal, followed by reconstruction such as primary closure or flap as needed.

items.question: A 12-year-old boy has multiple skin lesions that are easily bruised. He has ataxia, hypogonadism, and telangiectasia. What autosomal recessive malignant syndrome (AT) is TRUE of this condition?
options: It is characterized by atrioventricular malformation
It is associated with large intestinal Polyposis
It is a benign skin condition
items.explanation: Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a triad of ataxia, telangiectasia, and immune deficiencies. Patients often present with neurological symptoms and increased cancer risk, especially lymphoid malignancies. The disease is caused by mutations in the ATM gene.

items.question: A 15-year-old female undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy in the supine position and her exam shows a wedge-shaped, hypodense lesion in the posterior liver segments. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
items.explanation: After laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a wedge-shaped hypodense liver lesion likely represents a liver laceration or hematoma. An initial ultrasound is a safe, non-invasive, and cost-effective modality to further evaluate such lesions. CT or MRI may be used if ultrasound findings are inconclusive or if clinical deterioration occurs.

items.question: According to the published data, what would be the most appropriate management of diverticulum noted on the laparoscope in a patient with acute cholecystitis?
items.explanation: The published data indicate that diverticulum noted during laparoscopic examination of the gallbladder in acute cholecystitis does not require specific intervention. The most appropriate management is no intervention.

items.question: Laparoscopic appendectomy for acute appendicitis in an unventful patient confirmed by post-operative specimen shows perforated appendicitis with periappendiceal abscess. What therapy is recommended at the clinic visit?
options: Right hemicolectomy + 2 cm margin radical tumor excision.
items.explanation: In cases of perforated appendicitis with abscess identified post-operatively, adjuvant chemotherapy is recommended to address potential microscopic disease and prevent recurrence.

items.question: A 52-year-old woman with a BMI of 45 undergoes a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most serious postoperative complication is?
items.explanation: Morbid obesity (BMI 45) puts the patient at higher risk for pulmonary complications, especially pulmonary embolism due to venous stasis and decreased mobility post-surgery. It is the most serious complication post laparoscopic cholecystectomy in this patient.

items.question: Compared with open appendectomy, patients undergoing laparoscopic appendectomy have the following except?
options: Higher rates of surgical site infection.
items.explanation: Laparoscopic appendectomy generally results in shorter hospital stay, less pain, lower rates of ileus, and faster return to work compared to open appendectomy. An equivalent hospital length of stay does not occur, making option A the exception.

items.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding bile duct injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
options: Bile duct injuries occur in approximately 0.3% of cases.
ERC is the standard of care urgently after injury.
Bile duct injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy corresponds to injury to the cystic artery.
IOC is the standard of care for diagnosis of bile duct injury.
items.explanation: Bile duct injuries occur in approximately 0.3% of laparoscopic cholecystectomy cases. Intraoperative cholangiography (IOC) is helpful but not uniformly standard; early repair strategies depend on injury type. The bile duct injury does not correspond with cystic artery injury, and timely management is key.

items.question: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor of pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
items.explanation: The resectability of the tumor is the most important prognostic factor in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, as surgery offers the only chance for cure or long-term survival, while other factors like size and location affect resectability.

items.question: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for soft tissue sarcoma?
items.explanation: Histologic grading reflects the degree of anaplasia and proliferative activity, which histologic grading seems to have prognostic value. Grading has been of little predictive value in soft tissue sarcoma. Although tumor size, stage, tumor sites, and histologic type may influence prognosis, histologic grading is the most important prognostic factor for soft tissue sarcoma.

items.question: A 40-year-old female patient is worried about estrogen replacement therapy (ERT). Which of the following replacement therapy may be the best choice as a secondary to the intake of estrogen replacement therapy?
items.explanation: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that antagonizes estrogen effects in breast tissue, making it the best choice for estrogen replacement therapy to reduce the risk associated with breast cancer. Other options listed do not have the same protective anti-estrogenic effects on breast tissue.

items.question: Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents may be used for estrogen- and progesterone receptor-positive advanced breast cancer?
items.explanation: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer, especially in estrogen- and progesterone receptor-positive tumors. It works as an alkylating agent, causing DNA cross-linking and impairing replication.

items.question: Which of the following is the commonest cause of unilateral axillary lymphadenopathy?
items.explanation: Breast carcinoma is the most common cause of unilateral axillary lymphadenopathy because the lymphatics from the breast drain primarily to the axillary lymph nodes.

items.question: For which of the following malignancies does histological diagnosis hold great importance?
items.explanation: Histological diagnosis is particularly important in colon cancer for grading and staging. Accurate histologic diagnosis assists in planning treatment and predicting patient outcomes.

items.question: Which of the following is the urinary bladder malignant tumor?
items.explanation: Transitional cell carcinoma, also known as urothelial carcinoma, is the most common malignant tumor of the urinary bladder.

items.question: A 59-year-old woman with a leaking silicone breast implant presented with a breast mass. Which of the following is likely to occur following a leaking silicone breast implant?
options: Gross cystic disease of the breast
items.explanation: Leaking silicone implants can cause an inflammatory reaction resulting in granulomatous mastitis, a granulomatous inflammation of the breast tissue.

items.question: A 50-year-old female patient is going to have a silicone breast implant. Which of the following is most likely to be complications of this implant?
items.explanation: The most common complication of silicone breast implants is capsular contracture, which involves fibrosis and contracture of the capsule formed around the implant.

items.question: Most common cancers associated with paraneoplastic syndromes include?
items.explanation: Paraneoplastic syndromes most commonly occur in malignancies of the ovary, breast, kidney (renal), and lung.

items.question: A 64-year-old woman who underwent a mastectomy 2 years ago for locally advanced breast cancer now presents to the emergency department with rapidly enlarging mass at the mastectomy site. Clinical examination is disrupting tight adherence of the mass to the chest wall and chest skin is involved. What is the most likely to identify the causative and stuporous. Which test is best to be performed in this case?
items.explanation: Locally advanced breast cancer frequently metastasizes to bone causing hypercalcemia. Serum calcium determination is the best initial test to identify hypercalcemia as the cause of the symptoms. Other listed tests are not useful for this clinical presentation.

items.question: A 45-year-old patient presents to your office with rapidly enlarging mass in the left breast diagnosed as breast cancer. She has undergone many times in the past 5 years receiving multiple cycles of a drug ABC. Which of the following is the best treatment of choice?
items.explanation: In locally advanced breast cancer, breast conserving surgery (BCS) with chemotherapy is a preferred option when possible to reduce tumor size and limit disease spread. Complete excision alone is often insufficient without systemic therapy.

items.question: A postmenopausal woman undergoes mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection for invasive duct carcinoma of the breast. Biopsy shows SLNB (sentinel lymph node biopsy) negative for a new diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Which of the following receptor/protein expressions is negative in this patient?
items.explanation: A negative sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) indicates no metastatic spread to lymph nodes. Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor testing helps guide adjuvant therapy. Here, receptor/protein expression is negative for hormonal receptors, influencing treatment options.

items.question: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a lumpectomy and local radiation for a malignant tumor of the breast. The margins are clear, and some carcinoma of the left breast. The margins are clear and margins confirmed negative with no evidence of residual disease. What adjunct therapy should be advised?
items.explanation: For early stage breast cancer treated with lumpectomy and radiation, adjuvant chemotherapy and tamoxifen in hormone receptor positive cases are standard to reduce recurrence and improve survival. Radiotherapy alone or surgery alone is usually insufficient.

items.question: Which of the following statements about the lymphatic system related to breast cancer is true?
options: It is closely related to risk of breast cancer
It is defined by the presence of malignant cells
It determines the stage of cancer
It forms the primary route of tumor spread
It is unaffected in early breast cancer
items.explanation: The lymphatic system forms the primary route for the regional spread of breast cancer cells to lymph nodes. Assessment of lymphatic involvement is critical in staging and prognosis. Early involvement of lymph nodes often indicates advanced disease.

items.question: An elevation in which one of the following is most specific for a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma?
items.explanation: An elevation of catecholamine levels in 24-hour urine is most specific for diagnosing pheochromocytoma because pheochromocytomas are tumors that produce excess catecholamines. Other options such as free thyroxine, TSH, or TRAb are related to thyroid function or autoimmune thyroid disorders, and technetium peroxidase enzyme is not relevant to pheochromocytoma diagnosis.

items.question: Which of the following is the most accurate in the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma?
items.explanation: The plasma metanephrine level is the most accurate test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma. Plasma metanephrines are the metabolites of catecholamines and their levels are elevated even when catecholamines fluctuate, providing a highly sensitive and specific diagnostic marker.

items.question: A 58-year-old lady presents with the acute onset of erythema and edema in her left breast. She was treated with hormonal therapy for primary breast cancer 5 years prior. A mammogram shows skin edema and a mass like plaque involving erythema of the left breast skin. Punch biopsy reveals malignancy consistent with breast carcinoma. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
options: Simple mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy and monoclonal antibody therapy
items.explanation: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) presents with rapid development of erythema and edema, often mimicking infection. Treatment requires neoadjuvant chemotherapy and monoclonal antibody therapy to address the aggressive nature of the disease before surgery. Surgery or radiation alone is not sufficient initially.

items.question: Which of the following is the most common sign of Cushing syndrome?
items.explanation: Progressive truncal obesity is the most common symptom of Cushing syndrome, though not specific. Other symptoms such as proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, acne, and puffiness are also seen, but the hallmark and most common early sign is progressive central obesity due to cortisol's effects on fat distribution.

items.question: A 33-year-old woman is scheduled for elective thyroid surgery for a thyroid nodule. Which of the following statements regarding the presence of moderate hypothyroidism shows the most appropriate management of hypothyroidism?
options: Surgery should be deferred until hypothyroid state is achieved
Presence of surgery until euthyroid state is achieved
Hypothyroid state with symptoms are not surgery contraindicated
Presence diagnosis and treatment for hypothyroidism
Euthyroid symptoms and surgery as early as possible
items.explanation: Mild to moderate hypothyroidism is a diagnosis that applies to patients preparing for surgery. It does not necessarily require a delay for thyroid hormone replacement therapy before surgery. If a patient is not severely hypothyroid and shows no signs of myxedema or heart failure, mild to moderate hypothyroidism can be managed without postponing surgery, though close monitoring is necessary. Severe hypothyroidism or myxedema requires deferring surgery until the patient is euthyroid.

items.question: You have a patient who has pheochromocytoma and his preoperative preparation includes alpha and beta-blockade. Which of the following is the most appropriate preparation for surgery? Which of the following is not appropriate?
options: Patient with pheochromocytoma control of blood pressure
items.explanation: In the surgical preparation of pheochromocytoma, alpha blockade is initiated first to control hypertension caused by catecholamine excess, followed by beta-blockade to control tachycardia. Calcium channel blockers are not routinely used preoperatively in pheochromocytoma and may not be sufficient alone. ACE inhibitors like captopril can be adjuncts but are not primary agents for preoperative preparation.

items.question: 40-year-old female patient complains of increasing fatigue, dry voice, hoarseness, cold intolerance, cold weather intolerance, and constipation accompanied by swelling of the face and hands. Laboratory tests revealed low levels of TSH and T4. What is the likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: The patient's symptoms suggest hypothyroidism, but the laboratory finding of low TSH and low T4 indicates secondary hypothyroidism (central hypothyroidism). Primary hypothyroidism would typically show elevated TSH due to negative feedback. The low TSH here means a pituitary or hypothalamic cause, which is secondary hypothyroidism.

items.question: Hypothyroidism causes include all of the following except?
items.explanation: Hypothyroidism is characterized by deficient production or action of thyroid hormone. Hyperthyroidism is the opposite condition characterized by excessive thyroid hormone. Therefore, hyperthyroidism does not cause hypothyroidism.

items.question: Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by?
items.explanation: In primary hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland fails to produce sufficient thyroid hormones, leading to low T4 levels. The pituitary gland reacts by increasing TSH secretion to stimulate the thyroid, so TSH levels are elevated.

items.question: After thyroidectomy, patients need supplementation with?
items.explanation: After thyroidectomy, the thyroid gland is removed and patients cannot produce thyroid hormones, so they require replacement therapy with thyroxine (T4) to maintain normal metabolism.

items.question: The most likely cause for her symptoms is bilateral and are characterized by hyperplastic adrenal tissue. Although chromaffin cells frequently invade the adrenal capsule and surround the adrenal medullary arteries, the masses are confined to the adrenal medulla. Which of the following?
items.explanation: The symptoms described are characteristic of pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes catecholamines, predominantly epinephrine. The invasion of chromaffin cells and confinement to the adrenal medulla supports pheochromocytoma diagnosis.

items.question: A 22-year-old woman is being evaluated for a thyroid nodule. She is noted to have a history of urethral obstruction, headaches, and diarrhea. She is from a family in which papillary thyroid cancer and primary hyperparathyroidism are present. Serum calcium is high and parathyroid hormone levels are elevated. Five members of the patient's family developed medullary thyroid cancer. Serum calcitonin is > 2000 pg/ml after pentagastrin administration. A total thyroidectomy and parathyroidectomy with central lymph node dissection are performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Serum thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels
items.explanation: The clinical presentation and family history consistent with medullary thyroid cancer and elevated serum calcitonin levels following pentagastrin stimulation strongly support diagnosis of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma secretion of calcitonin.

items.question: A 48-year-old woman with breast cancer diagnosed five years ago is admitted with hypotension. Her serum calcium is 14 mg/dL and phosphorus is 1.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the correct first line of treatment?
items.explanation: Hypercalcemia is common in patients with malignancy, often due to bone metastases or PTHrP secretion. Initial management includes aggressive intravenous hydration with isotonic saline to restore intravascular volume and enhance renal calcium excretion, followed by bisphosphonate therapy.

items.question: Which of the following conditions is associated with a familial adenomatous polyposis?
items.explanation: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is characterized by the development of numerous polyps in the colon and rectum during adolescence or early adulthood. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and involves mutations in the APC gene, leading to a predisposition to colon cancer if untreated. It is distinct from Lynch syndrome, which involves mismatch repair gene mutations. BRCA1 gene mutations are primarily associated with breast and ovarian cancers, not familial adenomatous polyposis.

items.question: A definitive increased risk of developing colon cancer is associated with which of the following?
items.explanation: Adenomatous colon polyps are recognized as precancerous lesions that increase the risk of colorectal cancer. These polyps can undergo malignant transformation, especially if they are large, numerous, or display advanced histological features such as villous architecture or high-grade dysplasia. Ulcerative colitis also increases colorectal cancer risk but is categorized differently. Diverticulitis and pseudomembranous colitis do not have a confirmed direct association with increased colorectal cancer risk. Previous appendectomy is not linked to colon cancer risk.

items.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for an iatrogenic colon perforation?
items.explanation: Iatrogenic perforation of the colon often requires surgical intervention. Laparotomy allows for direct access to the abdominal cavity to identify and repair the perforation, control contamination, and manage any associated complications. This approach is preferred over conservative treatments like antibiotics or drainage alone because of the high risk of peritonitis and sepsis from fecal contamination. Hemicolectomy or colostomy might be performed during laparotomy if there is extensive damage, whereas CT-guided drainage is limited to localized abscesses.

items.question: A 50-year-old male patient presented with diffuse abdominal pain, vomiting, and distension. Exam revealed abdominal distension, generalized tenderness, and rigidity. Chest X-ray showed air under the diaphragm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
items.explanation: The presentation of diffuse abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal rigidity, and the presence of free air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray is consistent with a perforated hollow viscus, typically gastrointestinal perforation. This is a surgical emergency requiring exploratory laparotomy to identify and repair the perforation. Delay in surgical intervention can lead to worsening peritonitis and sepsis. Supportive measures like fluid resuscitation and antibiotics are essential but must be combined with surgical treatment.

items.question: A 65-year-old man undergoes a technically difficult low anterior resection for sigmoid colon cancer (53). A temporary loop ileostomy is created but he is left with a low rectal anastomosis which receives 3 units of packed red blood cells. Four days later, he develops abdominal pain and fever, with clinical signs of septic shock. Abdominal imaging reveals only a large pelvic collection above the urinary bladder. Sigmoid colonoscopy is made with the colonoscope above it. Low rectal wound emergency, colostomy is treated with the abdominal drainage tube and appropriate antibiotics. The extent of necrosis and bleeding from his perineal wound. Emergency colostomy and bleeding times. The prior degradation coagulation products are not considered because activated fibrinolysis is the biological mechanism. In this patient, the plague count is 70,000/µL. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation?
items.explanation: A 65-year-old woman presents to casualty with a 24-hour history of old pain, fever, and chills after low anterior resection with ileostomy. She has been undergoing the long operation and most complications could be peritonitis, abscess, or anastomosis leakage. CT scan confirms signs of pelvic abscess. A CT scan can detect the presence of abscess, fluid collections, and other complications after colorectal surgery. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in early postoperative period due to risk of perforation. Blood culture and plain X-ray have limited sensitivity. Thus, CT scan is the most appropriate investigation in this setting.

items.question: A 30-year-old male patient complains of recurrence complaints of frequency of bleeding per rectum. He has undergone previous abdominal surgery. The most likely cause for his complaint is?
items.explanation: A 30-year-old male with complaints of recurrent bleeding per rectum and history of abdominal surgery is likely to have solitary rectal ulcer syndrome. This condition presents with bleeding per rectum, mucus discharge, and straining. Solitary rectal ulcer is a common cause of bleeding per rectum in young adults and should be considered in differential diagnosis. Colonic carcinoma and diverticulitis are less likely due to age and clinical presentation. Colonic abscess and ascariasis are also unlikely.

items.question: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a long-standing history of dyspnea and cough with foul-smelling sputum. On examination, clubbing and right-sided pleural effusion are noted. CT chest shows a cavity with thick walls in the right upper lobe. What is the most appropriate next step?
items.explanation: In a patient with chronic productive cough, foul-smelling sputum, and cavitary lung lesion with pleural effusion, the next step is bronchoscopy. This allows visualization, sampling of sputum, and ruling out malignancy. Sputum culture can be misleading if contamination occurs. Empirical antibiotics should be guided by culture. CT-guided biopsy is riskier and usually not first line. Pulmonary angiography is typically not indicated initially.

items.question: 54. A 21-year-old man underwent colonoscopy for many episodes of rectal bleeding. He had over 100 polyps scattered throughout colon and rectum. Biopsy from the polyps proved to be an adenomatous polyp containing dysplastic cells. His family history is negative for polyposis syndromes. What is the most appropriate treatment at this time?
items.explanation: The patient likely has Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) given multiple adenomatous polyps (>100) throughout the colon and rectum, despite no family history. The standard treatment for FAP with rectal preservation is abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis to remove most polyps but preserve the rectum if it remains healthy. Total proctocolectomy is reserved for cases with rectal involvement or severe dysplasia. Polypectomy alone is insufficient due to risk of malignancy.

items.question: 55. A 21-year-old woman has ulcerative colitis admitted to the hospital because of fever, bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. During the second day of hospitalization, abdominal X-ray showed a transverse colon diameter of 7 cm. The patient is admitted to the ICU. What is the treatment of choice?
items.explanation: The patient has toxic megacolon (transverse colon diameter > 6 cm with systemic toxicity) secondary to ulcerative colitis. Treatment requires prompt total proctocolectomy with end ileostomy as medical management is unlikely to be successful and delay increases mortality risk. Surgery is the definitive therapy in such fulminant cases.

items.question: 56. Which of the following investigations has the highest sensitivity and specificity for detecting a colovesical fistula?
items.explanation: Computed tomography (CT) with contrast is the most sensitive and specific test to detect colovesical fistulas. It provides excellent anatomical detail revealing the fistula, inflammation, and any accompanying abscess. Other investigations like cystoscopy and barium enema have lower sensitivity.

items.question: 59. A 25-year-old man has recurrent, indolent fistulae of the anal region. He also complained of perianal skin lesion, fever, and stated family history is negative for inflammatory bowel disease. Colonoscopy revealed a healthy ileum and colon.
