IVP visualizes the upper tract but will not likely be helpful. Colonoscopy is done to rule out the colon tumor. CT scan confirms diagnosis.

items.question: A 59-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with recurrent pneumonia or air in the urine and recurrent urinary tract infections. She had a recent AAA repair. His blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse rate 90/min, and temperature 37 C. Which of the following tests would confirm the diagnosis?
items.explanation: Answer: C. CASE FILES Surgery 4th p280, 283: The diagnosis of colovesical fistula and to localize the infected tract after AAA repair. The IVP will likely not be helpful because there is no ureteral injury. The colon and bladder biopsies are used to rule out colon cancer.

items.question: A 4-year-old male admitted to the intensive care unit for ventilator management after AAA repair. His heart rate 100 bpm, temperature 35 C and his serum PO2 level is low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Acute coronary syndrome with cardiogenic shock
items.explanation: Answer: A. CASE FILES Surgery 4th p280, 283: Low PO2, low temperature, and respiratory distress in a post surgical patient are suggestive of pneumothorax.

items.question: 27. A 45-year-old female underwent modified radical mastectomy for left breast cancer and was hospitalized for 15 days. On the second postoperative day, she developed lethargy, tachypnea, and left-sided chest pain. Chest X-ray showed left lung collapse. What is the likely secured nerve?
items.explanation: Long thoracic nerve

items.question: 28. Which of the following is the most likely complication following inferior vena cava filter insertion?
items.explanation: Pulmonary embolism

items.question: 29. A 43-year-old man was admitted for two weeks' duration of progressive left upper limb weakness and numbness with the history of tuberculosis and is diagnosed as reactive infected necrotic disc with paraspinal abscess. One the following is the most appropriate investigation for diagnosis?
items.explanation: Tuberculosis culture is the most appropriate investigation

items.question: 30. A 47-year-old man after a car accident is admitted to ICU with renal trauma. Renal trauma is graded in 5 grades with grade I to V. The following are complications of grade III renal injuries, except:
items.explanation: Ischemic necrosis is not a common complication of grade III renal injuries

items.question: 31. All of the following are causes of gastric ulcer, except:
items.explanation: Trauma is not a cause of gastric ulcer

items.question: 33. Most common cause of perforations in adult male is:
items.explanation: As in adult males, peptic ulcer perforation is the most common cause of perforations in the gastrointestinal tract.

items.question: 34. Apart from abdominal pain, factor most common clinical presentation in acute suppurative bacterial cholangitis is:
items.explanation: Acute suppurative bacterial cholangitis typically presents with fever and jaundice.

items.question: 35. Which of the following causes least irritation of the biliary tract?
items.explanation: Gastric enzymes cause the least irritation of the biliary tract compared to bile acids, bile, blood, or pus.

items.question: 36. Which of the following complications is not seen with acute suppurative cholangitis?
items.explanation: Pancreatitis is generally not seen as a complication of acute suppurative cholangitis, while renal failure, peritonitis, radio hypo suppression, and shock may occur.

items.question: 37. A 9-year-old female who used to use the swimming pool regularly complained of abdominal pain on examination, abdomen was tender with mild guarding and rigidity of abdominal wall. The most likely diagnosis is:
items.explanation: In a young female with abdominal pain, tenderness, mild guarding and rigidity and history of using the swimming pool, perforated acute appendicitis is the most likely diagnosis.

items.question: Most common organ involved in retroperitoneal fibrosis
items.explanation: Answer: B Surgery Essences p371

items.question: Which is the most common mesenteric cyst?
items.explanation: Answer: B Surgery Essences p371

items.question: Necrotizing fasciitis: Which is true
options: Caused by anaerobic and aerobic bacteria
Necrotizing inflammation of necrotic tissue is caused by fungi
Definitive diagnosis by biopsy and excision
items.explanation: Answer: B Surgery Essences p1087

items.question: A common cause of mesenteric ischemia is
items.explanation: Answer: D Surgery Essences p1086

items.question: Which is not true of cysticercosis?
items.explanation: Answer: D Surgery Essences p1088

items.question: Which of the following patients would be most at risk of surgical wound infection?
options: Patient with severe and extensive burn
Patient who will be in hospital for long time
items.explanation: Review of surgery 3rd 204

items.question: A 65-yr-old man presents at the Outpatients with a chronic leg ulcer that has been present for 10 days after undergoing a Hernia repair. He has a temperature of 37.0°C. Which organism is most likely to be the cause of this surgical site infection?
items.explanation: The causative organism in most probably Staphylococcus aureus. This is the most common organism causing surgical site infection. The other options are less commonly responsible for surgical site infection.

items.question: Which of the following requires mostly stress ulcer prophylaxis?
options: 45-year old man with a femur fracture
56-year-old woman with a left hemispheric stroke on central feeds
A 65-year-old man who is hemodynamically normal after an acute myocardial infarction
items.explanation: A patient with severe sepsis or septic shock should have stress ulcer prophylaxis. Patients who do not manifest a coagulopathy do not require specific prophylaxis. Patients who are normotensive do not require stress ulcer prophylaxis.

items.question: 53. Use of Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangio drainage (PTCD) in obstructive jaundice is
items.explanation: PTCD whether requires stress stress-ictoc or wikipidia. It is a bedside procedure for drainage in malignant obstruction, bile duct obstruction, cholangitis, prophylaxis. Since percutaneous drainage is slow, other measures such as ERCP and internal nutrition is tolerated, prophylaxis can be stopped.

items.question: 54. Anticoagulant therapy during pregnancy is
options: Required in patients with pulmonary embolism
items.explanation: Anticoagulant therapy is required only in patients with pulmonary embolism during pregnancy.

items.question: 55. A 28-year-old woman who is 6 months pregnant is admitted with acute heart failure. She has non invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV). Expected cardiovascular changes in pregnancy:
items.explanation: During pregnancy, cardiac output increases significantly because of increased heart rate and stroke volume. Physiologic changes lead to volume expansion and decreased systemic vascular resistance. These changes are well tolerated normally.

items.question: 56. The cardiovascular system undergoes significant predictable changes in pregnancy. The statement which is true regarding pregnancy is
items.explanation: The cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes including dilation of left atrium and left ventricle. Mean arterial pressure and systemic vascular resistance decrease, while heart rate increases.

items.question: 57. A 22 years old woman in her third trimester presents with dyspnoea and mild pedal edema. On examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg; pulse is 100/minute; jugular venous pressure is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
items.explanation: Pregnancy is associated with mild edema, increased blood volume leading to jugular venous distension. These are physiological changes and common in third trimester.

items.question: 58. Which of the following is the most important change in respiratory system due to pregnancy?
items.explanation: Functional residual capacity (FRC), residual volume (RV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV) decrease due to elevation of diaphragm by gravid uterus, while tidal volume and minute ventilation increase.

items.question: Recommended caloric requirements for critically ill patients with multiorgan system failure and a BMI less than 30
items.explanation: B is answer 15 KCal/kg/day

items.question: What is the common side effect of Propofol as a drug used commonly in ICU?
items.explanation: Hypertriglyceridemia

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding total body water is true? (2020 P.D)
options: Total body water accounts approximately 60% of total body weight in males.
Intracellular body water is 2/3rd total body weight in the human body.
Males individually have greater proportion of water (relative to their body weight) compared to females.
The percentage of total body water decreases with age.
The percentage of total body water increases with age.
items.explanation: Rationale: Total body water constitutes roughly 60% of total body weight in adults. Intracellular fluid constitutes about 40% of total body weight and is contained mostly within skeletal muscle. The percentage of total body water decreases with age and increased body fat.

items.question: 65. Which one of the following is NOT a stimulus for ECF loss?
options: Hemorrhage leading to a reduction in blood volume resulting in a decreased hydrostatic pressure.
Increased capillary permeability after major surgery resulting in an increase in protein concentration.
A reduction in serum albumin concentration resulting in a decrease in plasma colloid oncotic pressure.
Negative interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure resulting in more fluid loss.
Decrease in plasma sodium concentration resulting in a reduced plasma osmotic pressure.
items.explanation: Reduction of serum albumin concentration causes a decrease in colloid oncotic pressure, which would tend to reduce fluid loss to the interstitial spaces, thus it is NOT a stimulus for ECF loss.

items.question: 68. 3rd spacing of fluid is associated with which of the following clinical TPN related complications?
items.explanation:
Answer: B. ASITE MCQ 2 (Resp P103)
3rd spacing fluid is associated with ascites.

items.question: 69. Instead of an indwelling urinary catheter, this patient has a suprapubic catheter due to urethral stricture. The main risk of this catheter is:
items.explanation:
Answer: K. ASITE MCQ 2 (Resp P103)
Zinc deficiency results in poor wound granulation.

items.question: 70. Which of the following regarding burn wound depth evaluation is correct?
options: First-degree burns are generally painful and warm to touch
Second-degree burns are characterized by dry eschar formation and no blistering
Third-degree burns are painful and involve epidermis and dermis
Fourth-degree burns are superficial and affect epidermis and upper dermis
items.explanation:
Answer: B. Rus 5th p160
1st degree burns are generally painful and warm to touch.

items.question: 71. Which of the following is TRUE regarding care of burn wounds?
options: Applying silver sulfadiazine to burn wounds is recommended
A thicker eschar should be surgically removed
Excision and grafting should be avoided during acute phase
Burn wound infections are rare and should not be frequently cultured
items.explanation:
Answer: B. Rus 5th, p160
Eschar removal is required in thick eschar burns.

items.question: Which of the following patients do not meet the criteria for 1% TBSA partial-thickness burns?
options: A 45-year-old woman with 1% TBSA partial-thickness burns on both hands
A 30-year-old woman with 1% TBSA partial-thickness burns on the anterior and posterior torso
A 50-year-old woman with 1% TBSA partial-thickness burns on the anterior and posterior torso
An 8-year-old boy with a chemical burn of 1.2% TBSA
A 30-year-old construction worker with pain and blistering consistent with second-degree burns covering 10 square cm but involving less than 1% TBSA
items.explanation: An 8-year-old boy with a chemical burn of 1.2% TBSA is less than 2% TBSA the minimum burn size for children. The other patients all have >1% TBSA burns.

items.question: Which of the following statements regarding the zones of burn injury is TRUE?
options: A zone of hyperemia consists of tissue with a zone of coagulation surrounded by a zone of stasis
Hyperemia in the zone of coagulation is caused by a deep zone of injured small vessels surrounded by a zone of stasis
A properly managed zone of hyperemia will most likely become necrotic
Burn depth classification must be coagulated to prevent eschar formation and conversion
The pathophysiology of cutaneous thermal injury creates a zone of coagulation surrounded by a zone of stasis and a zone of hyperemia
items.explanation: The pathophysiology of cutaneous thermal injury creates a defined pathophysiology of zones of injury in 1953 referred to as a zone of coagulation surrounded by a zone of stasis and a zone of hyperemia.

items.question: 75- Which ones and full-thickness skin grafts is TRUE use of?
options: Full-thickness skin grafts do not return to areas that has considerable movement.
Split-thickness skin grafts are immediately revascularized.
Post-graft, all surfaces are immediately approximated.
Donor site of full-thickness grafts usually requires skin graft to close.
items.explanation: Split-thickness skin grafts are immediately revascularized. This is true because full-thickness skin grafts require more time and are less likely to revascularize immediately due to their thickness.

items.question: 78. A 66-year-old woman has a right femoral popliteal bypass graft with greater saphenous vein done for critical limb ischemia. She presents after 3 years with tissue loss 8 months distal to the distal anastomosis. The most appropriate management is
items.explanation: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) is the suggested treatment for a patient with asymptomatic critical limb ischemia and a failing lower extremity bypass graft. PTA carries less morbidity and mortality compared to graft revision or replacement.

items.question: 79. A 68-year-old man with an 8 months history of acute arterial insufficiency due to embolism from the left atrium. He is diabetic, weighing 65 kg, has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, received 60 units of insulin per day. How long after acute severe limb ischemia do you wait before considering amputation?
items.explanation: The amputation rate is higher after blunt injury than with five hours of ischemia; however, the common and superficial femoral artery is the usual site of the injury. Amputation is often delayed beyond the acute phase to allow viability assessment and possible revascularization. Waiting 4 years is not typical; the question focus is on the timing after injury before considering amputation, generally beyond several hours depending on clinical status.

items.question: 81. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the following figure (A) (atelectasis)?
options: Mesenteric ischemia due to aortoiliac atherosclerosis.
items.explanation: Mesenteric venous thrombosis typically shows a band-like increased density with mild bowel wall thickening, and venous thrombosis causes submucosal and intramural hemorrhage, indistinct bowel margins, ascites, and perfusion abnormalities such as dilated veins. It is usually associated with portal vein thrombosis and a history of prothrombotic states. In contrast, mesenteric arterial embolism and nonocclusive ischemia typically present more dramatically with bowel wall thickening and distinct ischemic changes. Ischemic colitis involves the left colon, whereas the figure shows the small bowel. Thus, mesenteric venous thrombosis is the most likely diagnosis.

items.question: 82. A 25-year-old man with a 2-week history of progressive exertional breathlessness and a past episode of transient hemiparesis is is diagnosed with pulmonary embolism. He is started on anticoagulants. Which of the following would be the most appropriate place to insert an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter?
options: Above the renal veins but below the hepatic veins.
Intravenous (intrarenal) at the left renal vein.
At the origin of the left iliac vein.
At the junction of the right iliac and the inferior vena cava.
items.explanation: An IVC filter is usually placed in the infrarenal segment of the inferior vena cava (above the renal veins but below the hepatic veins) to prevent emboli from the lower extremities reaching the heart and lungs. Placing the filter below the renal veins avoids hindering renal vein return or causing renal vein thrombosis. Placement at the renal veins, iliac veins, or right atrium is not appropriate and may have complications.

items.question: 83. What is the most reliable index of severity of pulmonary embolism?
options: Elevated right ventricular to left ventricular ratio on CT
Elevated partial pressure of oxygen on arterial blood gas
items.explanation: Elevated right ventricular to left ventricular (RV/LV) ratio on CT is a reliable marker of right heart strain and severity in pulmonary embolism. It correlates with increased mortality and the need for more aggressive therapy. A large central embolus causes severe obstruction but does not always correlate with severity. Ventilation-perfusion scans indicate the presence but not severity. Elevated D-dimer indicates clot presence but not severity. An elevated arterial oxygen partial pressure is not typical in pulmonary embolism, which usually causes hypoxemia.

items.question: 84. Calf that is insensate and thrombolytic therapy for acute limb ischemia, with an increased risk of peri procedural stroke:
options: Reversed autogenous saphenous vein graft only
His reduced amputation rate compared with open surgery
Has less mortality compared with open surgery
items.explanation: Answer: A. Casepilo (cites 0.28) given.

items.question: 85. Retroperitoneal exposure of the usual external iliac artery requires division of the sympathetic plexus:
options: Requires division of the sympathetic plexus
Exposes the psoas muscle and ureter off the peritoneum
Exposes the gonadal artery and ureter off the peritoneum
Exposes the common iliac artery and the inferior vena cava
Requires mobilisation of the femoral vein
items.explanation: Answer: C. Casepilo (cites 3.429).

items.question: 87. Five days post-transplant a patient develops a high fever, malaise, hepatic tenderness and oliguria. Blood cultures are positive for Escherichia coli. The most likely cause is
items.explanation: Infection usually occurs after 1 week but sepsis within the first week post renal transplant is usually due to the donor colonized from a donor unsterile or sepsis caused during surgery leading to oligemic or ischemic injury resulting in oliguria and ATN.

items.question: 88. The most common cause of morality after kidney transplant is
items.explanation: The most common cause of death after renal transplant is cardiovascular disease including myocardial infarction.

items.question: 91. A 53-year-old woman with a BMI of 41 presents to clinic 3 years following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) complaining of significant upper abdominal pain and has had multiple admissions for suspected ulcer disease. Endoscopy shows a gastric ulcer in the gastric pouch. Which of the following is the BEST management?
items.explanation: Laparoscopic revision of RYGB is the BEST option for this patient as failure again is common following the procedure.

items.question: 92. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) is performed routinely after bariatric surgery. Which of the following is indicated for clinically severe obesity benefits?
options: Calcium, folate, vitamin B6, vitamin B12
items.explanation: Calcium, folate, vitamin B6, vitamin B12 are important for deficiency monitoring post bariatric surgery.

items.question: 94. A 26-year-old woman presents two years after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery with symptoms of refractory nausea and vomiting. She has had multiple hospital admissions and investigations with no diagnosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Internal hernia is a well-recognized complication of RYGB, leading to recurrent abdominal symptoms.

items.question: 95. A 23-year-old patient with hypertension and increased initial treatment for a cystic tumor with which it is most likely to be associated?
items.explanation: Pheochromocytomas are tumors composed of chromaffin cells that produce catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine), resulting in paroxysmal or sustained hypertension. The patient’s clinical presentation of hypertension with a cystic tumor is most consistent with pheochromocytoma.

items.question: 96. A 65-year-old woman with intracardiac thrombus that later 2 weeks of conservative therapy appears to be persistent. The chest symptoms and ECG changes, which include one or more of the following management at this time includes which of the following procedures?
options: Neck exploration and ligation of the thoracic duct
Subdiaphragmatic ligation of the thoracic duct
Thoracotomy and repair of the thoracic duct
Thoracotomy and abrasion of the pleura
items.explanation: Thoracotomy and repair of the thoracic duct is indicated for persistent chylothorax when conservative management fails after 2 weeks. This allows direct repair of the leak and prevents continued loss of lymphatic fluid.

items.question: 97. A patient with flushing and paling of the extremities during exercise and absent radial pulses. These symptoms are most likely associated with?
items.explanation: Aortic coarctation is characterized by upper extremity hypertension, diminished or absent femoral pulses, and symptoms such as exercise-induced limb ischemia and absent radial pulses caused by impaired arterial flow.

items.question: A 65-year-old woman has had pain in her right shoulder and arm that has been treated with analgesics without relief. The patient and a new personal history experienced significant weight loss and loss of appetite. She also reports mild granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells in the pleural lesion and pleural effusion. Which of the following diseases does the most likely have?
items.explanation: Bronchogenic carcinomas that typically produce which of these diseases usually cause pain in the shoulder and arm, weight loss, and pleural effusion with multinucleated giant cells.

items.question: A 71-year-old man has had a cough with sputum. The chest X-ray shows a lung mass that demonstrates minimal granulomatous inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Adenocarcinoma of the lung typically produces granulomatous inflammation and sputum production.

items.question: A 43-year-old man seeks your advice regarding pain and weakness in the right arm and hand. He reports pain localized at the right radial pulse and paresthesias that increased with abduction of the right upper extremity. On physical examination, the right hand is pale and cold, and the radial pulse disappears when the patient's arm is abducted and externally rotated. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
items.explanation: Thoracic outlet syndrome presents with pain and paresthesia in the upper extremity due to compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. Surgical decompression to relieve the nerve or vascular compression is the best initial treatment.

items.question: A 30-year-old woman presents without history of fever and generalized symptoms. She has a severe electrolyte disturbance, muscle weakness, and hypokalemia. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this presentation?
items.explanation: Diuretics can cause hypokalemia and muscle weakness due to electrolyte disturbance.

items.question: A 25-year-old man has a fever and develops jaundice. His laboratory tests reveal markedly elevated bilirubin with direct hyperbilirubinemia and elevated transaminases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
items.explanation: Viral hepatitis presents acutely with fever, jaundice, and elevated bilirubin and transaminases.

items.question: A 75-year-old man with history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 3 years ago presents with worsening angina. Coronary angiogram shows severe stenosis in native left anterior descending and right coronary artery and patent venous grafts. What should be the most appropriate management?
options: PCI should undergo native coronary arteries prior to operative graft thrombectomy
items.explanation: Optimal medical therapy is recommended for management of recurrent angina in patients with patent venous grafts and severe stenosis in native coronary arteries. Repeat CABG or PCI should be considered if medical therapy fails or symptoms continue worsening.

items.question: All of the following are accepted indications for emergent operative embolectomy for acute arterial embolism except:
items.explanation: Operative embolectomy is NOT indicated with mild motor or sensory deficit, as these patients are often managed conservatively. Irreversible ischemic changes or severe symptoms require urgent intervention.

items.question: In a patient with toxic megacolon and deep vein thrombosis (DVT), what is the best method of diagnosing and localizing DVT in this patient’s management?
items.explanation: Doppler duplex ultrasound is the preferred initial diagnostic test for DVT in most patients due to its noninvasive nature and high sensitivity and specificity.

items.question: In the presence of an inferior myocardial infarction, which of the following is the most likely sign?
options: Right-sided heart failure and jugular venous distension
Severe chest pain with radiation to the left arm
Elevated ST segment in leads V1 and V2
items.explanation: Inferior myocardial infarction is associated with right ventricular involvement and may result in right-sided heart failure and jugular venous distension.

items.question: Which one is unsatisfying the abdomen of an otherwise healthy young adult with symptomatic primary bradycardic cholecystectomy when indicated?
items.explanation: Cholecystectomy is the appropriate treatment for symptomatic primary bradycardic cholecystectomy when indicated.

items.question: Place the patient in Trendelenburg position
options: Increased MAP, decreased SVR, increased CVP
Decreased MAP, decreased SVR, increased CVP
Increased MAP, decreased SVR, decreased CVP
Decreased MAP, increased SVR, decreased CVP
items.explanation: Placing the patient in Trendelenburg position increases MAP, decreases SVR, and increases CVP.

items.question: Creation of pneumoperitoneum leads to the following changes associated with decreased MAP, increased SVR, increased CVP
options: Increased MAP, decreased SVR, increased CVP
Decreased MAP, increased SVR, decreased CVP
Increased MAP, increased SVR, increased CVP
Decreased MAP, decreased SVR, decreased CVP
items.explanation: Creation of pneumoperitoneum leads to decreased MAP, increased SVR, and decreased CVP due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and its effects.

items.question: Which of the following patients is most appropriate for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy instead of open cholecystectomy?
options: 42-year-old man without significant comorbidities with a symptomatic gallbladder stone
85-year-old woman with a small asymptomatic reducible ventral hernia
21-year-old man underwent major abdominal surgery with hiatus hernia repair
35-year-old woman unilateral right side femoral hernia and history of cardiac insufficiency
42-year-old woman with unilateral left side femoral hernia and history of congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 35%
items.explanation: A 42-year-old man without significant comorbidities and symptomatic gallbladder stone is most appropriate for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

items.question: Which study design is most appropriate for comparing major activity in the S phase of cell cycle, between patients with lymphomas and healthy participants?
items.explanation: Cross-sectional studies are observational and analyze data from a population at a specific point in time, making them suitable for comparing characteristics like cell cycle activity between two groups.

items.question: The planning phase of study design is important for:
items.explanation: Proper planning in study design helps reduce selection bias, prevent loss of follow-up, and ensures appropriate sample size calculation among other benefits.

items.question: In clinical studies, a double-blind study means:
options: Neither participants nor investigators know group assignments
Only participants are unaware of intervention
Only investigators are unaware of intervention
Both participants and investigators know group assignments
Investigators know but participants do not
items.explanation: Double-blind studies are designed so that neither the participants nor the investigators know which group the participants belong to, minimizing bias.

items.question: 1. Approved strategies for cancer chemoprevention include
items.explanation: Pharmacological agents, including antiestrogens, antiproliferative agents, and retinoids (vitamin A derivatives), represent the most commonly used chemopreventive agents.

items.question: 2. In patients with difficult-to-heal or recurrent inguinal hernia, the recommended approach is
items.explanation: Laparoscopic repair (TEP) is the most commonly used approach for difficult-to-heal or recurrent cases due to its advantages over open repair, including reduced chronic pain and lower recurrence rates.

items.question: Regarding Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and TAPP procedure, which of the following is NOT true?
options: The indications for laparoscopic RYGB are the same as for open RYGB.
Patients with Barrett's esophagus or severe colonic diverticular disease are better candidates for laparoscopic RYGB than for sleeve gastrectomy.
Conversion from a laparoscopic to an open procedure for RYGB is associated with a higher risk of internal hernia.
Concomitant hernia repair during RYGB is associated with an increased risk of the excessive weight loss.
items.explanation: Lower risk of internal hernia.

items.question: During laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair care must be taken in an area known as the 'triangle of doom'. What structure is located within this triangle?
items.explanation: The 'triangle of doom' is an area encountered during laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair that contains the external iliac artery and vein, and care must be taken to avoid injury to these vessels.

items.question: The indications for laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy include all of the following except:
options: Obesity with BMI between 40-45 kg/m2 with one or more risks/benefits/related obesity
BMI 30-40 kg/m2 with uncontrolled type II diabetes and/or hypertension
Body mass index 35 kg/m2 with severe obstructive sleep apnea syndrome
Body mass index between 30 and 35 kg/m2 with severe obesity related comorbid conditions
Body mass index >60 kg/m2 as first step for biliopancreatic diversion
items.explanation: Uncontrolled psychiatric illness and lack of compliance contraindicate sleeve gastrectomy. Body mass index between 30-35 with severe obesity related comorbidities is a typical indication, not an exception.

items.question: Regarding the use of monopolar diathermy, which of the following statements is true?
options: In monopolar diathermy, the electric current returned to the patient's body through the active electrode
Monopolar diathermy is preferable in patients with pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators
Use of monopolar diathermy in delicate propolar diathermy is ideal for delicate propolar diathermy
Laparoscopic diathermy is more safe than open surgery techniques
Use of bipolar diathermy has more thermal spread than monopolar diathermy
items.explanation: Laparoscopic diathermy is safer compared to open surgery as it uses precise energy application and reduces burn injury to intra-abdominal structures.

items.question: Regarding Gastrectomy, all the following statements are true except:
options: Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy is the most commonly used type of bariatric surgery
Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy is easier to perform than Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass
Sleeve Gastrectomy has greater risk of esophageal reflux than laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass
Biliopancreatic Diversion with Duodenal Switch has higher morbidity than Sleeve Gastrectomy
Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy is contraindicated in patients older than 65 years
items.explanation: Sleeve Gastrectomy is not contraindicated based solely on age, and can be successfully performed in selected patients over 65 years with comorbidities.

items.question: 21. In primary hyperparathyroidism, the following biochemical changes may be seen, anticipating post-surgery bone hunger:
items.explanation: Hyperparathyroidism often results in increased bone turnover, leading to elevated alkaline phosphatase levels which can predict the severity of bone disease and the risk of post-surgery bone hunger syndrome (hypocalcemia).

items.question: 22. Excision of thymus is mandatory in the treatment of:
options: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
Multinodular carcinoma of the thyroid gland
items.explanation: Thymectomy is required in cases of primary hyperparathyroidism with multigland involvement often because ectopic parathyroid tissue can be located in or near the thymus.

items.question: 19. Which one of the following bowel layers contains Brunner's glands and should be included during suturing of bowel?
items.explanation: Brunner's glands are located in the submucosa of the duodenum and proper closure of this layer is essential in bowel suturing to prevent leakage.

items.question: 20. Standard treatment of type III gastric carcinoid is:
options: Total gastrectomy with an ethylic resection
items.explanation: Type III gastric carcinoids are aggressive tumors requiring radical D2 gastrectomy with lymph node dissection.

items.question: 18. Which of the following bariatric procedures is NOT accepted for weight reduction?
items.explanation: Esophagopexy is not a recognized bariatric procedure for weight loss, unlike the others listed which are established surgical treatments for obesity.

items.question: All of the following statements regarding papillary thyroid carcinoma are correct EXCEPT:
options: Thyroid papillary carcinoma is the most common tumor of thyroid gland.
The inferior thyroid vein pierces pretracheal fascia to drain into the brachiocephalic vein.
The inferior laryngeal nerve lies in trachea-esophageal groove.
Central lymph node metastases are more common in recurrent laryngeal nerve.
Regional lymph node metastases are common.
items.explanation: The inferior thyroid vein pierces pretracheal fascia to drain into the left brachiocephalic vein, not the brachiocephalic vein, it's part of the thyroid drainage system.

items.question: The following statements regarding papillary thyroid carcinoma and isthmus resection are true:
options: Total thyroidectomy and isthmus resection is the treatment of choice in cases of thyroid carcinoma.
The inferior thyroid vein is a highly vascular structure supplied by arterial branches from the superior thyroid artery.
SBA MCQs for MRCS part 2 099: The thyroid gland is highly vascularised by arterial branches of the external carotid artery.
Isthmus is present in central part of thyroid, and is divided into left and right lobes.
The inferior thyroid vein drains into the internal jugular vein.
items.explanation: Isthmus is the central part of the thyroid gland dividing it into right and left lobes. The vascular supply and venous drainage involve different arteries and veins other than the external carotid artery and internal jugular vein, respectively.

items.question: Thyroid cancer is usually diagnosed by:
items.explanation: Ultrasound and fine needle aspiration cytology are the standard methods used to diagnose thyroid cancer.

items.question: 26. In a patient diagnosed to have a one cm insulinoma at the junction between body and tail of pancreas, the preferred treatment is
items.explanation: As it is a well-defined solitary insulinoma less than 2 cm, enucleation is preferred.

items.question: 27. Primary sternotomy thyroid carcinoma
items.explanation: Papillary and follicular thyroid carcinoma are to be malignant but well differentiated. Undifferentiated thyroid carcinomas believe that anaplastic thyroid carcinomas are the most common tumors to be malignant and aggressive, treated by surgery and radiotherapy.

items.question: 28. Which of the following statements about recurrent thyroid tumor is the most common functional
options: Cough is the most common functional complication of recurrent thyroid tumor
items.explanation: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve is the most common functional complication of recurrent thyroid tumor.

items.question: Which of the following procedures is the best treatment for insulinoma located in the tail of pancreas?
items.explanation: Insulinomas are usually solitary and benign tumors with 90% being less than 2 cm in size. Enucleation is the preferred surgical treatment to preserve pancreatic function.

items.question: 31. Which of the following statements is not true regarding primary malignancy of the GI tract?
options: The GI tract's most common site of primary extranodal lymphoma is the stomach.
Gastric lymphomas represent most common site of GI lymphoma.
Colonoscopy with biopsy is nonspecific diagnostic modality of primary lymphoma and demonstrated tumor.
H. pylori eradication therapy plays a role in the treatment of gastric lymphoma.
items.explanation: Esophageal lymphomas are non-Hodgkin lymphomas, not Hodgkin lymphomas.

items.question: 32. One of the following statements is not true regarding gastric intestinal metaplasia:
options: Gastric intestinal metaplasia is a preneoplastic lesion of the surface and glandular epithelium of stomach.
It is increased in patients with intestinal epithelium by intestinal epithelial cells.
Complete intestinal metaplasia is done based on the presence of absorptive cells and brush border and crypts similar to intestinal epithelium.
The diagnosis of gastric intestinal metaplasia is based on endoscopy mapping and surveillance upper endoscopy.
Incomplete intestinal metaplasia is characterized by small intestinal-type mucosa with goblet cells, a brush border, and absorptive cells.
items.explanation: It is increased in patients with intestinal epithelium, not by intestinal epithelial cells; this statement is incorrect as phrased.

items.question: 33. Rectal small bowel tumors which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
options: Both colonic and small bowel tumors are more common in the distal small bowel
Both colonic and small bowel tumors are more common in the distal small bowel
Both colonic and small bowel tumors are more common in the distal small bowel
Both colonic and small bowel tumors are more common in the distal small bowel
Both colonic and small bowel tumors are more common in the distal small bowel
items.explanation: Benign tumors are more common in the distal small bowel.

items.question: 34. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the endoscopic features of Crohn's colitis?
options: The characteristic feature of Crohn's colitis is the presence of segmental involvement with skip lesions
The involvement of the terminal ileum is common
The colon mucosa reveals a typically cobblestone appearance
Ulcers are predominantly linear, small and superficial
items.explanation: Ulcers are usually deep and longitudinal with cobblestone appearance.

items.question: 35. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for ischemic colitis?

items.question: 53. Which of the following statements regarding surgical treatment of pancreatic cancer is TRUE?
options: Involvement of the superior mesenteric artery is a contraindication to Whipple operation.
Preoperative biliary stenting is associated with improved survival.
Pylorus preserving operation is better than Whipple operation from the nutritional point of view.
The 5-year survival of Whipple operation for carcinoma of the head of pancreas is around 40%.
Total pancreatectomy is associated with improved survival.
items.explanation:
Answer: C?
A 56-year-old previously healthy physician notices that eyes are yellow and he has pain in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound and CT scan demonstrate a mass in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasound suggests involvement of the superior mesenteric vein. Which of the following statements regarding his treatment and prognosis is true?
A Total pancreatectomy is associated with improved survival.
B Involvement of the superior mesenteric vein is a contraindication to pancreaticoduodenectomy.
C Involvement of the superior mesenteric artery is a contraindication to pancreaticoduodenectomy.
D Pylorus preservation is never indicated at the time of pancreaticoduodenectomy.
E Preoperative biliary stenting is associated with improved survival after pancreaticoduodenectomy.
Answer: C? Lange5 net
Involvement of the superior mesenteric artery by a pancreatic tumor precludes resection for cure and therefore is a contraindication to proceeding with a Whipple procedure or pancreaticoduodenectomy. Involvement of the superior mesenteric vein does not necessarily preclude resection for cure as 2 to 3 cm of the portal vein/superior mesenteric vein can be resected and an end-to-end anastomosis or venous bypass be performed. Pyloric preservation is a well-excepted modification of the Whipple procedure. Total pancreatectomy is reserved for patients with extensive low-grade or cystic intraductal papillary lesions involving most of the pancreas. Preoperative biliary stenting is controversial with regard to risk of increased infectious complications postoperatively and preoperative stenting does not improve survival.

items.question: What is the most appropriate initial treatment for a symptomatic simple (congenital) hepatic cyst?
items.explanation: She does not require any further therapy. In instances where gallbladder carcinoma is discovered incidentally during cholecystectomy and is shown to have only invaded the mucosa and submucosa it is classified as stage I. The 5-year survival for these patients is 100% and no further treatment is required as for more advanced lesions, that is, those penetrating the muscular layer or with lymph node involvement (stages II & III). Here there is a higher incidence of local and regional spread to the liver and porta hepatis lymph nodes, respectively. For these patients an en bloc resection of segments 4 and 5 of the liver is performed along with dissection of celiac axis and porta hepatis lymph nodes. For more advanced lesions (stage IV), the prognosis is very poor, and further resection is not indicated. Gallbladder carcinoma responds poorly to radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

items.question: A 43-year-old woman undergoes open cholecystectomy. Intra-operative cholangiogram revealed multiple stones in the CBD. Exploration of the CBD was performed to extract gallstones. options: Extraction of the stone through the pathway created by the T-tube (after 6 weeks)

items.explanation: If a stone is detected, the T tube should be left in place for 6 weeks to allow the tract to mature. At this time, the T tube can be removed, and the stone can be extracted by using a Dormia basket under fluoroscopy. This approach is indicated only when the T-tube larger than 16 has been inserted. If this approach is not feasible, the stone can be extracted by retrograde endoscopic techniques or CBD exploration.

items.question: Following recovery in the hospital from a fracture of the femur, a 70-year-old nursing home female patient develops right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever. She has tenderness in the right subcostal region. There is evidence of progressive sepsis and hemodynamic instability. The WBC count is 24,000. A bedside sonogram confirms the presence of acalculous cholecystitis. What should treatment involve?
items.explanation: Obstruction of the cystic duct may be caused by factors other than stones. Acalculous cholecystitis carries a high mortality because it occurs in patients who are already critically ill. Furthermore, the establishment of the diagnosis is often delayed. Urgent cholecystostomy should be performed. In recent years, percutaneous cholecystostomy under CT or ultrasonography (US) guidance is performed more commonly than surgical cholecystectomy, because it carries a lower operative mortality rate. In a stable patient, cholecystectomy may be considered.

items.question: Which of the following investigations is most accurate in the localization of gastrinoma?
items.explanation: More than 90% of gastrinomas have receptors for somatostatin. Octreotide scanning (somatostatin receptor scintigraphy) has been shown to be the most sensitive test for localization of gastrinomas. However, successful localization depends on size and location. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is poor for very small (<1.1 cm) tumors and for small primary duodenal tumors. Duodenal gastrinomas are best.

items.question: Six months after laparoscopic splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura, a 38-year-old woman with lupus remains thrombocytopenic (platelet count, 42,000 cells/mm3). The next step should be:
items.explanation: The treatment of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is generally medical. Corticosteroids achieve a response in about two thirds of patients. Intravenous IgG and plasmapheresis have also been used acutely to increase platelet levels in patients with bleeding due to severely reduced platelet counts (typically several with platelet counts <20,000/μL). Spontaneous bleeding with a platelet count above this level is unusual, and platelet transfusion is not needed. Intravenous IgG and plasmapheresis have only short-term effects, and are not definitive treatment for thrombocytopenia. The diagnosis of ITP might be in doubt, but the presence of an accessory spleen must first be excluded. The presence of splenic tissue can be diagnosed by examination of the blood smear for Howell-Jolly bodies, which appear in the red cells of asplenic patients. Persistent splenic tissue can be confirmed by a technetium radionuclide scan. There is no indication that this patient is at risk for thrombotic events, and aspirin is not indicated.

items.question: Three weeks after admission to the ICU with acute pancreatitis, a 40-year-old man develops worsening respiratory failure, renal insufficiency, and an elevated WBC count to 28,000. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast reveals an area of non-enhancement. CT-guided fine needle aspiration cultures grow Escherichia coli bacteria. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. The next step in management should be:
options: Endoscopic transgastric drainage of the pancreas
items.explanation: Acute pancreatitis is most commonly caused by gallstones or alcohol consumption. Most episodes are self-limited and leave the patient without significant morbidity or mortality. However, in 15% to 20% of cases severe acute pancreatitis leads to systemic organ failure and local complications such as pancreatic pseudocyst, intra-abdominal or gastrointestinal hemorrhage, pancreatic or enteric fistulas, and pancreatic necrosis. Necrotizing pancreatitis is defined as pancreatitis with devitalized or nonviable tissue. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast and thin cuts through the pancreas can determine whether nonviable pancreatic tissue is present. If pancreatic necrosis is present, then image-guided aspiration of the nonenhancing pancreas is helpful to determine whether pancreatic necrosis is infected or noninfected. If bacteria grow from the aspirate culture in a patient with worsening sepsis or multiorgan system failure, operation is indicated. Surgical debridement of the pancreas can be performed through an open midline incision. The lesser sac is entered and the pancreas is gently debrided along with the left and retroperitoneum region, which can also be necrotic. Multiple debridements in the operating room may be required until thick necrotic tissue is removed. Some surgeons place irrigation catheters, whereas others place large drains after the debridement. Image-guided percutaneous drainage of the pancreas can be effective for a pancreatic abscess, but is not necrotic pancreatic tissue can only be debrided operatively. This patient with evidence of pancreatic necrosis and infected ERCP, percutaneous drainage, and distal pancreatectomy is not indicated.

items.question: Which of the following would be most accurate in making the diagnosis of malrotation in a patient with bilious vomiting?
options: Abdominal and pelvic computed tomographic (CT) scan
items.explanation: Malrotation includes a number of midgut congenital abnormalities resulting from improper rotation and fixation during gestation and occurs at a rate of 1 in 500 live births. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study is the preferred modality for diagnosis because the plain films rarely are suggestive of malrotation and other imaging methods are less sensitive or less specific. Immediate diagnostic imaging is indicated for any infant with bilious vomiting.

items.question: An 11-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of increasing right scrotal pain, now associated with mild hemi scrotal swelling and tenderness. The most likely diagnosis is:
items.explanation: Mullerian and mesonephric vestiges are common on both the testis and epididymis. Many of these appendices are pedunculated, making them more prone to torsion and infarction. Because many are Mullerian duct remnants, the peak incidence for clinical presentation of a torsed appendix is just before puberty, coinciding with a physiologic estrogen surge. The mullerian remnants become swollen and top heavy, and more susceptible to torsion. Pain is the common presenting symptom, often with gradual onset and relative mildness. There may be considerable delay before the child is brought to emergency department because symptoms do not subside. A careful examination may reveal a firm, exquisitely tender, pea-sized nodule in the upper scrotum attached to the epididymis or testis. Diagnosis is safe using Doppler ultrasound confirming the testis is not torsed. Treatment consists of analgesics.

items.question: A 13-year-old child presents with a hard, non-tender swelling in the right lobe of the thyroid gland which has been present for 4 months. What is the most likely histopathological diagnosis?
items.explanation: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common pediatric thyroid malignancy, representing 85-95% of cases. Pediatric thyroid cancers typically present as neck masses with no associated symptoms and thus come to medical attention at widely varying stages of disease progression. Papillary carcinoma tends to be more aggressive in children, with higher incidence of multifocality, lymph node metastases, and extracapsular extension.
